Para index in docroot: 2
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Buhot Reply :</text>
In the letter <throwit> I proposed a possible scenario
for the phase-separation instability of binary mixtures of
hard-core particles in the limit of high asymmetry between
large and small particles relating this transition to a
bond-percolation transition.
In his Comment </throwit><throwit> A. A. Louis claims that, at least
in the case of hard-spheres, the phase-separation transition
is </throwit><text font="italic">unrelated</text> to bond-percolation. In fact, the mapping
to bond-percolation relates to an instability of the homogeneous
phase and, in the case of hard-spheres (or hard-disks) it gives
only an upper bound for the packing fraction at the phase
separation transition.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 8
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">In many gravitational interactions between galaxies, gas and stars that
have been torn from either or both of the precursor galaxies can collect in
’tidal tails’. Star formation begins anew in these regions to produce ’tidal
dwarf galaxies’ <throwit> </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit>, giving insight into the process of galaxy formation through
the well-defined timescale of the interaction.
But tracking the star formation process has proved to be
difficult: the tidal dwarf galaxies with young stars showed no evidence of the
molecular gas out of which new stars form </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>. Here we report the
discovery of molecular gas (carbon monoxide emission) in two tidal dwarf
galaxies. In both cases, the molecular gas peaks at the same location as the
maximum in atomic-hydrogen density, unlike most gas-rich galaxies. We infer
from this that the molecular gas formed from the HI, rather than being torn
in molecular form from the interacting galaxies. Star formation in the tidal
dwarfs appears to mimic that process in normal spiral galaxies
like our own.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 10
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract. </text> We prove finiteness of the number of
smooth blow-downs on Fano manifolds
and boundedness
results for the geometry of
non projective Fano-like manifolds.
Our proofs use properness of Hilbert schemes
and Mori theory.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 1
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Non equilibrium in statistical and fluid mechanics.</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Ensembles and their equivalence.
Entropy driven intermittency.</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic">Giovanni Gallavotti</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center">Fisica, Università di Roma 1</p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center">P.le Moro 2, 00185 Roma, Italia</p>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text><text font="italic">We present a review of the chaotic hypothesis and
discuss its applications to intermittency in statistical mechanics and
fluid mechanics proposing a quantitative definition. Entropy creation
rate is interpreted in terms of certain intermittency phenomena. An
attempt to a theory of the experiment of Ciliberto–Laroche on the
fluctuation law is presented.</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 57
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="70%">Definition 1: </text><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%">A stationary ensemble </text><throwit /><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%"> for a system of
particles or for a fluid is the collection of </text><throwit /><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%"> distributions,
for given equations of motion, obtained by varying the parameters
entering into the equations.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 60
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="70%">Definition 2, </text><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%">(equivalence of ensembles):
Two thermostatting mechanisms are equivalent ‘‘in the thermodynamic
limit’’ if one can establish a one to one correspondence between the
elements of the ensembles </text><throwit /><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%"> and </text><throwit /><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%"> of SRB distributions
associated with the two models in such a way that the same observables,
in a certain class </text><throwit /><text font="typewriter" fontsize="70%"> of observables, have the same averages in
corresponding distributions, at least when some of the parameters of
the system are sent to suitable limiting values to which we assign the
generic name of ‘‘thermodynamic limit’’.</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Detector.</text> The description of the AMS detector is
presented in <throwit>.
All detector elements are used for particle identification in the present analysis:
the silicon tracker TRK, the permanent magnet, the time of flight
counters TOF, the anticoincidence counters ACC,
the transition radiation detector TRD, the ring imaging
Cherenkov detector RICH, and the electromagnetic
calorimeter ECAL.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Event selection and data samples.</text>
Over 65 billion
CR events have been recorded in the first 48 months
of AMS operations. Only events collected during normal
detector operating conditions are used in this analysis. This
includes the time periods when the AMS z axis is pointing
within 40<throwit> of the local zenith and when the ISS is not in the
South Atlantic Anomaly. Data analysis is performed in 57
absolute rigidity bins. The same binning as in our proton
flux measurement </throwit><throwit>
was chosen below 80.5 GV. Above
80.5 GV two to four proton bins are combined to
ensure sufficient antiproton statistics.
Events are selected requiring a track in the TRD and in
the inner tracker and a measured velocity </throwit><throwit> 0.3 in the
TOF corresponding to a downward-going particle. To
maximize the number of selected events while maintaining
an accurate rigidity measurement, the acceptance is
increased by releasing the requirements on the external
tracker layers, L1 and L9. Below 38.9 GV neither L1 nor
L9 is required. From 38.9 to 147 GV either L1 or L9 is
required. From 147 to 175 GV only L9 is required. Above
175 GV both L1 and L9 are required. In order to maximize
the accuracy of the track reconstruction, the </throwit><throwit>/d.o.f. of the
reconstructed track fit is required to be less than 10 both in
the bending and nonbending projections. The dE/dx
measurements in the TRD, the TOF, and the inner tracker
must be consistent with </throwit><throwit> = 1. To select only primary
CR, the measured rigidity is required to exceed the
maximum geomagnetic cutoff by a factor of 1.2 for either
positive or negative particles within the AMS field of view.
The cutoff is calculated by backtracing using the
most recent IGRF geomagnetic model.
Events satisfying the selection criteria are classified into
two categories: positive and negative rigidity events. A
total of 2.42 </throwit><throwit> events with positive rigidity are selected
as protons. They are 99.9</throwit><throwit> pure protons with almost no
background. Deuterons are not distinguished from protons,
their contribution decreases with rigidity: at 1 GV it is less
than 2</throwit><throwit> and at 20 GV it is 0.6</throwit><throwit>. The effective
acceptance of this selection for protons is larger than in our
proton flux publication </throwit><throwit>.
This is because there is no
strict requirement that selected particles pass through the
tracker layers L1 and L9 (see above) leading to a much
larger field of view at low rigidities and, therefore, to a
significant increase in the number of protons.
The negative rigidity event category comprises both
antiprotons and several background sources: electrons,
light negative mesons (</throwit><throwit> and a negligible amount of
</throwit><throwit>) produced in the interactions of primary CR
with the detector materials, and charge confused protons.
The contributions of the different background sources vary
with rigidity. For example, light negative mesons are
present only at rigidities below 10 GV, whereas charge
confusion becomes noticeable only at high rigidities.
Electron background is present at all rigidities. The
combination of information from the TRD, TOF, tracker,
RICH, and ECAL enables the efficient separation of the
antiproton signal events from these background sources
using a template fitting technique. The number of observed
antiproton signal events and its statistical error in the
negative rigidity sample are determined in each bin by
fitting signal and background templates to data by varying
their normalization. As discussed below, the template
variables used in the fit are constructed using information
from the TOF, tracker, and TRD. The distribution of the
variables for the template definition is the same for
antiprotons and protons if they are both reconstructed with
a correct charge-sign. This similarity has been verified with
the Monte Carlo simulation and the antiproton and
proton data of 2.97 </throwit><throwit> 18.0 GV. Therefore, the signal
template is always defined using the high-statistics proton
data sample. Three overlapping rigidity regions with different
types of template function are defined to maximize the
accuracy of the analysis: low absolute rigidity region (1.00-4.02 GV),
intermediate region (2.97-18.0 GV), and high
absolute rigidity region (16.6-450 GV). In the overlapping
rigidity bins, the results with the smallest error are selected.
At low rigidities, a cut on the TRD estimator </throwit><throwit> and
the velocity measurement in the TOF are important to
differentiate antiprotons from light particles (</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>).
Therefore, the mass distribution, calculated from the
rigidity measurement in the inner tracker and the velocity
measured by the TOF, is used to construct the templates and
to differentiate between the antiproton signal and the
background. The background </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> templates are
defined from the data sample selected using information
from the TRD, the RICH, and also the ECAL, when the
event can be measured by the ECAL.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12

the rigidity resolution function </throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit> is the corresponding effective acceptance
that includes geometric
acceptance as well as the trigger and selection efficiency,
and </throwit><throwit> is the exposure time.
Detector resolution effects cause migration of events </throwit><throwit>
from rigidity bin </throwit><throwit> to the measured rigidity bins </throwit><throwit>
resulting in the observed number of events </throwit><throwit>.
To account for this event migration, an iterative unfolding
procedure is used to correct the number of observed
events </throwit><throwit>.
The same procedure is used to unfold the observed number
of proton events.
The (</throwit><throwit>) flux ratio is defined for each absolute rigidity
bin by:</throwit></p>

We note that the </throwit><throwit>
ratio decreases from 1.15 at 1 GV to 1.04 at 450 GV due to the varying difference of
interaction cross sections for protons and antiprotons (and
considering bin-to-bin event migration).
With 3.49 </throwit><throwit> antiproton events, the accurate study of
systematic errors is the key part of the present analysis,
a detailed description can be found in </throwit><throwit>.
Overall systematic error on the antiproton-to-proton flux ratio ranges
from </throwit><throwit> at 1 GV to </throwit><throwit> in the last bin (259-450 GV)
with a minimum of </throwit><throwit> in the intermediate rigidity range (</throwit><throwit> GV)
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002179.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>This paper extends earlier work on the definition of
Wannier functions for Bloch electrons in a magnetic field.
Extensions to irrational as well as rational
magnetic fields are defined, and their properties investigated.
The results are used to give a generalisation of the Peierls
effective Hamiltonian which is valid when the magnetic flux per
unit cell is close to any rational number.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction</text>
Wannier functions are localised basis states which span
a band of Bloch eigenfunctions [1]. The use of localised
basis functions can be convenient both technically and
conceptually, particularly when considering perturbations
which are themselves spatially localised. There are
difficulties in defining satisfactory Wannier states
when a magnetic field is applied to the lattice.
Firstly, the eigenfunctions are typically not Bloch states:
in two dimensions the eigenfunctions are only Bloch states
if the ratio <throwit> of the flux quantum to the magnetic flux
per unit cell is a rational number [2,3] (in these cases I
will write </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are integers with no
common divisor). Secondly, even when the magnetic field is rational
in this sense, conventional Wannier states only have satisfactory
localisation properties if a topological invariant
(the Chern index) chararterising a Bloch band is equal to zero [4,5].
In a previous paper (reference [6]) it was shown how this
latter difficulty could be overcome, for two dimensional
lattices, in the case where the magentic flux per unit cell
is rational. In [6] I showed how to obtain a complete set of
states which span a Bloch band, and which retain all of the
useful properties of conventional Wannier functions.
Two different definitions were examined, termed type I
and type II Wannier functions.
The definition of these states contains the Chern index
</throwit><throwit> of the band, and in both cases they reduce to the
conventional Wannier function when </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Summary of earlier results</text>
The purpose of this section is to present, for the convenience
of the reader, a summary of some of the principal definitions
and equations from the earlier paper, reference [6]. The lattice vectors
are written <throwit>, and
the reprocal lattice vectors are </throwit><throwit>,
with </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Dense Associative Memory is Robust to Adversarial Inputs</text></p>
    <p>[0.10cm] 
<text font="smallcaps" fontsize="120%">Dmitry Krotov<throwit>, John J Hopfield</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[0.15cm]

<text font="smallcaps" fontsize="120%">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[0.15cm]</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001332.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction<throwit /></text>
Owing to QCD factorisation theorem for hard exclusive reactions
<throwit>
the dependence of the amplitude of the reaction
</throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with longitudinally polarised virtual photon
on the di-pion mass <throwit> factors out in an universal
(independent of the target) factor.
At leading order
in </throwit><throwit> this factor has the form
</throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Here <throwit> is the two-pion light cone
distribution amplitude (</throwit><throwit>DA) </throwit><throwit>,
which depends on
</throwit><throwit>–longitudinal momentum carried by the quark, </throwit><throwit>
characterising the distribution of longitudinal momentum between
the two pions</throwit><throwit>,
and the invariant mass of produced pions </throwit><throwit>,
the superscript </throwit><throwit> standing for isospin of produced pions
(</throwit><throwit>).
The dependence on the virtuality of the incident photon
</throwit><throwit> is governed by the ERBL evolution equation
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Deviations from the asymptotic form <throwit /></text>
The first non-trivial deviation from the asymptotic form of the
<throwit>DA occurs in </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> waves
</throwit><throwit>. Generically their effect on </throwit><throwit> dependence of the
hard amplitude can be written as:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> are Legendre polynomials and
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are the </throwit><throwit>-wave and the
</throwit><throwit>-wave </throwit><throwit> scattering phase shifts,
which are well known from low-energy experiments.
The functions </throwit><throwit> describe the deviation of the amplitude’s </throwit><throwit>
dependence from the asymptotic form.
These functions are real and can be parametrised as:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The dependence of <throwit> on </throwit><throwit> is governed by the
QCD evolution and in leading order is given by:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>With increasing <throwit>, the parameters </throwit><throwit> go
logarithmically to zero and one reproduces the asymptotic
formula (</throwit><throwit>).
The parameters </throwit><throwit> are directly related to partonic structure
of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> mesons, see section 4 and ref </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10

    <p><text font="bold">3. Angular distributions of produced pions<throwit /></text>
Another way to obtain sensitivity to the
non-asymptotic parameters <throwit>
is to study the
two pion angular distributions.
From the expression of the amplitude (</throwit><throwit>) one can derive
the </throwit><throwit> dependence of intensity densities
</throwit><throwit> defined as:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> are spherical harmonics, </throwit><throwit>
is the azimuthal angle between the pion decay plane and plane
formed by momentum of the virtual photon and total momentum
of produced </throwit><throwit> system.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">4. Expected values for the parameters<throwit /></text>
By crossing relations the parameter
<throwit> is related to the third moment of the valence quark distribution
in the pion </throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>If the parametrisation suggested in <throwit> is used for the
quark distributions in the pion, we obtain the values of the parameter
</throwit><throwit> listed in Table </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">5. Results of fits to the HERA data<throwit /></text>
Recently data on di-pion mass distribution in hard exclusive reaction
was measured at HERA by the reaction</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>This section presents attempts to fit HERA data
by the leading twist parametrisations described in the sections above.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">6. Discussion of the results and conclusions<throwit /></text>
The analysis presented here is based on the
leading order, twist-2 formalism. The power corrections
(higher twist contributions) to the
amplitude of the reaction (<throwit>) are systematically
neglected. The size of higher twist corrections
might be rather large </throwit><throwit>, so that they constitute the
main theoretical systematic uncertainty in our analysis.
On general grounds the higher twist effects should be smaller
for such observables as the shape of the di-pion mass distribution
considered here, also the study of angular distribution of produced
pions as discussed in section 3 can be used to minimise the contributions
of higher twists.
Another source of theoretical errors is that we fixed values of
parameters </throwit><throwit> by the model values (</throwit><throwit>).
Hopefully more precise data
will allow us to measure these parameters.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 33

the National Foundation for Scientific Reseach (FNRS).
M.V.P. is supported by RFBR grant 96-15-96764, by DFG and BMBF.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 27
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">Non-Interactive Key Transport Scheme.</text>
SGX uses an AES-based CMAC <throwit>.
This is a symmetric signature scheme using the same key for signature creation and verification.
Hence, local attestation already provides a shared symmetric secret between enclaves, namely the report key.
Any enclave can sign reports for a target by issuing </throwit><verbatim font="typewriter">EREPORT</verbatim>.
Although it has no direct access to the target enclave’s report key, it can indirectly use it via the <verbatim font="typewriter">EREPORT</verbatim> instruction.
In turn, the target enclave is able to access its own report key via <verbatim font="typewriter">EGETKEY</verbatim>.
We use this symmetry of report keys to derive fresh encryption keys.</p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Recent Progress in PYTHIA<throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[10mm]
<text fontsize="144%">Torbjörn Sjöstrand<throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[3mm]
<text font="italic">Department of Theoretical Physics,</text></p>
    <p>[1mm]
<text font="italic">Lund University, Lund, Sweden</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]
<inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="384.1pt">
        <para xml:id="p3.p1">
          <p>PYTHIA is a general-purpose event generator for multiparticle production
in high-energy physics. After a general introduction and program news
survey, some areas of recent physics progress are considered:
the matching to matrix elements, especially for <throwit> production;
charm and bottom hadronization; multiple interactions; and
interconnection effects. The report concludes with some words on the
future, specifically the ongoing transition to C++.</throwit></p>
        </para>
      </inline-para></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 53

    <p><text font="bold">For the time series analysis, we define the on-off time series
as follows.
Let us associate 0 or 1 with each unit according to the value
of <throwit>, that is, 0 for </throwit><throwit> and 1 for </throwit><throwit>.
We call the former the off-state and the latter
the on-state,
and the sequence of 0 and 1 as a function of time
the on-off time series.
As shown in Fig.15,
at almost all times, there exists only one
on-state, and whenever the long-pulse unit changes
from the on-state
to the off-state, the short-pulse unit becomes the on-state.
That is, the short-pulse unit plays a role of switching.
This is the same phenomenon as observed in §2 and §3.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

See Fig.25, 26, 27, 28.

notice that the duration time </throwit><throwit> for the long pulse unit
is nearly twice as the duration time </throwit><throwit>
for the short-pulse unit. On the other hand,
in the case of even member of units, although
there are various duration times,
we can find two peaks of the long duration time and the short one.
That is, in the chaotic state, the role of
each unit changes dynamically.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 73
<para xml:id="p71">
    <p><text font="bold">Now, let us see what happens in this system.
The behavior of the system depends on the
increase rate of the antigen <throwit>.
If </throwit><throwit> is large enough, say </throwit><throwit>,
the concentration of the antigen </throwit><throwit> increases
infinitely and the system is completely invaded
and destroyed by the antigen</throwit><throwit>.
If </throwit><throwit> is less than some value, say </throwit><throwit>,
the system copes with the antigens completely.
The number of antigens finally become small and the system
settles near to a clustering state depending on
the initial condition. Thus, in this case
there is no memory of the invasion by antigens.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">From this figure, we note that the response time is shorter in
the state in which the units 2 and 3 are
in the long-pulse units.
In the resultant attractor the units 2 and 3 are the long-pulse units.
This result implies
that the system modifies itself
so as to neutralize the antigen as effectively as possible.
Thus, it seems that the resultant state can respond
much better than other states. <throwit>Therefore, we can state
that the resultant attractor is viewed as
a kind of memory of the invasion
by the antigen.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 78
<para xml:id="p76">
    <p><text font="bold">Further, we scanned the initial value of <throwit> with </throwit><throwit>
fixed to 0.7. For </throwit><throwit>, the system settles
to a clustering state. On the other hand, for </throwit><throwit>
the system tends to a fixed point and the network collapses.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 79
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p77">
    <p><text font="bold" framed="underline">Case 2</text><text font="bold" /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 80
<para xml:id="p78">
    <p><text font="bold">Next, we consider the case that an antigen <throwit>
interacts only with the antibody </throwit><throwit> in the 3-unit closed network.
(Fig.33).</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 81
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p79">
    <p><text font="bold">In this case, we set the thresholds depending on units in order to
obtain clustering states.
Here, we introduce new notations of thresholds, </text><throwit /><text font="bold">,
</text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> as follows.
</text><throwit /><text font="bold"> is the threshold over which the </text><throwit /><text font="bold">-th antibody
recognizes other antibodies. </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> is the
threshold over which the antibody </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> recognizes
the antigen and </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> is the
threshold over which the antigen </text><throwit /><text font="bold">
recognizes the antibody </text><throwit /><text font="bold">.
Then the equation for the antigen </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> is</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">The first term expresses the decrease of the antigen
by neutralization by the antibody 1 and the second term represents
the continuous invasion of the antigen.
The sensitivity </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> of the </text><throwit /><text font="bold">-th unit is modified to</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">where </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> is the strength of the
interaction between </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold">.
We put </text><throwit /><text font="bold">, where </text><throwit /><text font="bold">
is the Kronecker’s delta.
The behavior of this network strongly depends
on the thresholds, the value of connectivity </text><throwit /><text font="bold">,
the initial value of the antigen </text><throwit /><text font="bold">
and the rate of invasion of the antigen </text><throwit /><text font="bold">.
If these values are taken appropriately,
the concentration of the antigen oscillates in some range.
See Fig.34.</text><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 82
<para xml:id="p80">
    <p><text font="bold">As in the case 1, the unit 1 which can
interact with the antigen is activated and
finally settles near to the long-pulse state.
See Fig.35.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 83
<para xml:id="p81">
    <p><text font="bold">It turns out that the relaxation time of the
concentration of the antigen is comparable in this state
with in the state where
the unit 1 is in the short-pulse state.
See Fig.36.<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 84
<para xml:id="p82">
    <p><text font="bold">When we compare this result with the result in the case 1,
it is considered that the number of units
which can interact with antigens is important for the
relaxation time.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 85
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p83">
    <p><text font="bold" framed="underline">Case 3</text><text font="bold" /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 86
<para xml:id="p84">
    <p><text font="bold">Now, let us consider the network with 4-units.
We assume that the antigen (<throwit>) has
a similar three-dimensional structure to the
antibody 1 and then can interact
with the unit 2, 3 and 4, but cannot interact
with the unit 1.
See Fig.37.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 87
<para xml:id="p85">
    <p><text font="bold">The differential equation for the antigen is</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">For the unit <throwit>, the differential equations are</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 88
<para xml:id="p87">
    <p><text font="bold">If we break the symmetry of the connectivity matrix
by lowering the threshold of one of the four units,
for some initial condition this
unit stays in the short-pulse state
and other units stay in the long-pulse states,
and so the clustering takes place(Fig.38).
For some other initial conditions, chaotic states appear.
That is, in this case chaos and
the clustering states coexist.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 89
<para xml:id="p88">
    <p><text font="bold">From the result of the case 1, it is expected that
the relaxation time of the system is short
when the unit which resembles the antigen
is in the short-pulse state.
Further, from the result of the case 2,
it is expected that the more is the number of units
which interact with the antigens, the shorter is the relaxation time.
Thus, here we investigate the relaxation time for the
following three cases.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 90
<para xml:id="p89">
    <p><text font="bold">Case a. The unit 1 is in the short-pulse state.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 91
<para xml:id="p90">
    <p><text font="bold">Case b. The unit 1 is in the long-pulse state.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 92
<para xml:id="p91">
    <p><text font="bold">Case c. The system is chaos.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 93
<para xml:id="p92">
    <p><text font="bold">We show the result in Fig.39.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 94
<para xml:id="p93">
    <p><text font="bold">The relaxation time <throwit> for the case a
is shortest and </throwit><throwit> for the case b
is longest. </throwit><throwit> for the case c is
in between </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.
From this result, it is considered that
chaos is more effective than the clustering states
to prepare for various types of antigens.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 95
<para xml:id="p94">
    <p><text font="bold">§7. Summary and discussions<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 96
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p95">
    <p><text font="bold">In this paper, we studied the three models of the immune network
for small number of degrees of freedom </text><throwit /><text font="bold">,
the original model introduced by Bersini et.al.,
the modified model with different functions
of the maturation and the proliferation of B-cells
from those of the original model, and the modified model
with a threshold over which antibodies can recognize other antibodies
and antigens. First, we summarize common characteristics
of these models.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 97
<para xml:id="p96">
    <p><text font="bold">In these models there exist limit cycle states and chaotic states.
We investigated bifurcation structures obtained by
changing several parameters
and found that the transitions to chaos are Intermittency
by heteroclinic intersections.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 98
<para xml:id="p97">
    <p><text font="bold">There is a peculiar type of limit cycle.
In this limit cycle, the permutational symmetry of the system
is broken and concentrations of antibodies and B-cells
oscillate in a characteristic manner. We call this the clustering
state.<throwit>In the clustering state, for example in the
three-unit system,
there are two long-pulse units
in which the concentrations of antibodies are large
and one short-pulse unit in which the concentration
of the antibody is small.
Two long-pulse units oscillate in anti-phase to each other.
At almost all times, only one unit has a
large concentration of the antibody.
The short-pulse unit
plays a role of ”switching” the long-pulse units which
take the large concentrations.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 99
<para xml:id="p98">
    <p><text font="bold">On the other hand, in the state of chaos,
no such explicit division of roles exist,
but each unit changes its role dynamically.
That is, in chaos, a dynamical
change of roles takes place.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 100
<para xml:id="p99">
    <p><text font="bold">We investigated the invasion by antigens
when the clustering takes place.
We found that
when the number of antigens is not too many and interaction between
antigens and antibodies continues for an appropriate period,
the unit which can interact with
antigens settles near to the long-pulse unit after
the concentration of antigens is reduced to small values
in some range of a parameter.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 101
<para xml:id="p100">
    <p><text font="bold">By investigating the relaxation time,
we found that in the clustering state
the relaxation time depends on what state
the system stays in.
In the case 1 that the two units interact with antigens
the relaxation time is short or long
when the unit which interacts with antigens is in the long-pulse unit
or short-pulse unit, respectively.
On the other hand, in the case 2 that
only one unit interacts with antigens
the relaxation time takes similar value both in the long-pulse
unit and in the short-pulse unit.
Thus, if many units can interact with antigens
by the invasion of the antigens
the system moves to the state in which the response to
antigens is most efficient. Thus, the clustering state is
considered to be a memory of the invasion by antigens.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 102
<para xml:id="p101">
    <p><text font="bold">Further, we checked that the system is robust
against the symmetry breaking perturbations.
Chaotic and periodic states change only a little by these
perturbations.<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 103
<para xml:id="p102">
    <p><text font="bold">As for the modified model with thresholds, we observed a interesting
feature.
The feature is the positive aspect of chaos
in response to the invasion by antigens.
In this model there is the coexistence of chaos and clustering states
when
the thresholds are chosen appropriately depending on units.
In the response to the antigen invasion,
we found that
the relaxation time in chaotic state
takes an intermediate value between the large
and the small response times in the two types of clustering states.
This suggests a positive aspect of chaos in immune networks,
that is, the possibility that chaos
may cope with the invasion by any kinds of
antigens equally well.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 104
<para xml:id="p103">
    <p><text font="bold">Now, let us discuss the cause of
the appearance of clustering state.
This is related to the mechanism of the switching of long-pulse units
or the dynamical role change.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 105
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p104">
    <p><text font="bold">Let us consider the 3-unit closed chain.
See Fig.5(b), 10(b) and 40.
In the present interaction, any two units tend to
oscillate in opposite phases.
If the concentration of the antibody
in one unit, say </text><throwit /><text font="bold">, increases,
then the sensitivities of other two units become large.
By this, the second terms of the differential equations for </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and
</text><throwit /><text font="bold">
become large and </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> decrease.
This is a kind of ’winner takes all’ mechanism.
Then, the sensitivity </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> becomes small.
Thus, when </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> becomes large, the third term
of the differential equation for </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> becomes small
compared to the other two terms. Thus,
next </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> begins decreasing.
This causes the decrease of </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold">
and the increase of </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold">.
Since </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> and </text><throwit /><text font="bold"> begin to increase from small values,
these take similar values. However, when these become rather large,
two units are forced to stay in states
with opposite phases each other.
Thus, one increases further and the other decreases.
At this stage, for the clustering state,
the increasing unit is fixed to the long-pulse
unit, but for chaos, it is not fixed and the dynamical change of the
switching role takes place.
Therefore, the behavior of the switching is
due to the ’winner takes all’ mechanism and the
’anti-ferro’ type interaction between any two units.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 106
<para xml:id="p105">
    <p><text font="bold">Next, let us discuss the causes of different behaviors
between the original model and the modified model without
threshold.<throwit>We studied influences of each of the terms
in the 3-unit closed chain system.
We pay attention to the unit 1 only,
(</throwit><throwit>,</throwit><throwit>),
because we consider the case that
the system has the permutational symmetry.
The differential equations of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
are</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">Here, we denote each term in the above equations as
follows.</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">We compare the time sequence in the original model
with that in the modified model.
See Fig.41,42.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 107
<para xml:id="p106">
    <p><text font="bold">In these figures, solid lines denote
<throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, large dotted lines represent
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, small dotted lines represent
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, respectively.
We note that the terms concerning the
maturation and the proliferation give the biggest influence on
the behaviors of the system in both the models.
In the original model these terms increase and
decrease more rapidly than in the modified model.</throwit><throwit>The chaos in the original model is hyperchaos but that in the modified
model
is not hyperchaos.
The complexity and the large topological
dimensionality for chaos in the original model
seem to be due to sharp behaviors of these functions.
However, to clarify the influence of the choice of
these functions, it is necessary to perform further investigation.
This is left to a future study.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 108
<para xml:id="p107">
    <p><text font="bold">We considered the threshold
over which the antibodies can recognize other antibodies.
We can also consider a threshold over which
the antigen can be recognized by other antibodies.
This is another situation to be investigated.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 109
<para xml:id="p108">
    <p><text font="bold">In this study, we investigated
three cases of invasions by antigens.
In these cases, we have interest in
the generic behaviors of the system
when the several parameters are changed, e.g.,
the initial values of antigens or the input
rate of the antigen <throwit>, etc.
We found that in some cases the system
changes in a positive way,
that is, in the resultant state the relaxation time becomes
shorter if there are plural units which interact with antibodies.
There exists a kind of memory in the system.
From the perspective of the real immune network,
the existence of memory states and the response to
the invasion by antigens in a system with
large number of degrees of freedom are very
interesting problems. These will be studied in the future.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 110

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">THE HIGGS SECTOR OF THE MSSM</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">IN THE DECOUPLING LIMIT</text></p>
    <p>ANTONIO DOBADO <throwit /></p>
    <p><text font="italic">Departamento de Física Teórica</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">Universidad Complutense de Madrid</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">28040– Madrid,  Spain</text></p>
    <p>MARIA J. HERRERO <throwit /></p>

Para index in docroot: 7
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Preasymptotic effects in beauty decays</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para align="center" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[0.3cm]
<inline-block class="ltx_parbox" vattach="middle" width="369.9pt">
        <p>Large preasymptotic effects in beauty decays have been found
using heavy-quark and SU(3) symmetry, as well as experimental
data on charmed hyperons.
Contrary to rather uniform beauty-meson lifetimes, a much larger
spread of beauty-baryon lifetimes is predicted. However,
it is highly unlikely that, theoretically, the
<throwit> ratio, which
at present deviates more than </throwit><throwit> from the experimental result,
can be lowered below 0.9.</throwit></p>
      </inline-block></p>
  </para>

element in Ker(</throwit><throwit>)? For the torus it is easily seen that
</throwit><throwit> suffices. We prove here that </throwit><throwit> is a group of order 32 and that an
upper bound for the order of </throwit><throwit> is given by </throwit><throwit>. The previously known
upper bound was greater than </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

</throwit><throwit> and separating curves are mapped to a 3–cycle in the third symmetric group,

nongeometric kernel, where </throwit><throwit> is the intersection of all index three subgroups of
</throwit><throwit>. We have been unable to find reasonable bounds on the size of this
quotient.</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002220.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:
<text fontsize="90%">We discuss three-body supersymmetric top decays,
in schemes both with and without <throwit>-parity conservation,
assuming that sfermion masses are larger than </throwit><throwit>.
We find that MSSM top decays into chargino/neutralino
pairs have a strong kinematic suppression in the region of
the supersymmetric parameter space consistent with the LEP limits,
with a decay width </throwit><throwit> GeV. MSSM top decays into
neutralino pairs have less kinematical suppression, but require a
flavour-changing vertex, and are likely to have a smaller rate.
On the other hand, </throwit><throwit>-violating decays
to single charginos, neutralinos and conventional fermions can be larger
for values of the </throwit><throwit>-violating couplings still permitted by other
upper limits. The cascade decays of the charginos and neutralinos
may lead to spectacular signals with explicit lepton-number violation, such
as like-sign lepton events.
</throwit></text></text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">HP:</text> A wave equation is said to satisfy the <text font="italic">Huygens
principle</text> (HP) iff the field at a point <throwit> depends only on the data at
the intersection of the past light cone through </throwit><throwit> with the Cauchy
hypersurface [4–6], in the sense that any two sets of data which coincide
there must give the same field at </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

iff each set of Cauchy data with compact support produces no tails [15].</p>

depending on the wave equation (and at least one of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> is
not identically zero), while the wave forms </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are arbitrary

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00753.xml
Para index in docroot: 8
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
<text font="italic">With the ultimate goal of iteratively solving piecewise smooth (PS) systems, we
consider the solution of piecewise linear (PL) equations.
As shown in <throwit> PL models can be derived in the fashion of
automatic or algorithmic differentiation as local approximations of PS functions with a
second order error in the distance to a given reference point. The
resulting PL functions are obtained quite naturally in what we call the
abs-normal form, a variant of the state representation proposed by
Bokhoven in his dissertation </throwit><throwit>. Apart from the tradition
of PL modelling by electrical engineers, which dates back to the
Master thesis of Thomas Stern </throwit><throwit> in 1956, we take into
account more recent results on linear complementarity problems and semi-smooth equations
originating in the optimization community </throwit><throwit>. We analyze simultaneously the original PL problem (OPL)
in abs-normal form and a corresponding complementary system (CPL), which is closely related to
the absolute value equation (AVE) studied by Mangasarian et al </throwit><throwit> and
a corresponding linear complementarity problem (LCP). We show that the CPL, like KKT conditions and other
simply switched systems, cannot be open without being injective. Hence some of the intriguing PL structure described by Scholtes
in
</throwit><throwit> is lost in the transformation from OPL to CPL. To both
problems one may apply Newton variants with appropriate generalized
Jacobians directly computable from the abs-normal representation.
Alternatively, the CPL can be solved by Bokhoven’s modulus method and
related fixed point iterations. We compile the properties of the
various schemes and highlight the connection to the properties of the
Schur complement matrix, in particular its signed real spectral radius as
analyzed by Rump in </throwit><throwit>. Numerical experiments and suitable
combinations of the fixed point solvers and stabilized generalized Newton
variants remain to be realized. </throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math-ph0002041.xml

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=astro-ph0002007.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">The Cosmological Quark-Hadron Transition and</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Massive Compact Halo Objects</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">One of the abiding mysteries in the so-called standard cosmological
model is the nature of the dark matter. It is universally accepted that
there is an abundance of matter in the universe which is non-luminous, due to
their very weak interaction, if at all, with the other forms of matter,
excepting of course the gravitational attraction. Speculations as to the
nature of dark matter are numerous, often bordering on exotics, and searches
for such exotic matter is a very active field of astroparticle physics at the
dawn of the new century. Nevertheless, in recent years, there has been
experimental evidence <throwit> for at least one form of dark
matter - the massive compact halo objects detected through gravitational
microlensing effects proposed by Paczynski some years ago </throwit><throwit>. To
date, no clear consensus as to what these objects, referred to in the
literature as well as in the following by the acronym MACHO, are made of;
for a brief discussion of some of the suggestions, see below. In this work,
we show that they find a natural explanation as leftover relics from the
</throwit></text><text font="italic">putative</text><text font="bold"> first order cosmic quark - hadron phase transition that is
predicted by the standard model of particle interactions to have occurred
during the microsecond epoch of the early universe.</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0002042.xml

Para index in docroot: 20
<para xml:id="p18">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%" framed="underline">CONCLUSIONS</text><throwit>The main findings of the present paper are contained in Lemmas A, B, C, and D.
The nonorthogonality of the LSL states (for </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>) implies
that, even in the absence of bound states, the Moller operator
connecting </throwit><throwit> to </throwit><throwit> may be nonunitary and </throwit><throwit> may loose its interpretation as the unit matrix. Several
standard results of scattering perturbation theory [1-7] based on the
LSL states may require re-examination. Before ending, it may
be added that the present work is not concerned with another
peculiarity of the LS equation - the Faddeev ambiguity [8] - arising
from the noncompactness of the kernel. We also believe that the
time-dependence of the LSL states will be much richer than the
standard Schrodinger kets </throwit><throwit> but this
aspect will be dealt-with in a future communication.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">The large-scale distribution of warm ionized gas around
nearby radio galaxies with jet-cloud interactions</text><text font="bold">
C.N. Tadhunter</text><throwit /><text font="bold">, M. Villar-Martin</text><throwit /><text font="bold">, R. Morganti</text><throwit /><text font="bold">,
J. Bland-Hawthorn</text><throwit /><text font="bold"> &amp;
D. Axon</text><throwit /><text font="bold">
</text><throwit /><text font="bold" fontsize="90%"> Department of Physics, University of Sheffield, Sheffield S3 7RH, UK <throwit /><throwit> Institude d’Astrophysique, 98bis Boulevard Arago, F-75014, Paris, France </throwit><throwit /><throwit> NFRA, PO Box 2, 7990 AA Dwingeloo, The Netherlands </throwit><throwit /><throwit> Anglo-Australian Observatory, PO Box, 296 Epping, NSW 2121, Australia </throwit><throwit /><throwit> Division of Physics and Astronomy, Department of Physical Sciences,
University of Hertfordshire, College Lane, Hatfield, Herts AL10 9AB, UK </throwit></text><text font="bold" /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract Deep, narrow-band H</text><throwit /><text font="bold"> observations taken with
the TAURUS Tunable Filter (TTF) on the 4.2m WHT telescope
are presented for two nearby radio
galaxies with strong jet-cloud interactions.
Although the brightest emission
line components are closely aligned with the radio jets — providing
nearby examples of the “alignment effect” most commonly observed
in high redshift (</text><throwit /><text font="bold">) radio galaxies — lower surface brightness
emission line structures are detected at large distances (10’s of kpc) from
the radio jet axis. These latter
structures cannot be reconciled with anisotropic illumination
of the ISM by obscured quasar-like sources, since parts of the
structures lie outside any plausible quasar ionization cones. Rather, the
distribution of the emission lines around the fringes of the extended
radio lobes suggests that the gas is ionized either by direct interaction with
the radio components, or by the diffuse photoionizing radiation fields
produced in the shocks generated in such interactions. These observations
serve to emphasise that the ionizing effects of the radio components can
extend far from the radio jet axes, and that deep emission line imaging
observations are required to reveal the true distribution of warm gas
in the host galaxies. We expect future deep imaging observations to
reveal similar structures perpendicular to the radio axes in the high-z radio galaxies.</text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">The electron-electron interaction</text> (EEI) can strongly affect the
magnetoconductivity even for low electron densities, where the 2DES is
nondegenerate. Of particular interest for both theory and experiment
are many-electron effects for densities and temperatures where
<throwit>. The 2DES is then </throwit><text font="italic">strongly correlated</text> and forms a nondegenerate electron liquid or,

Para index in docroot: 12
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Strategy A:</text> This is known as <text font="italic">hash-rehash Strategy</text>
 <throwit>. In this strategy,
each page of the
main memory is allowed to reside in two locations
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> in the cache that are determined as follows: </throwit><throwit>
is the string of the first </throwit><throwit> bits of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> is the string of the
next </throwit><throwit> bits of </throwit><throwit>. When a page </throwit><throwit> from the main memory is brought
to the cache, it is first put in </throwit><throwit> provided </throwit><throwit> is empty;
if </throwit><throwit> is occupied we place </throwit><throwit>
in </throwit><throwit>. (If there is some page </throwit><throwit> residing at </throwit><throwit>,
then it is replaced by </throwit><throwit> and is sent back to the main memory.)</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Strategy B:</text> This is known as
<text font="italic">two-way skewed-associative
strategy</text> <throwit>.
In this case, we
divide the cache into
two banks </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, each with capacity </throwit><throwit>. The pages of
the two banks are denoted by </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> respectively where </throwit><throwit>. With each page </throwit><throwit> are associated two pages
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, one from each bank. When a page </throwit><throwit> is brought
to the cache, we first try to store </throwit><throwit> in the
first bank at location </throwit><throwit>, and if that fails, we store it in
the second bank at location </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Strategy C:</text> This is known as
<text font="italic">two-way set-associative strategy</text>
 <throwit>. Here the cache is again divided into
two banks.
The only difference is that we associate pages </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
with page </throwit><throwit>. That is, if
</throwit><throwit> is already taken, we try to store the page in the second
bank but at location </throwit><throwit> (and not </throwit><throwit> as in Strategy </throwit><throwit>).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002181.xml
/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.01225.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">The dispersal of cells from an initially constrained location
is a crucial aspect of many physiological phenomena ranging from
morphogenesis to tumour spreading. In such processes, the way
cell-cell interactions impact the motion of single cells, and in
turn the collective dynamics, remains unclear. Here, the spreading
of micro-patterned colonies of non-cohesive cells is fully
characterized from the complete set of individual trajectories. It
shows that contact interactions, chemically mediated interactions
and cell proliferation each dominates the dispersal process on
different time scales. From data analysis and simulation of an
active particle model, we demonstrate that contact interactions act
to speed up the early population spreading by promoting individual
cells to a state of higher persistence,
which constitutes an as-yet unreported contact <text font="italic">enhancement</text> of
locomotion. Our findings suggest that the current modeling paradigm
of memoryless interacting active particles may need to be extended
to account for the possibility of internal states and
history-dependent behaviour of motile cells.<throwit /><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002051.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">High Orders of Perturbation Theory:</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Are Renormalons Significant? </text></p>
    <p>I. M. Suslov</p>
    <p>P.L.Kapitza Institute for Physical Problems,</p>
    <p>117337 Moscow, Russia</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="384.1pt">
      <para xml:id="p1.p1">
        <p>According to Lipatov, high
orders of perturbation theory are determined by the saddle-point
configurations (instantons) of the corresponding functional
integrals. According to ’t Hooft, some
individual large diagrams, renormalons, are also
significant and they
are not contained in the Lipatov contribution.
The history of the conception of renormalons is
presented, and the arguments in favor of and against their
significance are discussed. The analytic properties of the Borel
transforms of functional integrals, Green functions, vertex
parts, and scaling functions are investigated in the case
of <throwit>
theory. Their analyticity in a complex plane with a cut from the
first instanton singularity to infinity (the
Le Guillou – Zinn-Justin hypothesis) is proved. It rules out
the existence of the renormalon singularities pointed out by
’t Hooft and demonstrates the nonconstructiveness of the
conception of renormalons as a whole. The results can be
interpreted as an indication of the internal consistency
of </throwit><throwit>
theory.</throwit></p>
      </para>
    </inline-para>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1. INTRODUCTION</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para align="center" xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">2. PROS AND CONS</text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00789.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Algebraic structures spanned by differential-like operators</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">on toy Fock spaces.</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Jerzy Szulga</p>
    <p>Department of Mathematics and Statistics,</p>
    <p>Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, USA</p>
    <p>Email: szulgje@auburn.edu</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract. </text> We study multiplicative systems of linear mappings acting on the toy Fock space, a.k.a. Rademacher chaos or Walsh-Fourier series, related to the creation, annihilation, and conservation operators in quantum probability. Like differential operators they entail analogs of the Leibnitz Formula and the Chain Rule, derived with the help of Riesz products (or discrete coherent vectors). Two symmetries among these operators entail groups and algebras of varying signatures and mixed commutativity, generalizing Pauli spin matrices and quaternions. In particular, anticommutative Rademacher systems are constructed.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> Toy Fock space, Riesz products, creation-annihilation-conservation, discrete derivatives, rigged Hilbert spaces</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">AMS 2010 MSC:</text> Primary 47L30; Secondary 46L53, 60H07, 42C10</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><throwit /><text font="bold" fontsize="144%"> supergravity and various aspects of
light-cone formalism in AdS space-time</text>
<throwit /></p>
    <p>R.R. Metsaev</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic">Department of Theoretical Physics, P.N. Lebedev Physical
Institute, Leninsky prospect 53, 117924, Moscow, Russia</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Light-cone gauge formulation of <throwit> supergravity in
</throwit><throwit> background.</throwit></text>
In recent years, due to the conjectured duality
between the string theory and <throwit>, </throwit><throwit> SYM theory
</throwit><throwit> (for review see </throwit><throwit>)
there has been rapidly growing interest in
strings propagating in AdS space.
Inspired by this conjecture the Green-Schwarz formulation of strings
propagating in </throwit><throwit> was suggested in </throwit><throwit> (for further
developments see </throwit><throwit>-</throwit><throwit>). Despite considerable efforts
these strings have not yet been quantized</throwit><throwit>.
As is well
known, quantization of GS superstrings propagating in flat space is
straightforward only in the light-cone gauge.
Because the string theories are approximated at low energies
by supergravity theories it seems reasonable that we should first study a
light-cone gauge formulation of supergravity theories in AdS spacetime.
Light-cone description of type </throwit><throwit> supergravity in </throwit><throwit>
background can teach us a lot. For example it can be used to construct
charges of global symmetries so that certain of them have the same
form for both supergravity and superstring.
Keeping in mind extremely important applications to string theory let us
now restrict our discussion to </throwit><throwit> supergravity in </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para xml:id="p14">
    <p><text font="bold">Self-dual fields in AdS space-time.</text>
In this section we would like to discuss self-dual fields in AdS
space. In our knowledge they have not been discussed previously in
literature.
As in Minkowski space the strengths of AdS (anti) self-dual fields satisfy
self-duality constraint</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Because this constraint it is impossible to construct an appropriate
Lorentz covariant action without introducing auxiliary
fields<throwit>.
The action for self-dual fields
can be most easily understood within the framework of light-cone gauge
formulation. For definiteness let us restrict ourselves to the case of
six dimensional AdS space and to second rank antisymmetric tensor field.
First of all we would like to discuss formulation of self-dual fields in
Minkowski space which is most convenient for generalization to AdS space.
In light-cone gauge physical degrees of freedom of self-dual field in
Minkowski space are described by field </throwit><throwit> which satisfies the
self-duality constraint </throwit><throwit>. The
field </throwit><throwit>, which is the </throwit><throwit> tensor, can be decomposed into
</throwit><throwit> tensors </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>.
The self-duality constraint
tells us then that </throwit><throwit> is expressible in terms of </throwit><throwit>:
</throwit><throwit>.
Thus, if one wishes, in Minkowski
space the self-dual field can be described by unconstrained field
</throwit><throwit> (or </throwit><throwit>) </throwit><throwit /><throwit>.
Note that this form of description breaks manifest </throwit><throwit>
(which is </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>) invariance to manifest </throwit><throwit> (which is
</throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>) invariance. On the other hand light-cone gauge
formalism in </throwit><throwit> space respects only manifest </throwit><throwit> (see
</throwit><throwit>). Therefore the description based on unconstrained
field </throwit><throwit> is most appropriate to be generalized to AdS space.
Thus our aim is to find realization of AdS algebra generators
on the space of unconstrained field </throwit><throwit>. The realization of AdS
algebra on the space of physical fields found in (</throwit><throwit>, formulas
(4.1)-(4.8) and (4.17)-(4.19)) is formulated in terms of spin operator
</throwit><throwit> and operators </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. The form of spin operator is fixed by

    <p><text font="bold">2.1 Proposition. </text> <text font="italic">Let <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> be two primitive isotropic vectors, or two short roots, or two long roots. Then </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are equivalent under </throwit><throwit> if and only if their images in </throwit><throwit> coincide. The number of </throwit><throwit>-orbits of lines </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> is a primitive isotropic vector, a short root or a long root, is 40, 36 or 45, respectively. </throwit></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 15
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3.2 Definition. </text> <text font="italic">A cross in <throwit> is a set of 5 pairwise orthogonal pairs </throwit><throwit>, one pair consisting of long vectors and the others consisting of short vectors. The associated cross in </throwit><throwit> is the union of the mirrors of the </throwit><throwit>; it follows that a cross in </throwit><throwit> is a set of 5 pairwise orthogonal mirrors, one long and 4 short. The associated cross in </throwit><throwit> is the preimage of the cross in </throwit><throwit>. A point of </throwit><throwit> lies in this cross just if it is orthogonal to a root whose projection to </throwit><throwit> is one of the </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3.3 Lemma. </text> <text font="italic">There are 135 crosses, three containing each of the 45 long mirrors of <throwit>, and all 135 crosses are all equivalent under </throwit><throwit>. More precisely, if </throwit><throwit> is a long mirror in </throwit><throwit> then the 12 short mirrors orthogonal to </throwit><throwit> decompose in a unique way into three sets of 4 mirrors which are pairwise orthogonal, and the stabilizer of </throwit><throwit> in </throwit><throwit> permutes these sets transitively. </throwit></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">

  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction.</text>   The view of superbranes as theories of partial spontaneous breaking of global
SUSY (PBGS) received a considerable attention (see, e.g.,
<throwit> - </throwit><throwit>). The salient feature of this approach is
that it deals with the Goldstone superfields
living on the worldvolume superspace of
unbroken SUSY and accommodating the superbrane
physical degrees of freedom.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Superbranes from PBGS.</text> The PBGS approach is
the generalization
of the above nonlinear realization view of branes to the superbranes.
Though originally <throwit> the phenomenon of partial
breaking of global SUSY
(</throwit><throwit> down to </throwit><throwit> in </throwit><throwit>) was studied without any reference
to superbranes, the
subsequent study </throwit><throwit>-</throwit><throwit> revealed
the profound relationship between both
concepts. It was shown in </throwit><throwit> that </throwit><throwit> superstring
in the static gauge
can be understood as the theory of partial breaking
of </throwit><throwit> SUSY to its
</throwit><throwit> subgroup. The very existence of self-consistent
GS type actions for
superbranes, with the appropriate fermionic </throwit><throwit>-symmetry,
was inferred in the
pioneering paper </throwit><throwit> from the study of the partial breaking
</throwit><throwit>.
The same PBGS pattern was treated in
</throwit><throwit> from the </throwit><throwit> perspective as the partial breaking
of </throwit><throwit> SUSY with two central
charges down to </throwit><throwit> one, with the systematic use of the nonlinear
realizations and inverse Higgs effect techniques. It was shown that
the self-consistent theory can be constructed in terms of the (covariantly)
chiral and antichiral bosonic </throwit><throwit> superfields which are the Goldstone ones
corresponding to the central charges (that is, to the translation
operators in fifth and sixth
directions from the </throwit><throwit> viewpoint). The fermionic Goldstone
superfields associated
with the spontaneously broken supertranslation generators
are covariantly expressed in terms of these
basic Goldstone superfields by the covariant constraints of the type (</throwit><throwit>).
The relevant Goldstone superfields action, a nonlinear generalization of the
standard free action of </throwit><throwit> chiral superfields, was constructed in
</throwit><throwit>. In components,
after eliminating the auxiliary fields, it yields just
the static gauge form of the GS action
for the </throwit><throwit> 3-brane in a flat background.
An interesting new phenomenon was discovered
in </throwit><throwit>. It turned out that the same SUSY admits several
different PBGS options depending
on into which multiplet of unbroken SUSY one embeds the Goldstone fermion.
In the </throwit><throwit> case, instead of placing
this field into
the chiral </throwit><throwit> multiplet, one can place it into
the abelian vector </throwit><throwit> multiplet as a “photino”,
by imposing the appropriate covariant
constraints on the Goldstone fermionic superfield which
generalize the Bianchi identities for
the flat </throwit><throwit> Maxwell superfield strength.
The relevant invariant action, on the one hand,
is </throwit><throwit> extension of the Born-Infeld (BI) action with the hidden,
nonlinearly realized half of supersymmetry,
and, on the other, is (in components) a gauge-fixed form of
the GS action of the “space-time filling”
D3-brane. One more option is to embed the Goldstone fermion into
the </throwit><throwit> tensor (or linear)
multiplet </throwit><throwit>. The emerging brane
is the super “L3-brane” in </throwit><throwit>
(in terminology of </throwit><throwit>), it is related to the
</throwit><throwit> 3-brane via
the familiar duality between </throwit><throwit> tensor and chiral superfields.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p15">
    <p><text font="bold">3. Hypermultiplet as a Goldstone superfield.</text>
To describe the <throwit> breaking of Poincaré SUSY with 16 supercharges, it
is natural to start from the maximally symmetric situation where the broken
and unbroken SUSY “live” as simple ones. This amounts to
considering the PBGS option </throwit><throwit>
(we could equally choose </throwit><throwit>). From the </throwit><throwit> perspective,
</throwit><throwit> is a central extension of </throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit>
are, respectively, the </throwit><throwit> indices and the
</throwit><throwit> doublet indices. The basic anticommutation relations read</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>One also must add generators of the <throwit> Lorentz
group </throwit><throwit>, with </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
generating the </throwit><throwit> Lorentz
group </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>-symmetry </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 20
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p19">
    <p><text font="bold">4. N=1, D=4 supermembrane.</text> This case corresponds
to the partial breaking
of <throwit> SUSY to </throwit><throwit> one. The </throwit><throwit> superalgebra
in the </throwit><throwit> notation
reads</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 29
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p28">
    <p><text font="bold">5. Concluding remarks.</text> The geometric PBGS approach
can be thought of as a useful and viable alternative to the
standard GS description of superbranes. Its main merit is
that it gives <text font="italic">manifestly</text> worldsurface supersymmetric
off-shell superfield actions. Leaving aside
such important conceptual questions as whether it can be helpful
for quantization, etc, we list here a few more modest problems
solving which could extend its range of applicability.</p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00219.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">A partial inverse problem for the Sturm-Liouville operator on a star-shaped graph
</text></p>
    <p>[0.2cm]
<text font="bold">Natalia P. Bondarenko</text></p>
    <p>[0.2cm]</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> The Sturm-Liouville operator on a star-shaped graph is considered. We assume that the potential is known
a priori on all the edges except one, and study the partial inverse problem, which consists in recovering the potential
on the remaining edge from the part of the spectrum. A constructive method is developed for the solution
of this problem, based on the Riesz-basicity of some sequence of vector functions. The local solvability of the inverse problem
and the stability of its solution are proved.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> partial inverse problem, differential operator on graph, Sturm-Liouville operator, Weyl function, Riesz basis,
local solvability, stability.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">AMS Mathematics Subject Classification (2010):</text> 34A55 34B09 34B24 34B45 47E05</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2

Para index in docroot: 18
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Harry Lipkin (Weizmann Institute):</text>  I would like to point out
that the Donnachie and Landshoff fit to the total cross section,
which was accepted by the Particle Data Group in 1966, was thrown out
by them in 1998 with a different value of the pomeron intercept. I
have fit the same data some time ago with a still different value.
The point is that there are still not enough data on total cross
sections to tell us whether there is a universal pomeron with a
universal intercept that is coupled to meson-baryon and baryon-baryon
total cross sections. What are needed are new data at higher
energies. The recent data on hyperon-nucleus cross sections from
SELEX actually support my model, but I don’t believe that either. I
think that what is happening is that there is a non-leading
contribution which confuses the issue and is not understood. To
resolve this, we just have to get more data at higher energies.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction.</text>
The theory of quasi-Hopf algebras was developed by V.G.Drinfel’d for the
description of quantizations of Lie groups and algebras or so-called quantum
groups.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Semirings and character tables.</text>
A <text font="italic">semiring</text> is a set <throwit> with a collection of non-negative integers
</throwit><throwit> (</throwit><text font="italic">structural constants</text>) which
satisfy the (<text font="italic">associativity</text>) condititon</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>An element <throwit> of the semiring </throwit><throwit> is an </throwit><text font="italic">identity</text> if <throwit> for all </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<text font="italic">Let <throwit> be a degree map for the rigid seniring </throwit><throwit>.
Then </throwit><throwit> satisfies to the conditions</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para xml:id="p18">
    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 1</text>(Uniqueness of degree map)<text font="bold">.</text>
<text font="italic">Any two degree maps for commutative rigid semiring <throwit> coincides.
</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p24">
    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 2.</text>
<text font="italic">The map <throwit> given by the collection
</throwit><throwit> is a homomorphism of (semi)rings
(the collection satisfies to the condition </throwit></text>(1)<text font="italic">) if and only if
there is a map <throwit> such that </throwit><throwit>
for any </throwit><throwit>.
</throwit></text></p>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p33">
    <p><text font="bold">3. Semisimple monoidal categories.</text>
The <text font="italic">monoidal category</text> [6] is a category
<text font="caligraphic">G</text>  with a bifunctor</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which called <text font="italic">tensor (or monoidal) product</text>. This functor must be equiped
with a functorial collection of isomorphisms (so-called <text font="italic">associativity
constraint</text>)</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which satisfies to the following <text font="italic">pentagon axiom</text>:</p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 45
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p41">
    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 3.</text>
<text font="italic">Semisimple monoidal categories are twisted forms of each other iff
their semirings of simple objects are isomorphic.
Isomorphism classes of quasimonoidal functors
<throwit> between semisimple monoidal categories
are in one-to-one correspondence with the homomorphisms
</throwit><throwit> of the semirings of simple objects.
In particular, monoidal functors </throwit><throwit>
between semisimple monoidal categories are twisted forms
of each other iff they induce the same map
</throwit><throwit> of the Grothendieck rings.
</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

is an algebra <throwit> together
with a homomoprhisms of algebras</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>and an invertible element <throwit> (</throwit><text font="italic">associator</text>)
for which</p>

    </throwit><throwit>

<text font="italic">The homomorphisms of quasi-bialgebras <throwit>
are twisted forms if and only if the monoidal functors </throwit><throwit>
are twisted forms.
In particular, the homomorphisms of semisimple quasi-bialgebras
</throwit><throwit> induce the same homomorphism
</throwit><throwit>
of Grothendieck rings if and only if one is isomorphic to the twisted form
of the other.
</throwit></text></p>
