<text font="italic">Finite dimensional semisimple quasi-Hopf algebras <throwit>
are quasi-isomorphic if and only if their semirings of simple objects
</throwit><throwit> are isomorphic.
</throwit></text></p>

was proved in [11] where it was assumed that the isomorphism of
(enveloping algebras of) semiring preserves the class
of regular representation.</p>

if and only if their group algebras are isomorphic as quasi-Hopf algebras,
e.g. there is an isomorphism of algebras </throwit><throwit>
and an invertible element </throwit><throwit> such that
</throwit><throwit> for any </throwit><throwit>.

Para index in docroot: 80
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p76">
    <p><text font="bold">5. Galois algebras.</text>
Here we give brief description of bi-Galois associative algebras. As was explained above they correspond to the isomorphisms of character tables with trivial associators.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 90

    <p><text font="bold">Example 3.</text>
Let <throwit> be a finite abelian group. Denote by </throwit><throwit> the dual group
</throwit><throwit>. The 2-cocycle </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>is non-degenerated.</p>
  </para>

elements. The standard symplectic form </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit> defines a
non-degenerated 2-cocycle</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> is bilinear form on </throwit><throwit> such that
</throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit>Let </throwit><throwit> be the group of automorphisms of the form </throwit><throwit>.
For </throwit><throwit> the cohomology group
</throwit><throwit>
is one dimensional </throwit><throwit>-vector space generated by the class
</throwit><throwit>.
Thus the affine symplectic group </throwit><throwit> and the (unique) non-split
extension of </throwit><throwit> by </throwit><throwit> have the same
character tables.
</throwit><throwit>For </throwit><throwit> the cohomology group </throwit><throwit>
is trivial and the pair </throwit><throwit> defines the automorphism
of character table of
</throwit><throwit> which doesn’t correspond to any group automorphism.
This isomorphism intertwings the characters </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
and the classes </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 110
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p106">
    <p><text font="bold">6. Class-preserving automorphisms and permutation
representations with the same character.</text>
We will call an automorphism <throwit> of the finite group </throwit><throwit>
by </throwit><text font="italic">class-preserving</text> if <throwit> preserves all conjugacy
classes of </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit> for all </throwit><throwit> (see [2, 9, 14]).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 112
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p108">
    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 5.</text>
<text font="italic">For any class-preserving automorphism <throwit> of the finite group </throwit><throwit>
there is an invertible element </throwit><throwit> such that
</throwit><throwit> for any </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> is </throwit><throwit>-invariant element of
</throwit><throwit>.
</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 116
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p112">
    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 6.</text>
<text font="italic">For any two permutation representations <throwit>
of the finite group </throwit><throwit> there is an invertible element </throwit><throwit>
such that </throwit><throwit> for any </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> is </throwit><throwit>-invariant element of
</throwit><throwit>.
</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 118
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p114">
    <p><text font="bold">7. Concluding remarks.</text>
The cohomological nature of the sets of possible twistings
was actively explored
in the theory of quantum groups. Nonabelianity of those cohomology
is probabily
a major difficulty of the theory. In quantum group theory this difficulty
was overcome by methods of tangent cohomology which are unapplicable
for finite
groups. In this case non-abelian cohomology sets of twistings
can be abelianized
by means of algebraic K-theory. Namely, the maps from
the sets of twistings to
some Hochschild cohomology of representation ring can be costructed
[5]. The detailed description of those maps would be the subject
of subsequent paper.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=gr-qc0002001.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>We perform a numerical analysis of the gravitational field of
a global monopole coupled nonminimally to gravity, and find
that, for some given nonminimal couplings (in contrast with the minimal
coupling case), there is an attractive
region where bound orbits exist.
We exhibit the behavior of the frequency shifts that would be
associated with “rotation curves” of stars in circular orbits
in the spacetimes of such global monopoles.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0001098.xml

    <p><text font="bold">1.1 The concept of circular system</text> was introduced by D. Voiculescu in
<throwit>, and plays an important role in his theory of free probability.

    </throwit><p>is <text font="italic">free</text> in <throwit>, and if each of the selfadjoint elements listed in

    <p><text font="bold">1.2 q-circular systems.</text> In work related to <throwit>-deformations of the

a remarkable deformation of the full Fock space, called the </throwit><throwit>-Fock space;
here </throwit><throwit> is a parameter in </throwit><throwit>, and the actual full Fock space is
obtained for </throwit><throwit> (see review in Section 2.2 below). In connection to
this, Bożejko and Speicher studied the
distribution – called by them </throwit><text font="italic">q-Gaussian</text> – of <throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>
is an appropriately normalized creation operator on the </throwit><throwit>-Fock space.
They discovered that the </throwit><throwit>-Gaussian distribution is the probability measure
associated to an important family of orthogonal polynomials, the
</throwit><throwit>-continuous Hermite polynomials. If </throwit><throwit>, then the </throwit><throwit>-Gaussian is the
semicircular distribution appearing in (1.2), while the usual Gaussian is
obtained in the limit </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">GROTHENDIECK–VERDIER DUALITY PATTERNS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">IN QUANTUM ALGEBRA</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Yuri I. Manin</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> After a brief survey of the basic definitions of the Grothendieck–Verdier
categories and dualities, I consider in this context introduced earlier dualities in the categories
of quadratic algebras and operads, largely motivated by the theory of quantum groups.
Finally, I argue that Dubrovin’s “almost duality” in the theory of Frobenius
manifolds and quantum cohomology also must fit a (possibly extended)
version of Grothendieck–Verdier duality.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords: </text> Duality, quadratic algebras, quadratic operads, <throwit>–manifolds.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Reflection Amplitudes in Non-Simply Laced Toda Theories</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">and Thermodynamic Bethe Ansatz</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>We study the ultraviolet asymptotics in non-simply laced affine Toda
theories considering them as perturbed non-affine Toda theories,
which possess the extended conformal symmetry.
We calculate the reflection amplitudes, in non-affine Toda theories
and use them to derive the quantization condition for the
vacuum wave function, describing zero-mode dynamics.
The solution of this quantization conditions for the ground state energy
determines the UV asymptotics of the effective central charge.
These asymptotics are in a good agreement with Thermodynamic
Bethe Ansatz(TBA) results.
To make the comparison with TBA possible, we give the exact relations
between parameters of the action and masses of particles
as well as the bulk free energies for non-simply laced affine Toda
theories.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001193.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>A test for the Gaussian and exponential Ansätze for the nonperturbative
parts of the coefficient functions, <throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>, which parametrize the
gauge-invariant bilocal correlator of the field strength tensors
in the stochastic vacuum model of QCD, is proposed.
It is based on the evaluation of the heavy-quark condensate within this
model by making use of the
world-line formalism and equating
the obtained result to the one following directly from the
QCD Lagrangian. This yields a certain relation between
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>,
which is further compared with an analogous relation between
these quantities known from the existing lattice data. Such a
comparison leads to the conclusion that at the distances
smaller than the correlation length of the vacuum,
Gaussian Ansatz is more suitable than the exponential one.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0001035.xml

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> In the Painlevé analysis of nonintegrable partial
differential equations one obtains differential constraints describing the
movable singularity manifold. We show that, for a class of <throwit>-dimensional
wave equations,
these constraints have a general structure which is related to the
</throwit><throwit>-dimensional Bateman equation. In
particular,
we
derive the expressions of the singularity manifold constraint
for the </throwit><throwit>-dimensional sine-Gordon -, Liouville -,
Mikhailov -, and double sine-Gordon equation, as well as two
2-dimensional polynomial field theory equations, and prove that their
singularity manifold
conditions are satisfied by the
</throwit><throwit>-dimensional Bateman equation.
Finally we give some examples.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> The electronic structure of atomic clusters has been intensively studied
experimentally and theoretically in the last two decades (see, for example, reviews
in Refs. <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>). One general feature of the experimental
mass-abundance spectra of </throwit><throwit>-atom clasters is the existence of magic numbers:
Clusters with these numbers of atoms are produced more abundantly. As </throwit><throwit> enlarges,
the amplitude of these variations lessens, then in still larger clusters increases
once again, and so on, i.e., oscillations with beats occur.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text> We furthermore use the expression derived in our future extended publication
for the correction to the binding energy of electrons (the atomic units are used):</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Here <throwit> is the correction to the electronic density, which because
of other effects goes beyond the initial model approach (for example, TF or ETF model),
</throwit><throwit> is the chemical potential in the initial model, the correction </throwit><throwit>
is assumed to be small and is calculated using the initial self-consistent potential.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold">3.</text> The integral limits and points <throwit> of stationary phase make
the main contribution in the integral over </throwit><throwit> in Eq.(5). These points are
determined from the relation:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>A function <throwit> decreases monotonically and for all potentials
</throwit><throwit> that are finite at the origin the slope of the corresponding curve at
</throwit><throwit> is the same </throwit><throwit>,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The value of the derivative at <throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>depends strongly on the form of the potential. For an oscillator
<throwit>, for a square well </throwit><throwit>, and for the Woods-Saxon potential
the value of </throwit><throwit> varies with increasing </throwit><throwit>, vanishing in the limit of a very
large number of atoms.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">4.</text> The proposed simple method makes it possible for any
spherical potential to determine the period and amplitude of oscillations associated with each
supershell and to estimate their relative role in beating occurence. The results
of such an analysis for a square well potential:</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>are displayed in Fig.1. Let’s note that even though we start with the expression</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">5.</text> For spherical potential we give the analytical
expression for the oscillating part of the binding energy of electrons as an explicit
sum of contributions from the leading periodic orbits (supershells).
We show that a number of the leading
orbits in the expansion depends strongly on the form of the potential
and is determined by the value of derivative (6b)(see Eq.(7)).
The more soft potentials will be dealt in detail in our
extended publication where among other things small clusters and finite temperatures
will be analyzed.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 9
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><throwit> </throwit><text font="bold">Why the mass-to-luminosity ratio and the color
index of disk galaxies do depend on <throwit> (or luminosity)?</throwit></text>
At least there are three alternatives: the star formation (SF) efficiency,
the gas infall efficiency and/or the internal face-on dust extinction
depend on the galaxy mass. We explore the last
alternative since self-consistent models of disk galaxy
evolution within the hierarchical formation scenario show that the
<throwit> ratio and </throwit><throwit> do not significantly depend on mass or
luminosity (Avila-Reese &amp; Firmani 2000, RevMexA&amp;A, v. 36, in press;
Avila-Reese et al., this volume).</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para xml:id="p5">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Stefan Förste<throwit>, Zygmunt Lalak</throwit><throwit>,

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>In this note we elaborate on various five dimensional contributions to the
effective 4D cosmological constant in brane systems. In
solutions with vanishing
5D cosmological constant we describe a non-local mechanism of
cancellation of vacuum energy between the brane and the
singularities. We comment on a hidden fine tuning which is implied by
this observation.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text>.
We discuss the bihamiltonian geometry of the Toda lattice
(periodic and open). Using some recent results on the separation
of variables for bihamiltonian manifold, we show that these systems can be
explicitly integrated via the classical Hamilton–Jacobi method in
the so–called Darboux–Nijenhuis coordinates.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.01016.xml

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Computer Simulations of Friction, Lubrication and Wear</text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002022.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">1 Introduction<throwit /></text>The travelling salesman problem (TSP) is a simple example of a multivariable combinatorial
optmization problem and perhaps the most famous one. Given a certain set of
cities and the intercity distance metric, a travelling salesman must find the
shortest tour in which he visits all the cities and comes back to his starting
point. It is a non-deterministic polynomial complete (NP- complete) problem
[1-3].
In the standard formulation of TSP, we have <throwit> number of cities distributed
randomly on a continuum plane and we determine the average optimal
travel distance per city </throwit><throwit> in the Euclidean metric (with
</throwit><throwit>), or </throwit><throwit> in the Manhattan
metric (with </throwit><throwit>).
Since the average distance per city scales (for fixed area) with the number of
cities </throwit><throwit> as </throwit><throwit>, we find that the normalized travel distance per
city </throwit><throwit> or
</throwit><throwit> become the optimized constants and their values
depend on the method used to optimize the travel distance. Extending the
analytic estimates of the average nearest neighbour distances, in particular
within a strip and varying the width of the strip to extremize (single parameter
optimization approximation), one gets </throwit><throwit> [4] and
</throwit><throwit> [5]. Careful (scaling, etc.) analysis of the
numerical results obtained so far indicates that </throwit><throwit> [6].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">2 Computer Simulation and Results<throwit /></text>We generate the randomly diluted lattice configurations following the standard
Monte Carlo procedure for different system sizes. For each system size <throwit>, we
vary the lattice size </throwit><throwit> so that the lattice concentration </throwit><throwit> varies.
For each such lattice configuration, the optimum tour with open boundary
conditions, is obtained with the help of the </throwit><text font="italic">GNU tsp_ solve</text> [11]
developed using a branch and bound algorithm (see Fig. 1).
It claims to give exact results for <throwit> and near-optimal solutions for
</throwit><throwit>. It may be noted that the program works
essentially with the Euclidean distance. However there exists a geometric
relationship between the Euclidean distance and the Manhattan distance. We may
write </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>
is the magnitude of the Euclidean path vector between two neighbouring cities
and </throwit><throwit> is the sum of the components
of the Euclidean path projected along the Cartesian axes.
Naturally, </throwit><throwit>. If </throwit><throwit> corresponds to the shortest
Euclidean path, then </throwit><throwit> ,
for any other path denoted by the primed set. If the optimized Euclidean
path does not correspond to the optimized Manhattan path, then one will have
</throwit><throwit>,
where all the </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> satisfy the previous bounds.
Additionally, for random orientation of the Euclidean distance with respect to
the Cartesian axes, </throwit><throwit>. It seems,
with all these constraints on </throwit><throwit>’s and </throwit><throwit>’s, it would be
impossible to satisfy the above inequalities on
</throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit>. In fact, we checked for a set of </throwit><throwit>
random optimized Euclidean tours for small </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>), obtained using the algorithm, whether the
optimized Manhattan tours correspond to different sequence (of visiting the
cities), and did not find any. We believe that the optimized Euclidean tour
necessarily corresponds to the optimized Manhattan tour.
We then calculate </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> for each such optimized tour.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">3 Conclusions<throwit /></text>We note that the TSP
on randomly diluted lattice is certainly a trivial problem when <throwit> (lattice
limit) as it reduces to the one-dimensional TSP (the connections in the optimal
tour are between the nearest neighbours along the lattice).
Here </throwit><throwit>.
However, it is certainly NP- hard at the </throwit><throwit> (continuum) limit,
where </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> (extrapolated for large
system sizes </throwit><throwit>). We note that
</throwit><throwit> remains practically close to unity for all values of
</throwit><throwit>. Our numerical results also suggest that </throwit><throwit>
as </throwit><throwit>.
It is clear that the problem crosses from triviality (for </throwit><throwit>) to the NP- hard
problem (for </throwit><throwit>) at a certain value of </throwit><throwit>.
We did not find any irregularity in the variation of </throwit><throwit> at any </throwit><throwit>.
A naive expectation might be that around
the percolation point, beyond which the marginally connected lattice spanning
path is snapped off [7], the </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit> suffers some irregularity.
The absence of any such irregularity can also be justified easily: the
travelling salesman
has to visit all the occupied lattice sites (cities), not necessarily those on
the spanning cluster. Also, the TSP on dilute lattices has got to accomodate
the same kind of frustration as the (compact) self-avoiding chains on dilute
(percolating) lattices, although there the (collapsed) polymer is confined only
to the spanning cluster. This indicates that the
transition occurs either at </throwit><throwit> or at </throwit><throwit>. From the consideration of
frustration for the TSP even at </throwit><throwit>, it is almost certain that the
transition occurs at </throwit><throwit>.
However, this point requires further investigations.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-lat0002005.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text>: A review of results from lattice studies using improved and scale
controlled cooling methods is presented and their significance is
discussed. The improvement of the action ensures stable instanton
solutions of physical sizes. The scale controlled cooling can be
generally used as a gauge invariant low pass filter to extract the
physics from noisy MC configurations; in particular it preserves
instanton-antiinstanton pairs selected according to their interaction.
We apply these methods to analyze various features of the topological
structure of the Yang-Mills vacuum in a scaling invariant way.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Birth of the Brane World </text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Kazuya Koyama<throwit /></text>
<text font="bold">and</text>
<text font="bold">Jiro Soda</text>
<throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Abstract</text></p>
    <quote>
      <p>Birth of the brane world is studied using the Hamiltonian approach.
It is shown that an inflating brane world can be created from nothing.
The wave function of the universe obtained from the Wheeler de-Witt equation
and the time-dependent Schr<throwit>dinger equation for
quantized scalar fields on the brane are the same as in the conventional
4-dimensional quantum cosmology if the bulk is exactly the Anti-de
Sitter spacetime. The effect of the massive objects in the bulk is also
discussed. This analysis tells us the presence of the extra dimension
imprints a nontrivial effect on the quantum cosmology of the
brane world. This fact is important for the analysis of the
quantum fluctuations in the inflationary scenario
of the brane world.
</throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit /></p>
    </quote>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]
<inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="384.1pt">
        <para xml:id="p3.p1">
          <p>When studying the production of minijets and transverse energy flow
in high energy hadron-hadron or nucleus-nucleus collisions, two
essential points have to be taken into account. First, one has to
account for the virtuality of the colliding partons and secondly,
it is important to avoid double counting, when many links in a
parton chain can be interpreted as the momentum transfer in a hard
subcollision. The Linked Dipole Chain model, introduced for low-<throwit>
DIS, is particularly suitable for a study of these problems. It
describes (mini)jet production in a </throwit><throwit>-factorizing
formalism, which includes all links in a parton chain on an equal
footing, avoiding double counting. In a “naive” calculation based
on integrated structure functions, the cross section blows up for
small </throwit><throwit>, which makes it necessary to introduce a soft
cutoff. In our approach we find a dynamical suppression at low
</throwit><throwit>, which makes it possible to extrapolate to higher
energies and make more reliable predictions for RHIC and LHC.</throwit></p>
        </para>
      </inline-para></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002010.xml

Para index in docroot: 13
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><throwit>(BEDT-TTF)</throwit><throwit>Cu(NCS)</throwit><throwit> (BEDT-TTF denotes
bis-ethylenedithio-tetrathiafulvalene, or ET for short) is one in
a series of highly anisotropic OSs, characterized by a layered
structure. The conducting layers consist of a checkerboard pattern
of face-to-face ET dimers, with nearest neighbor dimer pairs
oriented perpendicularly </throwit><throwit>. These donor sheets exhibit
near isotropic 2D conductivity within the </throwit><text font="bold">bc</text> plane. The
insulating layers form from weakly bonded arrays of <throwit>shaped
Cu(NCS)</throwit><throwit> anions. The anisotropy parameter in the normal state,
given by the ratio of the in-plane to out-of-plane conductivities
</throwit><throwit>, is </throwit><throwit>. In the superconducting
state, the anisotropy parameter is given by </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are the London penetration depths
for AC currents induced parallel (</throwit><throwit>) and perpendicular (</throwit><throwit>) to the
conducting layers respectively </throwit><throwit>. Such a large
anisotropy makes this OS a prime candidate to study Josephson
coupling, and changes in this coupling upon the introduction of
supercurrent vortices into the sample through the application of
an external magnetic field.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Highly Excited Friedmann Universe</text> <throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">V. V. Kuzmichev</text> <throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> A highly excited Friedmann universe filled with
a scalar field and radiation has been considered. On the basis of
a direct solution to the quantum-mechanical problem with a
well-defined time variable, it has been shown that such a universe
can have features (energy density, scale factor, Hubble constant,
density parameter, matter mass, equivalent number of baryons, age,
dimensions of large-scale fluctuations, amplitude of fluctuations
of cosmic microwave background radiation temperature) identical to
those of the currently observed Universe.<throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> Available cosmological data suggest that, from the
point of view of quantum theory, the currently observed Universe
is likely to be in a highly excited state [1]. This is confirmed
by estimates of the number of the quantum state that corresponds
to its averaged motion as a discrete unit [1-4]. In view of this,
it is important to investigate cosmological systems featuring
gravitational and matter fields and occurring in states with large
quantum numbers by proceeding from a direct solution to the
relevant quantum-mechanical problem.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text> The wave function of the quantum Friedmann universe
filled with radiation and a uniform scalar field <throwit> specified
by the potential </throwit><throwit> is determined by the Schrödinger
equation [4]</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> is a privileged time coordinate related to the
synchronous proper time </throwit><throwit> by the coordinate condition </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> being the scale factor, while</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>plays the role of the effective interaction potential in the
cosmological system being considered. Here, we use the system of
units in which <throwit> and
</throwit><throwit /><throwit /></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 21
<para xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">6.</text> The above numerical estimates of the parameters of the
universe are of an illustrative character. If we nevertheless
associate them with our Universe, it can be concluded that the
values observed in the present era for the scale factor, the mass
of matter in the Universe, and the density of the cosmic microwave
background radiation energy satisfy relation (23). The zero-order
approximation, which corresponds to setting <throwit>
in (20), leads to a very small value of </throwit><throwit>,
but it is very close to the lower boundary of the uncertainty
interval for </throwit><throwit> [11]. Although the potential </throwit><throwit>
undergoes only small variations in response to changes in the
field </throwit><throwit>, the field </throwit><throwit> itself changes fast, oscillating
about the point </throwit><throwit>, so that the approximation in which
</throwit><throwit> is invalid. The application of the present
model in this approximation would result in the
radiation-dominated universe; that is, it would not feature a
mechanism capable of filling it with matter upon a slow descent of
the potential </throwit><throwit> to the equilibrium position, which
corresponds to the true vacuum. In states of the universe that are
characterized by large values of the quantum numbers, the kinetic
term of the scalar field ensures the density parameter value close
to unity.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">ABOUT THE DETECTION OF GRAVITATIONAL WAVE BURSTS</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text fontsize="80%">T.PRADIER, N.ARNAUD, M.-A. BIZOUARD, F. CAVALIER, M. DAVIER, P.HELLO</text></p>

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Test of T violation in neutral B decays
<throwit /></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para align="center" class="ltx_noindent" vattach="middle" width="341.4pt" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>T violation should be tested independently of CP violation.
Besides K system, B meson decays provide another good place to
study T violation. In the Standard Model, T violation in
<throwit> oscillation is expected
to be small. The angular distribution of </throwit><throwit> decay
permits one to extract the T-odd correlation. In the absence
of final state interaction, T violation in
</throwit><throwit>
decay can reach </throwit><throwit> via </throwit><throwit> mixing.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001117.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">ON THE CONSISTENCY OF THE DETERMINISTIC</text></p>
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">LOCAL VOLATILITY FUNCTION MODEL</text></p>
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">(‘IMPLIED TREE’)</text></p>
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text fontsize="80%">KARL STROBL<throwit /></text></p>
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">ABN AMRO Bank N.V.</text></p>
    <p align="center" class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">250 Bishopsgate, London EC2M 4AA, U.K.</text></p>
    <inline-para align="center" class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="325.2pt">
      <para xml:id="p2.p1">
        <p class="ltx_align_center"><text fontsize="80%">ABSTRACT</text></p>
        <p><text fontsize="80%">We show that the frequent claim that the implied tree prices
exotics consistently with the market is untrue if the local volatilities
are subject to change and the market is arbitrage-free.
In the process, we analyse – in the most general
context – the impact of stochastic variables on the P&amp;L of a hedged
portfolio, and we conclude that no model can <text font="italic">a priori</text> be expected
to price all exotics in line with the vanilla options
market. Calibration of an assumed underlying
process from vanilla options alone must not be overly restrictive, yet still
unique, and relevant to all exotic options of interest.
For the implied tree we show that the calibration to real-world prices
allows us to only price vanilla options themselves correctly.
This is usually attributed to the incompleteness of the market
under traditional stochastic (local) volatility models. We show that
some ‘weakly’ stochastic volatility models without quadratic variation of
the volatilities avoid the incompleteness problems,
but they introduce arbitrage.
More generally, we find that any stochastic tradable either has quadratic
variation – and therefore a <throwit>-like P&amp;L on instruments with
non-linear exposure to that asset – or it introduces arbitrage
opportunities.</throwit></text></p>
      </para>
    </inline-para>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002006.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction.–</text>
There are several reasons to
study systems with interacting gravitational and non-Abelian
gauge fields with the Lagrangian of the type</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Here dots stand for other possible fields, which can be
scalars, Abelian vectors, etc. Also
the gauge coupling constant <throwit> can be position-dependent,
which is the case when a dilaton is present. First,
all modern models of particle physics include Yang-Mills fields as a
basic element and, since
the energies under consideration are climbing higher and higher,
the effects of gravity should also be considered. Besides,
as suggested by the recent brane-world scenarios, even at low
energies
gravity might be important </throwit><throwit>.
From the classical General Relativity point of view, the model
(</throwit><throwit>) can be viewed as a natural generalization of the
Einstein-Maxwell theory.
This suggests studying its solutions and,
in particular, checking
whether the standard electrovacuum theorems still apply.
Surprisingly, the answer to the latter question is negative –
the theory admits a large variety of new bizarre solutions,
such as hairy black holes, say, whose existence manifestly
contradicts the
conventional wisdom like the no-hair conjecture </throwit><throwit>.
Unfortunately, most of these solutions are available only
numerically,
which is due to the high complexity of the equations.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">The tale of the EYMS sphaleron.–</text>
As was mentioned above, only very few supergravity solutions with
non-Abelian gauge fields are known explicitly.
Of these we would like to describe
one which is particularly
interesting in view of the surprising developments it has caused.
This solution was originally discovered numerically in the
Einstein-Yang-Mills-Dilaton (EYMD) model for the gauge group
SU(2) <throwit>
(in which case one has in Eq.(</throwit><throwit>) </throwit><throwit>,
and there is also the standard kinetic term for the dilaton </throwit><throwit>).
The solution describes
a static, spherically symmetric particle-like object with finite
ADM mass
and a globally regular geometry. The gauge field is
essentially non-Abelian and purely magnetic
with zero total charge – due to the fast
fall-off at infinity.
It was realized that the solution is unstable
</throwit><throwit>, which however is not a drawback.
On the contrary, it turns out that the solution admits an
elegant interpretation </throwit><throwit> as a sphaleron
</throwit><throwit>. Specifically, one can
show that the solution relates to the top of the potential
barrier between the topological vacua in the EYMD theory.
This suggests that it might be responsible for some kind
of fermion number non-conservation in the theory. Let us
call this solution EYMD sphaleron.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">Dimensional reduction of type I string theory.–</text>
Let us sketch the essential steps leading to the above diagram.
The details can be found in <throwit>, and also in
</throwit><throwit>.
The starting point is the bosonic part of the action of D=10, N=1 supergravity</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The idea is to find a parameterization of <throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> in terms of
four-dimensional variables which reduces the equations of motion
for the action (</throwit><throwit>) to a consistent system of
four-dimensional equations. As a first step,
the tangent space metric is chosen in the form</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Here the parameter <throwit> assumes two values: </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>.
The two options correspond
to the same theory in D=10 – up to a renumbering of coordinates –
but to two different choices of the four-space.
Keeping this parameter in all formulas, we shall be able
to consider the two different cases together – the
reduction on </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit> and that
on </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p19">
    <p><text font="bold">Bogomol’nyi equations.–</text> The D=4 models obtained above
admit supersymmetric vacua.
These are solutions of the
bosonic field equations for which there are such non-trivial spinors
<throwit> that </throwit><throwit>.
It is rather difficult to directly solve the second order field equations for
the
bosonic Lagrangian (</throwit><throwit>), especially with non-trivial gauge fields.
The procedure is therefore to focus on the conditions
</throwit><throwit>, and this gives
the system of equations for the </throwit><throwit>.
These equations are usually inconsistent, but one can look for the
consistency conditions. The latter can be formulated as a system of
first order equations for the bosonic background, usually called
Bogomol’nyi equations. The Bogomol’nyi equations are compatible with
the second order field equations, and are sometimes integrable.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold">Supersymmetric monopole.–</text>
Let us set in (<throwit>) </throwit><throwit>. Notice that the equations
then become the same both in the FS and EFS cases.
After the substitution </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>the Bogomol’nyi equation (<throwit>) become equivalent
to one equation</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which is integrable. This gives the solution in the closed form:</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>For <throwit> (the EFS case) this solution describes a globally Euclidean
background with an essentially non-Abelian gauge field.
Since the configuration does not depend on </throwit><throwit>, the action
is infinite. For </throwit><throwit> (the FS case)
the solution is of the BPS monopole
type with unit magnetic charge. This is geodesically complete and
globally hyperbolic </throwit><throwit>.
Unfortunately, the ADM mass is infinite and the solution
is not asymptotically flat – due to the dilaton potential.
In view of its supersymmetry, it is very plausible that the
Lorentzian solution is stable, while for its Euclidean
counterpart the notion of dynamical stability makes no sense.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which is normalized such that <throwit>.
Unfortunately, analytical solutions to Eq.(</throwit><throwit>) are unknown.
The numerical integration

  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Complete Renormalization Group Improvement- Avoiding Factorization
and Renormalization Scale Dependence in QCD Predictions<text font="medium" /></text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="144%">C.J. Maxwell<throwit> and A. Mirjalili</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="120%">Centre for Particle Theory, University of Durham</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>For moments of leptoproduction structure functions we show that all
dependence on the renormalization and factorization scales disappears
provided that all the ultraviolet logarithms involving the physical
energy scale <throwit> are completely resummed.
The approach is closely related to Grunberg’s method of
Effective Charges.
A direct and simple method for extracting </throwit><throwit>
from experimental data is advocated.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">3. Coherent States .</text>
For our needs here a brief introduction to the concept of
coherent states (CS) on Lie groups
goes as follows: consider a Lie group <throwit>, with a unitary irreducible
representation </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, in a Hilbert space </throwit><throwit>. We
select a reference vector </throwit><throwit>, to be called the
”vacuum” state vector, and let </throwit><throwit> be its isotropy
subgroup, i.e for </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. The map from the factor group
</throwit><throwit> to the Hilbert space
</throwit><throwit>, introduced in
the form of an orbit of the vacuum state under a factor group element,
defines a CSV
</throwit><throwit> labelled
by points </throwit><throwit> of the coherent state manifold.
Coherent states form an (over)complete set of states, since
by means of the Haar invariant measure of the group </throwit><throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">viz. <throwit /></text>, they provide a resolution of unity,
<throwit>. As a consequence, any vector
</throwit><throwit> is analyzed in the CS basis,
</throwit><throwit>, with coefficients
</throwit><throwit>. We should note here that the square integrability
of the vectors </throwit><throwit> will impose some limits on the growth parameters of
the functions </throwit><throwit> (cf. </throwit><throwit> and references therein).</throwit></p>
  </para>

</throwit><throwit> by (0.1).
So it is enough to show
</throwit><throwit> by [7, 7.1] (because the Albanese kernel is torsion free by [9]).
See Remark after (1.3).
By the definition of
</throwit><throwit>,
it is enough to show
</throwit><throwit>.
But this is clear.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 10
<para xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> We show that biholomorphic automorphisms of a real analytic hypersurface in <throwit>
can be considered as (pointwise) Lie symmetries of a
holomorphic completely overdetermined involutive second order PDE system
defining its Segre family. Using the classical
S.Lie method we obtain a complete description of infinitesimal symmetries of such a
system and give a new proof of some well known results of CR geometry.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">The interplay between perturbative QCD and power corrections:
the description of scaling or automodelling limit violation
in deep-inelastic scattering
</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> The study of deep-inelastic scattering (DIS)
processes has a rather long and inspiring history. One of the first
realizations that the analysis of <throwit> DIS could play an important role
in investigations of the properties of the nucleon came
in Ref.</throwit><throwit>. The fundamental concept of scaling of
DIS structure functions (SFs) </throwit><throwit> has lead to many subsequent
investigations. Other important stages in the
development of both theoretical and experimental studies
of various characteristics of DIS processes in this productive
period were reviewed in detail recently </throwit><throwit>.
In particular, it was stressed that after the experimental
confirmation of scaling and indications of the existence
of point-like constituents of the nucleon, the more rigorous theoretical
explanation of the behaviour of DIS form factors
came onto the agenda. A series of
works by N. N. Bogolyubov and coauthors </throwit><throwit>, were devoted to
the development of the new method, which made it possible to analyse the
asymptotics of the form factors
of </throwit><throwit> DIS using the Jost-Lehmann-Dyson
integral representation,
and explain the property
of scaling (or as called it by the authors of Ref.</throwit><throwit> “automodelling”)
behaviour of the corresponding SFs
in the framework of general principles of local quantum field
theory </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text>  Our analysis of Refs.<throwit>-

its Mellin moments </throwit><throwit> using the Jacobi polynomials method, proposed
in Ref.</throwit><throwit> and further developed in the works of Ref.</throwit><throwit>.
Within this framework one has:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where
<throwit> are the Jacobi polynomials,
</throwit><throwit> are combinatorial coefficients given in
terms of Euler </throwit><throwit>-functions of the </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> weight parameters.
In view of the reasons discussed in Ref.</throwit><throwit>, they were fixed
to 0.7 and 3 respectively. The QCD evolution of the moments
is defined by the solution of the corresponding renormalization group equation:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The QCD running coupling constant enters this equation
through <throwit> and is defined as the expansion
in terms of inverse powers of </throwit><throwit>.

moments in Eq.(2) were parametrized as
</throwit><throwit>.

    <p><text font="bold">Remark 5</text>  Actually we believe that Theorem 1 still holds
provided the hypersurface <throwit> of contact type therein is replaced by the stable
hypersurface in the sense of [HV2]. Hence the hypersurface </throwit><throwit> of contact type in

Para index in docroot: 19
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark 6</text>  In [B] it was proved that the system of
Gromov-Witten invariants of the product of two varieties is equal to the
tensor product of the systems of Gromov-Witten invariants of the two factors.
Using the methods developed in [FO][LiT][R][Si] we believe that one can still
prove these product formula of Gromov-Witten invariants with any genus
for any product of two closed symplectic manifolds, and thus Corollary 3 also holds
for any genus <throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Holomorphy, Minimal Homotopy and the</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Combinatorial Intersection Cohomology for Fans</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 20
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">0. Preliminaries</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold">0.A Cones and Fans:</text> Let <throwit> be a real
vector space of dimension </throwit><throwit>. A non-zero
linear form </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>
determines the </throwit><text font="italic">upper halfspace</text>
<throwit>.
A (strictly convex polyhedral) </throwit><text font="italic">cone</text>
in <throwit> is a finite intersection </throwit><throwit> of halfspaces
with linear forms satisfying </throwit><throwit>. We let </throwit><throwit> denote the linear span of
</throwit><throwit> in </throwit><throwit>, and define </throwit><throwit>. A cone of dimension </throwit><throwit> is
often called a </throwit><throwit /><text font="italic">-cone</text> for short.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 27
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">0.B Graded <throwit>-modules:</throwit></text>
In this subsection, we recall algebra results
useful for the sequel.
We denote
with <throwit> the symmetric algebra </throwit><throwit>
over the dual vector space </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit>. Its
elements are canonically identified with
polynomial functions on </throwit><throwit>.
In the case of a
rational fan </throwit><throwit> is isomorphic to
the cohomology algebra </throwit><throwit> of the
classifying space </throwit><throwit> of the complex
algebraic </throwit><throwit>-torus </throwit><throwit>
acting on the associated toric variety.
Motivated by that
topological considerations, we
endow </throwit><throwit> with the positive even grading
determined by setting </throwit><throwit>;
in particular, </throwit><throwit> consists of all
linear forms on </throwit><throwit>. For a cone </throwit><throwit>
in </throwit><throwit>, let </throwit><throwit> denote the algebra
</throwit><throwit> with the grading as above.
The natural projection </throwit><throwit> extends to an epimorphism </throwit><throwit> of graded algebras. We
usually consider the elements in </throwit><throwit>
as functions </throwit><throwit>; the above
epimorphism then corresponds to the
restriction of polynomial functions.
If </throwit><throwit> is of dimension </throwit><throwit>, then the
equality </throwit><throwit> clearly holds.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 31
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">0.C Sheaves on a fan space:</text>
Let <throwit> be a sheaf of
real vector
spaces on the fan space </throwit><throwit>. Since the
“affine” open sets </throwit><throwit> form a basis of the topology
of </throwit><throwit>, the sheaf </throwit><throwit> is uniquely
determined by the collection of its values
</throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>, together
with the restriction homomorphisms
</throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>. On the
other hand, every such collection
belongs to a sheaf </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>, since an
“affine” open subset </throwit><throwit> can not be covered by strictly
smaller open sets. Furthermore, we note that
the sheaf </throwit><throwit> is flabby if and only if every
restriction map </throwit><throwit> is surjective. – In the same
spirit of ideas, sheaves on a fan
occur in the work of
Bressler and Lunts [BreLu</throwit><throwit>],
Brion [Bri] and
McConnell [McC].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 36
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">0.D Fan constructions associated with a
cone:</text> In addition to the <text font="italic">affine
fan</text> <throwit> and the </throwit><text font="italic">boundary fan</text> <throwit> associated
with a cone </throwit><throwit>, we need two more
constructions. Firstly, if </throwit><throwit> belongs
to a fan </throwit><throwit>, we consider the </throwit><text font="italic">star</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>of <throwit> in </throwit><throwit>. This set is not a
subfan of </throwit><throwit> – we note in passing that
it is the </throwit><text font="italic">closure</text> of the one-point
set <throwit> in the fan topology –, but
its image</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>under the quotient projection <throwit> is a fan in </throwit><throwit>, called
the </throwit><text font="italic">“transversal fan”</text> of <throwit>
in </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-lat0001016.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Axial Anomaly and Ginsparg-Wilson fermions in the Lattice Dirac Sea
picture</text></p>
    <p>Srinath Cheluvaraja</p>
    <p><text font="italic">Dept. of Physics and Astronomy, Louisiana State University,
Baton Rouge, LA, 70808</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>N.D. Hari Dass</p>
    <p><text font="italic">Institute of Mathematical Sciences,
Chennai, 600113</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">ABSTRACT<throwit /></text>The axial anomaly equation in 1+1 dimensional QED is obtained on the lattice
for fermions obeying the Ginsparg-Wilson relation. We make use of the
properties of the Lattice
Dirac sea to investigate the connection between the anomaly and the
Ginsparg-Wilson operator in the Hamiltonian picture. The correct anomaly is
reproduced for gauge fields whose characteristic time is much larger than
the lattice spacing, which is the regime where the adiabatic approximation
applies. A non-zero Wilson <throwit> parameter is
necessary to get the correct anomaly. The anomaly is shown to be independent
of </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>. The generalization to 3+1 dimensions is also discussed.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002140.xml

discussions and M.Gazdzicki for correspondence.</p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001078.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">A note on Riemann normal coordinates.</text></p>
    <p>[6mm]</p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">Agapitos Hatzinikitas<throwit /></text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">[8mm]</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="120%">University of Athens,</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="120%">Nuclear and Particle Physics Division,</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="120%">Panepistimioupoli GR-15771 Athens, Greece.</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">[8mm]</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Abstract</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">[3mm]</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_parbox" vattach="middle" width="448.1pt"><text fontsize="90%">The goal of this note is to provide a recursive algorithm that allows one to calculate the expansion of the
metric tensor up to the desired order in Riemann normal coordinates. We test our expressions up to fourth order and predict
results up to sixth order. For an arbitrary number of symmetric partial derivatives acting on the components of the
metric tensor subtle treatment is required since the degree of complication increases rapidly.</text></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=astro-ph0002313.xml
Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">The origin of the hard (<throwit> keV) X-ray background has
remained mysterious for over 35 years. Most of the soft
(</throwit><throwit> keV) X-ray background has been resolved into
discrete sources, which are primarily quasars; however, these
sources do not have the flat spectral shape required to
match the X-ray background spectrum. Here we report the results
of an X-ray survey 30 times more sensitive than previous studies
in the hard band and four times more sensitive in the soft
band. The sources detected in our survey account for at least
75 per cent of the hard X-ray background. The mean X-ray
spectrum of these sources is in good agreement with that of the
background. The X-ray emission from the majority of the detected
sources is unambiguously associated with either the nuclei
of otherwise normal bright galaxies or optically faint sources,
which could either be active nuclei of dust enshrouded
galaxies or the first quasars at very high redshifts.
</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001202.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Towards cohomology of renormalization:</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">[4pt]
bigrading the combinatorial Hopf algebra of rooted trees
D. J. Broadhurst<throwit> and D. Kreimer</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text> The renormalization of quantum field theory twists the antipode of a
noncocommutative Hopf algebra of rooted trees, decorated by an infinite set of
primitive divergences. The Hopf algebra of undecorated rooted trees,
<throwit>, generated by a single primitive divergence, solves a universal
problem in Hochschild cohomology. It has two nontrivial closed Hopf
subalgebras: the cocommutative subalgebra </throwit><throwit> of pure
ladder diagrams and the Connes-Moscovici noncocommutative subalgebra
</throwit><throwit> of noncommutative geometry. These three Hopf algebras
admit a bigrading by </throwit><throwit>, the number of nodes, and an index </throwit><throwit> that specifies
the degree of primitivity. In each case, we use iterations of the relevant
coproduct to compute the dimensions of subspaces with modest values of </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> and infer a simple generating procedure for the remainder. The results
for </throwit><throwit> are familiar from the theory of partitions, while
those for </throwit><throwit> involve novel transforms of partitions. Most
beautiful is the bigrading of </throwit><throwit>, the largest of the three. Thanks to
Sloane’s </throwit><text font="typewriter">superseeker</text>, we discovered that it saturates all possible
inequalities. We prove this by using the universal Hochschild-closed
one-cocycle <throwit>, which plugs one set of divergences into another, and by
generalizing the concept of natural growth beyond that entailed by the
Connes-Moscovici case. We emphasize the yet greater challenge of handling the
infinite set of decorations of realistic quantum field theory.
</throwit><throwit>) D.Broadhurst@open.ac.uk;
http://physics.open.ac.uk/</throwit><throwit>dbroadhu</throwit><throwit>Physics Dept, Open University, Milton Keynes MK7 6AA, UK</throwit><throwit /><throwit>) Dirk.Kreimer@uni-mainz.de;
http://dipmza.physik.uni-mainz.de/</throwit><throwit>kreimer</throwit><throwit>Heisenberg Fellow, Physics Dept, Univ. Mainz, 55099 Mainz, Germany</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para align="center" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Table 1</text>: Dimensions <throwit>
of the bigrading the cocommutative
subalgebra, </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002133.xml
/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001332.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">The layered quasi-one-dimensional molecular superconductor (TMTSF)<throwit>PF</throwit><throwit> is a very exotic material with a superconducting order parameter whose ground state symmetry has remained ill-defined </throwit><throwit>. Here we present a pulsed NMR Knight shift (K) study of </throwit><throwit>Se measured simultaneously with transport in pressurized (TMTSF)</throwit><throwit>PF</throwit><throwit>. The Knight shift is linearly dependent on the electron spin susceptibility </throwit><throwit>, and is therefore a direct measure of the spin polarization in the superconducting state. For a singlet superconductor, the spin contribution to the Knight shift, K</throwit><throwit>, falls rapidly on cooling through the transition. The present experiments indicate no observable change in K between the metallic and superconducting states, and thus strongly support the hypothesis of triplet p-wave superconductivity in (TMTSF)</throwit><throwit>PF</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract. <text font="medium">    We prove the following theorem for Holomorphic Foliations in
compact complex kaehler manifolds: if there is a compact leaf with finite holonomy, then
every leaf is compact with finite holonomy. As corollary we reobtain
stability theorems for compact foliations in Kaehler manifolds of Edwards-Millett-Sullivan and
Hollman.</text></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Noncommutative analysis and quantum physics</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">I. Quantities, ensembles and states</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Arnold Neumaier</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="slanted">Institut für Mathematik, Universität Wien</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="slanted">Strudlhofgasse 4, A-1090 Wien, Austria</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="slanted">email: neum@cma.univie.ac.at</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="slanted">WWW: http://solon.cma.univie.ac.at/<text yoffset="-2.6pt">~</text>neum/</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract.<text font="medium">
In this sequence of papers, noncommutative analysis is used to give a
consistent axiomatic approach to a unified conceptual foundation of
classical and quantum physics, free of undefined terms.
 The present Part I defines the concepts of quantities, ensembles, and
states, clarifies the logical relations and operations for them,
and shows how they give rise to probabilities and dynamics.
The stochastic and the deterministic features of quantum physics
are separated in a clear way by consistently distinguishing between
ensembles (representing stochastic elements) and states (representing
realistic elements).
 Ensembles are defined by extending the ‘probability via expectation’
approach of Whittle to noncommuting quantities. This approach
carries no connotations of unlimited repeatability; hence it can be
applied to unique systems such as the universe.
Precise concepts and traditional results about complementarity,
uncertainty and nonlocality follow with a minimum of technicalities.
Probabilities are introduced in a generality supporting so-called
effects (i.e., fuzzy events).
 States are defined as partial mappings that provide reference values
for certain quantities. An analysis of sharpness properties yields
well-known no-go theorems for hidden variables.
By dropping the sharpness requirement, hidden variable theories such
as Bohmian mechanics can be accommodated, but so-called ensemble states
turn out to be a more natural realization of a realistic state concept.
The weak law of large numbers explains the emergence of classical
properties for macroscopic systems.
 Dynamics is introduced via a one-parameter group of automorphisms.
A detailed conceptual analysis of the dynamics in terms of Poisson
algebras will follow in the second part of this series.
 The paper realizes a strong formal implementation of Bohr’s
correspondence principle. In all instances, classical and quantum
concepts are fully parallel: a single common theory has a classical
realization and a quantum realization.</text></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="left" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Keywords<text font="medium">:
axiomatization of physics,
Bell inequality,
Bohmian mechanics,
complementarity,
correspondence principle,
deterministic,
effect,
elements of physical reality,
ensemble,
event,
expectation,
flow of truth,
foundations of quantum mechanics,
Heisenberg picture,
hidden variables,
ideal measurement,
nonlocality,
foundations of probability,
preparation of states,
quantities,
quantum correlations,
quantum logic,
quantum probability,
reference value,
Schrödinger picture,
sharpness
spin,
state,
state of the universe,
uncertainty relation,
weak law of large numbers,
Young measure</text></text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Effective interactions between electric double-layers<throwit /><throwit /></text><text fontsize="120%">Jean-Pierre Hansen<throwit /></text>Department of Chemistry, Cambridge
University, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United Kingdom;
e-mail: jph32@cus.cam.ac.uk<throwit /><throwit /><text fontsize="120%">Hartmut Löwen<throwit /></text>Institut für Theoretische Physik II,
Heinrich-Heine-Universität, Universitätsstraße 1,<throwit>D-40225
Düsseldorf, Germany; e-mail : hlowen@thphy.uni-duesseldorf.de</throwit><throwit /><throwit /><throwit /><text fontsize="120%">Key Words:</text> Density functional; charged colloids;
correlations; Poisson-Boltzmann theory; Debye screening<throwit /><throwit /><text fontsize="120%">Shortened Title</text>: Electric double-layer interactions<throwit /><throwit /><text fontsize="120%">Abstract<throwit /></text>The present review summarizes and assesses recent
theoretical and experimental advances, with special emphasis
on the effective interaction
between charge-stabilized colloids, in the bulk or in
confined geometries, and on the
ambiguities of defining an effective charge of the colloidal
particles. Some consideration is given to the often neglected
discrete solvent effects.<throwit /><throwit /></p>

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 245

    <p><text font="bold">§9. Rings of Stable Range One</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 265
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p257">
    <p><text font="bold">(9.7)</text> Also well-known is the following classical generalization of
Schur’s Lemma: <text font="italic">if <throwit> is a module of finite length,
then</throwit></text> <throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">is a semiprimary (and hence semilocal)
ring</text>; see, for instance, [La<throwit>: Ex. (21.24)].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 266
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p258">
    <p><text font="bold">(9.8)</text> Any strongly indecomposable module has, by definition,
a local (and hence semilocal) endomorphism ring. Examples include, for
instance, all indecomposable modules of finite length, and all injective
(in fact all quasi-injective or pure-injective) indecomposable modules;
see, e.g. [La<throwit>: (3.52), Exer. (6.32)] and [F</throwit><throwit>: (2.27)].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 267
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p259">
    <p><text font="bold">(9.9)</text> Camps and Dicks [CD] showed in 1993 that <text font="italic">any artinian
module has a semilocal endomorphism ring.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 268
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p260">
    <p><text font="bold">(9.10)</text> In 1995, Herbera and Shamsuddin [HS] generalized the
Camps-Dicks result above by showing that, <text font="italic">if a module <throwit> has finite
uniform dimension and co-uniform dimension</throwit></text>,<throwit>
</throwit><text font="italic">then it has a semilocal endomorphism ring.</text> This class includes all
linearly compact modules<throwit>, and therefore all artinian modules. Thus, the Herbera-Shamsuddin
result implies that linearly compact modules have semilocal endomorphism
rings; this affirms an earlier conjecture of Faith. In the </throwit><text font="italic">commutative</text>
case, a stronger conclusion is possible. In this case, any linearly compact
module <throwit> is algebraically compact (i.e. purely injective)
according to Jensen and Lenzing [JL: p. 289]. Therefore, combining the
Herbera-Shamsuddin result above with [JL: (7.5)], we see that </throwit><throwit>
has a </throwit><text font="italic">semiperfect</text> endomorphism ring. This provides a nice
connection back to the material of §5.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 269
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p261">
    <p><text font="bold">(9.11)</text> A nonzero module is said to be <text font="italic">uniserial</text> if its
submodules form a chain under inclusion. Such a module has clearly
uniform dimension and co-uniform dimension both equal to <throwit>. Thus,
if </throwit><throwit> where the </throwit><throwit>’s are
uniserial, then the “serial module” </throwit><throwit> has uniform and co-uniform
dimension </throwit><throwit>, and hence it has a semilocal endomorphism ring by (9.10).
For more information on the structure of </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>, and its applications to a (weak) Krull-Schmidt Theorem
for serial modules, see Facchini’s paper [F</throwit><throwit>] and his recent book
[F</throwit><throwit>].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 281

reading of a penultimate version of this paper. His many thoughtful
comments and suggestions have led to various improvements in my exposition.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract – In order to function reliably, synthetic molecular circuits require mechanisms that allow them to adapt to environmental disturbances. Least mean squares (LMS) schemes, such as commonly encountered in signal processing and control, provide a powerful means to accomplish that goal. In this paper we show how the traditional LMS algorithm can be implemented at the molecular level using only a few elementary biomolecular reactions. We demonstrate our approach using several simulation studies and discuss its relevance to synthetic biology.
</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001126.xml

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text>
1D quantum oscillator, reduction,
<throwit> interaction, duality, 1D anyon.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">I. INTRODUCTION</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">II. ANYON–OSCILLATOR DUALITY</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">III. ENERGY LEVELS AND WAVE FUNCTIONS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p14">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">IV. DUALITY FOR SOLUTIONS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">V. CONCLUSIONS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">a)</text> The 1D oscillator has only a discrete energy spectrum and, therefore,
is a model provided by the property which is known in QCD as confinement.
A particle situated in the confinement potential cannot be removed from
the center and transferred to infinity. On the
other hand, the 1D Coulomb anyon is a system possessing both the discrete and
continuous part in the energy spectrum. At the same time, it includes <throwit>
interaction and, therefore, pretends to be a magnetic monopole in one spatial
dimension. All these ideas confirm that our result can be interpreted in the
spirit of the Seiberg–Witten duality</throwit><throwit>: The theories with strong
coupling (i.e., including confinement) are equivalent to the theories with
weak coupling (i.e., without confinement) accompanied by magnetic monopoles.
We conclude that the Seiberg–Witten duality has its prototype in 1D quantum mechanics.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 20
<para xml:id="p18">
    <p><text font="bold">b)</text> The anyon–oscillator duality is a simple example of a
more complicated
dyon–oscillator duality<throwit>. The latter connects
the isotropic oscillator with charge–dyon bound system
(dyon is a hypothetical object which has both
the electric and magnetic charge</throwit><throwit>). The passage from an oscillator to
a charge–dyon system is realized by non-bijective bilinear
transformations</throwit><throwit> (for the mapping of the 1D Coulomb system into the
oscillator refer to</throwit><throwit>).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para xml:id="p19">
    <p><text font="bold">c)</text> The wave function (<throwit>) of 1D Coulomb anyon can formally be
extended to the region </throwit><throwit>. Such a continuation is an arbitrary-rule
operation and we choose the following one. First, still being in the region </throwit><throwit>,
we change </throwit><throwit> in the exponent and confluent hypergeometric function by </throwit><throwit>
and remain unchanged the factor </throwit><throwit>. Then, we extend the expression to the
region </throwit><throwit>. These steps allow us to get rid of divergence in
the exponent for large negative values of </throwit><throwit> and conserve the normalization condition
in </throwit><throwit> by multiplying the function </throwit><throwit> by the factor
</throwit><throwit>. The obtained wave function </throwit><throwit> satisfies
Eq. (</throwit><throwit>) in the region </throwit><throwit>
and has the parity </throwit><throwit>, i.e. describes the 1D anyon</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">d)</text> Eq. (<throwit>) for </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> corresponds to
the so-called 1D hydrogen atom</throwit><throwit> (for later references see</throwit><throwit>)
which has some mysterious properties. For example,
the ground state corresponds to an infinite negative value of the energy and the exited
levels are double degenerated. The reason is that the potential </throwit><throwit> is singular
in 1D space and the system is provided by hidden symmetry</throwit><throwit>
and supersymmetry</throwit><throwit>. As it is follows from (</throwit><throwit>) and
(</throwit><throwit>), the Calogero–Sutherland potential transforms the 1D hydrogen
atom into two modified atoms with the statistical parameter </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>. This transformation leads to the formation of the ground states
with a finite energy level and remove the problem of degeneracy (replacement
</throwit><throwit>).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold">e)</text> It is easily to be convinced
that Eq. (<throwit>) is identical to the Schrödinger
equation with the Hamiltonian</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. So, we deal with
a charged particle
moving in the field created by the 1D Coulomb dyon of the electric charge </throwit><throwit>
and purely imaginary magnetic charge </throwit><throwit>.
The Calogero–Sutherland potential gains the
meaning of the Goldhaber term typical of theory
of magnetic monopoles</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
