/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=gr-qc0002033.xml
Para index in docroot: 1
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">A THEORY OF QUANTUM GRAVITY</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">FROM FIRST PRINCIPLES</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> When quantum fields are studied on manifolds with
boundary, the corresponding one-loop quantum theory for bosonic
gauge fields with linear covariant gauges needs the assignment of
suitable boundary conditions for elliptic differential operators of
Laplace type. There are however deep reasons to modify such a scheme
and allow for pseudo-differential boundary-value
problems. When the boundary operator is
allowed to be pseudo-differential while remaining a projector, the
conditions on its kernel leading to strong ellipticity of the
boundary-value problem are studied in detail. This makes it possible
to develop a theory of one-loop quantum gravity from first principles
only, i.e. the physical principle of invariance under infinitesimal
diffeomorphisms and the mathematical requirement of a strongly
elliptic theory.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">(i) Ellipticity in the Interior</text></p>
    <p>Let <throwit> be an open subset with compact closure in </throwit><throwit>, and
consider an open subset </throwit><throwit> whose closure </throwit><throwit>
is properly included into </throwit><throwit>: </throwit><throwit>.
If </throwit><throwit> is a symbol of order </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>, it is said to be
</throwit><text font="italic">elliptic</text> on <throwit> if there exists an open set </throwit><throwit>
which contains </throwit><throwit> and positive constants
</throwit><throwit> so that</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>. The corresponding operator </throwit><throwit>
is then elliptic.</throwit></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">(ii) Strong Ellipticity in the Absence of Boundaries</text></p>
    <p>Let us assume that the symbol under consideration is
<text font="italic">polyhomogeneous</text>, in that it admits an asymptotic expansion
of the form</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where each term <throwit> has the </throwit><text font="italic">homogeneity property</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The leading symbol is then, by definition,</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Strong ellipticity in the absence of boundaries is formulated in
terms of the leading symbol, and it requires that</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> being a positive function
on </throwit><throwit>. It can then be proved that the Gärding inequality holds,
according to which, for any </throwit><throwit>,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with <throwit>.</throwit></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">(iii) Strong Ellipticity in the Presence of Boundaries</text></p>
    <p>The homogeneity property (32) only holds for <throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>. Consider now the case </throwit><throwit>, for which one obtains
the leading symbol which plays the key role in the definition
of ellipticity. If </throwit><throwit> is not a polynomial (which corresponds
to the genuinely pseudo-differential case) while being a homogeneous
function of </throwit><throwit>, it is irregular at </throwit><throwit>. When </throwit><throwit>,
the only control over the leading symbol is provided by
estimates of the form</throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>We therefore come to appreciate the problematic aspect of symbols
of pseudo-differential operators.<throwit> The singularity at
</throwit><throwit> can be dealt with either by modifying the leading symbol
for small </throwit><throwit> to be a </throwit><throwit> function (at the price of
loosing the homogeneity there), or by keeping the strict
homogeneity and dealing with the singularity at </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">References</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 1
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">MINIMAL ESCAPE VELOCITIES</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> We give a new derivation of the minimal velocity estimates
[SiSo1] for unitary evolutions. Let <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> be selfadjoint operators on a
Hilbert space </throwit><throwit>. The starting point is Mourre’s inequality </throwit><throwit>,
which is supposed to hold in form sense on the spectral subspace </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit>
for some interval </throwit><throwit>. The second assumption is that the multiple
commutators </throwit><throwit> are well-behaved for </throwit><throwit> . Then
we show that, for a dense set of </throwit><throwit>’s in </throwit><throwit> and all </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit> is contained in the spectral subspace </throwit><throwit> as
</throwit><throwit>, up to an error of order </throwit><throwit> in norm. We apply this general result
to the case where </throwit><throwit> is a Schrödinger operator on </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> the dilation
generator, proving that </throwit><throwit> is asymptotically supported in the set
</throwit><throwit> up to an error of order </throwit><throwit> in norm.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">1. INTRODUCTION</text>
Before posing the problem in abstract form we describe it in its
original concrete setting. Consider the Schrödinger equation</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for a particle in <throwit> under the influence of a potential </throwit><throwit>. We are
interested in the long–time behavior of orbits </throwit><throwit> in the
continuous spectral subspace </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit>. Under mild conditions on </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
is selfadjoint and</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for some constant <throwit>. Here </throwit><throwit>
denotes the expectation value of an observable </throwit><throwit> in the state </throwit><throwit>.
By Ruelle’s theorem ([Rue], see also [CFKS], [HuSi1]) any orbit </throwit><throwit> in
</throwit><throwit> is </throwit><text font="italic">escaping</text> in a mean ergodic sense :</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for any finite <throwit>. The question is : </throwit><text font="italic">how fast ?</text> The answer will of
course depend on the initial state <throwit>. The simplest example is the
free particle (</throwit><throwit>): if the Fourier transform </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit>
is smooth and supported outside some ball of radius </throwit><throwit>, then a standard
asymptotic expansion gives the result</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for any <throwit>. In this sense the orbits </throwit><throwit> of the given type are said to have a
</throwit><text font="italic">minimal escape velocity <throwit /></text> given by the support of <throwit>.
To obtain a similar result for </throwit><throwit> we study the long–time behavior
of the expectation values </throwit><throwit>
for suitable observables </throwit><throwit>, which evolve according to</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Mourre’s very fruitful idea [Mou] was to find observables <throwit> such that the commutator

    <throwit>

Para index in docroot: 22
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3. COMMUTATOR EXPANSIONS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Proof.</text>

    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Inserting the expansion (3.7) we notice that only the remainder
<throwit> contributes, since</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Commutator expansions of this type were introduced in [SiSo1] and have since become
an important tool of operator analysis. There are several versions
([SiSo1], [Ski], [IvSi], [ABG]) which differ in the form of the remainder estimate.
The results above are derived in [HuSi2] and are based on the
Helffer-Sjöstrand functional calculus ([HeSj], [Dav]).</p>

    <p><text font="bold">COMMENT ON ”QUANTUM PHASE SHIFT CAUSED BY SPATIAL<throwit>CONFINEMENT”</throwit></text>
<throwit /><throwit /><throwit /><text font="bold">Murray Peshkin</text> <throwit /><throwit /><text font="italic">Argonne National Laboratory</text> <throwit /><text font="italic">Physics Division-203</text> <throwit /><text font="italic">Argonne, IL 60439-4843</text> <throwit /><text font="italic">peshkin@anl.gov</text> <throwit /><throwit>Received 3 September 1999; revised 22 November 1999 </throwit><throwit /><throwit /><throwit>The analysis of phase shifts in executed and proposed interferometry
experiments on photons and neutrons neglected forces exerted at the
boundaries of spatial constrictions. When those forces are included it
is seen that the observed phenomena are not in fact geometric in nature.
A new proposal in the reply to this comment avoids that pitfall.
</throwit><throwit /><throwit>Key Words: interferometry, phase shifts, force-free effects. </throwit><throwit /><throwit /><throwit /><text font="bold">1. INTRODUCTION</text> <throwit /><throwit>Allman </throwit><text font="italic">et al.</text> [1] have proposed a neutron interference experiment
wherein the neutrons in one arm of an interferometer pass through a
channel in an otherwise reflecting barrier and the resulting phase
shift is to be measured. Following an earlier discussion [2], they
calculate that the phase shift expected to be induced by the neutrons’
passage through the channel in the barrier will be given for an
appropriate range of the parameters by</p>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract </text>
By using the method of iterated integral representations of series, we establish some explicit relationships between multiple zeta values and Integrals of logarithmic functions. As applications of these relations, we show that multiple zeta values of the form</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for <throwit> or </throwit><throwit>, and</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, satisfy certain recurrence relations which allow us to write them in terms of zeta values, polylogarithms and </throwit><throwit>. Moreover, we also prove that the multiple zeta values </throwit><throwit> can be expressed as a rational linear combination of products of zeta values, multiple polylogarithms and </throwit><throwit> when </throwit><throwit>. Furthermore, we also obtain reductions for certain multiple polylogarithmic values at </throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">Keywords</text> Multiple zeta values; multiple polylogarithms; harmonic numbers; Euler sums.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">AMS Subject Classifications (2010):</text> 11A07; 11M32; 33B15</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 7
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Introduction</text></p>
    <p>Let <throwit> be the roots of a </throwit><text font="italic">generic</text> polynomial
<throwit> over a division algebra </throwit><throwit>.
There are two important classical problems: a) to express the
coefficients </throwit><throwit> through the roots, and b)
to determine all factorizations of </throwit><throwit>, or </throwit><throwit>, where
</throwit><throwit> is a formal variable commuting with elements of </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para xml:id="p62">
    <p vattach="bottom"><text font="bold">Figure 1.</text> A schematic of the VME part of the E791 DA system.
Two complete VME crates are shown, with the Event Fifo Buffers and data paths
from the digitizers at the base.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 69
<para xml:id="p64">
    <p vattach="bottom"><text font="bold">Figure 2.</text> Detail of the connections between a single EFB and the six
EBIs attached to it. Each EBI is in a different VME crate. The output data
path and the EFB status lines are bussed across all six EBIs. The output data
path connects to the VME backplane of each crate through the EBI. The EBIs
share the data path by communicating along the EFB token line.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 72
<para xml:id="p66">
    <p vattach="bottom"><text font="bold">Figure 3.</text> Schematic of the entire E791 DA system. The VAX 11/780 was
the user interface to the VME part of the system, via the DA Control Display.
The VAX part of the DA program handled the status and error displays, sent
events for monitoring to the event pool, and received histogram requests
via the mailbox. An entirely separate set of programs picked up events from
the event pool or sent histogram requests to the mailbox.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 75
<para xml:id="p68">
    <p vattach="bottom"><text font="bold">Figure 4.</text> Detail of the E791 DA Control Display. The lower half of
the screen contained commands to the system, executed by using arrow keys to
move the shaded box over the command. The upper half of the screen contained
contained information on the current state of the system (RUNNING or IDLE,
tapes LOADED or UNLOADED, tape writing ON or OFF), the Run Number if a
data-taking run was in progress, and the number of events written to tape.</p>
  </para>

<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">A FOCUS ON FOCAL SURFACES</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center">E.
Arrondo, M. Bertolini and C. Turrini</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">§0. Notations and definitions.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Definitions:</text> A point <throwit> is a </throwit><text font="italic">fundamental point</text> of <throwit> if </throwit><throwit> is not a finite set.
Dually, a </throwit><text font="italic">fundamental plane</text> of <throwit> is a fundamental point of
</throwit><throwit>, i.e. a plane containing infinitely many lines of the congruence.
The </throwit><text font="italic">focal locus</text> of <throwit> is the branch locus (typically a surface)
of </throwit><throwit>. The elements of the focal locus are called </throwit><text font="italic">focal points</text>
of <throwit>. Dually, a </throwit><text font="italic">focal plane</text> of <throwit> is a focal point of </throwit><throwit>.
Equivalently ([5] Lemma 4.4), a focal point </throwit><throwit>
is characterized by the fact that there exists a line </throwit><throwit> of the
congruence such that the embedded tangent plane of </throwit><throwit> at the point
represented by </throwit><throwit> meets the alpha plane </throwit><throwit> in at least a
line of </throwit><throwit> (i.e. a pencil of lines of </throwit><throwit>). This is
in fact the definition of focal point given by Goldstein.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 25
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Definition:</text> We will call a <text font="italic">focal line</text> <throwit> of a
congruence to a line of a congruence such that all of its points are
focal. Again from [5] Lemma 4.4, this means that the
embedded tangent plane of </throwit><throwit> at the point represented by </throwit><throwit> meets in
a pencil all the alpha planes </throwit><throwit> for which </throwit><throwit>. Then, a
line </throwit><throwit> is focal if and only if its embedded tangent plane is a
beta-plane.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 27
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Definition:</text> We will call the <text font="italic">strict focal
surface</text> of a congruence <throwit> to the closure </throwit><throwit> of the reduced
structure of the branch locus of </throwit><throwit>. To
distinguish from this, we usually refer to the focal locus </throwit><throwit> (as a
scheme) as the </throwit><text font="italic">total focal surface</text>.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remarks:</text> 1) We abused the notation in the above
definition. First of all, <throwit> could be empty. As observed in the
definition of focal line, this would imply that the embedded
tangent plane of </throwit><throwit> at any point is a beta-plane. In this case,
the congruence itself is a beta-plane (see for instance [5],
Corollary 4.5.1). On the other hand, </throwit><throwit> could be either a point
(and then </throwit><throwit> is an alpha-plane) or a curve, which would mean that
</throwit><throwit> is the congruence of bisecants to that curve. As we will
observe later, such a congruence is only smooth when the curve is a
twisted cubic or an elliptic quartic.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 32
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Definition:</text> If <throwit> is a
surface, we will write </throwit><throwit> for the class of its hyperplane
section. It is clear that a surface and its dual have the same
invariant </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 34
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">§1. Numerical invariants of the focal surface
of a smooth congruence.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 44
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remarks:</text> 1) The degree and class of the focal surface
are very well-known and there are much simpler ways to compute them.
In fact, all the other numerical invariants of the focal surface,
except <throwit>, can be computed by just using the incidence variety
point-line. In fact, </throwit><throwit> can also be computed by using that it
is the class of </throwit><throwit> considered as a surface in </throwit><throwit> (see
[15]). Then </throwit><throwit> is nothing but the degree of
</throwit><throwit>, which is easily seen to be the value just
computed.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 54
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remarks:</text> 1) If at the end of the above proof we
multiply by <throwit> instead of </throwit><throwit>, we would get the degree of the ruled
surface consisting of those lines such that one of its two focal
points is a cusp in the focal surface. This number turns out to be
</throwit><throwit>, and was already known by the classics (see
[18] §13 or [16] page 197). In fact, they also
knew how to compute the degree invariants of the nodal and cuspidal
curves. Of course, they computed all these invariants in terms of
other invariants, as for instance </throwit><throwit>, instead of the “modern”
invariants that we use.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 59
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 1.13</text>: (See also Example 5.5 below).
The complete intersection of <throwit> with a general hyperplane and
a general quadric produces a congruence of bidegree </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>, in particular without cuspidal curve. As a surface in </throwit><throwit>,it is the surface given by the polarized pair
</throwit><throwit> i.e. by the linear
system of plane cubics through five points. Therefore, the
congruence contains sixteen lines of </throwit><throwit>, which correspond
to sixteen pencils of lines of </throwit><throwit>. Hence the congruence
contains sixteen fundamental points (and sixteen fundamental
planes) and the degree of the corresponding cone at each of them is
one. In fact, the formula in 1) yields </throwit><throwit>, and hence Remark 3)
proves that there are no more fundamental points (or fundamental
planes).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 60
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 1.14</text>: As a second example, we can
consider the congruence <throwit> of bidegree </throwit><throwit> which is the Del
Pezzo surface (i.e. </throwit><throwit>) given by the polarized pair
</throwit><throwit> i.e. by the linear
system of plane cubics through four points. It is known, and easy
to verify, that such a Del Pezzo surface contains exactly ten lines
(the four exceptional lines and the six lines joining the four base
points) and five pencil of conics (the four pencils given by the
lines in </throwit><throwit> through one base point and the pencil given
by the conics through the base points). This implies that the
congruence has </throwit><throwit> fundamental points and </throwit><throwit> fundamental planes
in </throwit><throwit> Indeed the ten lines give rise to ten fundamental
points and ten fundamental planes. Moreover each pencil of conics
contains at least one conic which is contained in an alpha-plane.
Let us prove this fact for instance for the pencil </throwit><throwit> (for
the others the proof is the same). Since the image of </throwit><throwit> in
</throwit><throwit> is a line, in particular it is contained in an
alpha-plane, so that there is a section of </throwit><throwit> vanishing on
</throwit><throwit>, i.e. a section of </throwit><throwit>. Since
</throwit><throwit>, it follows easily that there is an exact
sequence</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>From this it follows that <throwit>, and hence any
conic in </throwit><throwit> is contained in the zero locus of a section of
</throwit><throwit>. But observe that </throwit><throwit>, so that exactly a
hyperplane inside </throwit><throwit> corresponds to alpha-planes. This
means that at least one section corresponding to an alpha-plane
vanishes on a a conic of the pencil, as wanted. Applying now Remark
3) we see that the degree of the ruled surface generated by the lines
throught the fundamental points is </throwit><throwit> (since the bidegree is
</throwit><throwit> there is no cuspidal curve). Since we have found ten cones of
degree one and five cones of degree two, there are no more
fundamental points in the congruence.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 61
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 1.15</text>
In this last example, we consider the congruence of bidegree <throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> which is the rational surface given by the polarized pair
</throwit><throwit> i.e. by the
linear system of plane quartics with a fixed double point and through
other six points. Such a Castelnuovo surface contains twelve lines
(the six exceptional lines corresponding to simple points, and the
six lines joining the double point with the other six ones) and </throwit><throwit>
conics (the one corresponding to the double base point, the </throwit><throwit>
corresponding to the lines joining two simple base points, the </throwit><throwit>
corresponding to conics through the double point and other four
simple points, and the one corresponding to the cubic with a double
point in the double base point and passing through the other base
points). Fano shows ([4], pages 154-155) that besides the twelve
fundamental points coming from the twelve lines of the congruence,
there can be other fundamental points (vertex of cones corresponding
to conics lying in alpha-planes) or not, depending on the projective
embedding. Specifically the Castelnuovo surface is the complete
intersection of the cubic Segre threefold and a smooth hyperquadric
in </throwit><throwit>. It is hence contained in a three-dimensional linear
system of hyperquadrics. Each smooth quadric in the system can be
viewed as a Grassmannian. While for a general quadric we do not get
extra fundamental points, for particular ones we can get one, two or
three new fundamental points.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 62
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark:</text> As shown in the previous example, the number
of the fundamental points of a congruence does not depend only on its
invariants, in particular it is meaningless to look for a formula
giving the contribution of the fundamental points only in terms of
the bidegree, of the sectional genus and of other usual invariants of
the surface. This fact seems not to be considered by Roth who gives a
formula ([16], page 198) to compute the degree <throwit> of the
scroll of lines of </throwit><throwit> consisting of those lines such that
one of its two focal points is a node in the focal surface. Such a
formula, when applied to a congruence of bidegree </throwit><throwit> with </throwit><throwit> hence without nodal curve, should give the number of fundamental
points. However the formula for </throwit><throwit> given by Roth fails for
several congruences (and not only for the above example).</throwit></p>
  </para>

even if one would expect the focal locus to be just the curve
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

quartic with three cusps, so its dual is a nodal cubic), </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>. Then we get </throwit><throwit> (in fact, as we remarked, the dual of the

Para index in docroot: 177
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 5.3:</text> The above example shows that the
dual of the congruence of bisecants to a twisted cubic behaves
nicely with respect to is focal surface. So it is natural to see
what happens to the congruence <throwit> dual of the other smooth
congruence of bisecants, namely the bisecants to an elliptic
quartic </throwit><throwit>. Then </throwit><throwit> has bidegree </throwit><throwit> and sectional
genus </throwit><throwit>. Hence, the total focal surface has degree </throwit><throwit>. On the
other hand, reasoning as in the previous example, </throwit><throwit> will be the
congruence of bitangents to the dual </throwit><throwit>, which is a tangent
developable of degree </throwit><throwit> and cuspidal curve of degree </throwit><throwit>
(corresponding to the osculating planes of </throwit><throwit>). Since the
hyperplane section has genus one, it follows easily that </throwit><throwit>
has a nodal curve of degree </throwit><throwit> and hence </throwit><throwit>. What
happens now is that the total focal surface is twice </throwit><throwit>
(and therefore no formula for the invariants of the focal surface
is valid anymore). Indeed, given a general point </throwit><throwit>,
there are two bitangents to </throwit><throwit> with tangency points at </throwit><throwit>
and another point. Summing up, the congruence of bitangents to the
(strict) focal surface coincide with the congruence </throwit><throwit> itself, but
the (total) focal surface of the congruence is not </throwit><throwit> as a
scheme, but only as a set.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 179
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 5.4:</text> We have observed (Prop.
3.5 or Corollary 4.5) that the only smooth
congruence of bitangents to a smooth surface in <throwit> is the
congruence of bidegree </throwit><throwit> of bitangents to a smooth quartic
</throwit><throwit>. By duality, we also have a smooth
congruence </throwit><throwit> of bidegree </throwit><throwit> consisting of the bitangents to
the dual </throwit><throwit>. This is a surface in </throwit><throwit> of degree </throwit><throwit>,
a nodal curve of degree </throwit><throwit> and cuspidal curve of degree </throwit><throwit>. As in
the dual case, this counts six times in the total focal surface (since
through a general point of it there pass six lines that are tangent at
that point and another one). But the total focal surface has degree
</throwit><throwit>, so that there are no other components. Hence this congruence
verifies the same property with respect to the focal surface as the
one in the previous example.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 181
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Example 5.5:</text> Consider in <throwit> the congruence
</throwit><throwit> obtained in Example1.13, which has bidegree </throwit><throwit> and
sectional genus </throwit><throwit>. It is then a very classical result that the
focal surface is the so-called Kummer’s surface, a quartic surface
with sixteen nodes, corresponding to the sixteen fundamental points
of </throwit><throwit> (see for [8] for a thorough study of this surface).
However, the congruence of bisecants to the Kummer’s surface (which
should have bidegree </throwit><throwit>) splits as sixteen beta-planes
(corresponding to the singular planes) and six congruences of
bidegree </throwit><throwit> as above.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Acknowledgements</text></p>
    <p>The last author would like to thank
Jürgen Jost for
inviting her for a three months stay at the Max Planck Institut in den Naturwissenschaften
during the fall of 1998
when a big part of this
paper was written. It was completed during a stay
at the Mathematics Institute of the University of
Bonn supported by the von Humboldt Stiftung.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 15
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Weighted traces on
the algebra of
(classical) P.D.Os</text> <text font="italic">In [KV 1], the authors
introduced a new trace type functional
<throwit> on operators in </throwit><throwit> with order in
</throwit><throwit> where
</throwit><throwit> is some non integer complex
number called the canonical trace. Avoiding
integer orders has to do
with the fact that a positive homogeneous distribution on </throwit><throwit> of
non integer order can be extended in a unique way to a positive
homogeneous distribution on </throwit><throwit> [H].
In this section we first briefly recall the construction of this trace </throwit><throwit> and
some of its properties. We use this trace as a
tool to build linear functionals of
pseudo-differential operators which we call
”weighted traces” and to study some of
their properties. Such functionals were also
considered in [MN] to prove a pseudo-differential
generalization of the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index
theorem. For the sake of
self-containedness, we recall the proof of this
fact. We refer the reader to Appendix A for
notations and basic facts concerning
pseudo-differential operators. </throwit></text>
 <throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">The Kontsevich and Vishik canonical
trace</text>  Let us first describe the general
lines of the construction in a heuristic way. For
a (classical) pseudo-differential operator locally
given by:</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> is the
(locally defined) total symbol (see Appendix A), we
would like to define</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which in general does not make sense
since
<throwit> typically has components of degree </throwit><throwit>. It
however does make sense for an operator of order </throwit><throwit> and
yields the ordinary trace. We should therefore find a way of only
picking up the finite term in such an expression.
 Let us consider a
classical P.D.O </throwit><throwit> of order </throwit><throwit> with
symbol </throwit><throwit> ( see [Sh] for a
discussion about such assumptions on the symbol) where
</throwit><throwit>,

</throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>. Since </throwit><throwit>

</throwit><throwit> is homogeneous of order </throwit><throwit> to express the
last integral. If </throwit><throwit> is an integer then
there is an integer </throwit><throwit>
such that </throwit><throwit> and we have for </throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>

expansion in <throwit> and of a constant (w.r.to </throwit><throwit>) </throwit><throwit> such that</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Because

    <throwit>

</throwit><throwit> for any </throwit><throwit> such that </throwit><throwit>
(see Proposition 3.2 in [KV2]).  </throwit><throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">A fundamental property of the canonical trace</text>  Following Kontsevich and Vishik, we shall call
a local family <throwit> with distribution kernels (locally)
</throwit><text font="italic">weakly holomorphic</text> if the following conditons are satisfied:
 (i) The order <throwit> of </throwit><throwit> is (locally) holomorphic in </throwit><throwit>,
 (ii)The kernel
</throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit> is (locally) holomorphic in </throwit><throwit>
for </throwit><throwit> in disjoint local charts,

the homogeneous components </throwit><throwit> of the symbol </throwit><throwit> are (locally) holomorphic
functions in
</throwit><throwit> on the restriction to </throwit><throwit> of the cotangent sphere bundle </throwit><throwit>.

</throwit><throwit> for some </throwit><throwit> increasing with </throwit><throwit> tends to a (locally)
holomorphic kernel on </throwit><throwit> when </throwit><throwit>.
 In (iii) the topology on the space of symbols is given by the
supremium norm of the symbol and its derivatives and in (iv) the convergence is to be understood in the
sense of weak convergence of distributions [KV1].</throwit></p>

<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">2. The Radul cocycle as a coboundary of
the weighted trace</text> <text font="italic">In this section we investigate the coboundary of
the weighted traces introduced
above. We show how the cocycles obtained in this way relate to the
Radul cocycle which arises in
geometric quantization [M2]. In the context of
regularized determinants, it
is related to the multiplicative anomaly [D].
This cocycle was already investigated in [MN]
where the authors express
the coboundary of weighted traces in terms of a
Wodzicki residue (see [MN] Lemma 13). </text>  We shall need some definitions of Lie algebra cohomology (see e.g. [M1] ).
 <throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">Lie algebra cohomology:</text> Let <throwit> be a Lie
algebra and </throwit><throwit> an </throwit><throwit>-module (the action of </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit> is denoted by a ”dot”).
A </throwit><text font="italic">cochain of degree n</text> ( or <text font="italic">n-cochain</text>) with values in <throwit>
is an antisymmetric multilinear map
</throwit><throwit> (n times) </throwit><throwit>. Let </throwit><throwit> denote
the space of all </throwit><throwit>-cochains and let us define the coboundary operator:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>Taking <throwit> with the trivial zero action of </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
for any </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> we have :</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>In particular <throwit> . An </throwit><text font="italic">n-cocycle</text> is a
cochain of degree <throwit>
with vanishing coboundary. Let us
denote by </throwit><throwit> the set of </throwit><throwit>-coboundaries, by
</throwit><throwit> the set of </throwit><throwit> cocycles and let us call </throwit><throwit>
the </throwit><throwit>-th cohomology space.
 </throwit><throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">The weighted Radul cocycle on
<throwit /></text> We now apply this construction to <throwit> and the </throwit><throwit>-cochain
given by a weighted trace.

</throwit><throwit> do not satisfy the cyclicity property

    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which we call the <throwit>-weighted Radul cocycle. This terminology is justified
on the grounds of

expression of the classical Radul cocycle.

a weighted trace from being tracial
in terms of a Wodzicki residue, which is a trace of purely infinite
dimensional type.</text>

obtained for </throwit><throwit> [CFNW] (see formula (24)),[M2],
[R] (see formula (41)), [KK] (see formula (1)).
In this particular case, the Radul cocycle
was also considered in [KV2] in
relation to multiplicative anomalies for determinants of elliptic
operators (see also [D]) but it was later
considered for more general operators </throwit><throwit> in [MN]
and proved (see Lemma 13) to be a coboundary in
the Hochschild cohomology of pseudo-differential
operators. As a consequence of the above
proposition,
the weighted Radul cocycle vanishes on the algebra of odd-class P.D.Os with
integer order whenever the underlying manifold is odd dimensional.

<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">5. Geometry on weighted bundles</text>
 <throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">Weighted vector bundles</text>

in the class
</throwit><throwit> whenever there is a
compact boundaryless compact smooth Riemannian
manifold </throwit><throwit>,
a finite rank smooth vector bundle </throwit><throwit> based on </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> such that
</throwit><throwit>.

the Lie
algebra
</throwit><throwit> of the Hilbert current group </throwit><throwit>
lies in </throwit><throwit>.

</throwit><throwit> be the class of Hilbert vector bundles </throwit><throwit>

(possibly infinite dimensional) manifold </throwit><throwit>
with fibres modelled

Para index in docroot: 10
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction</text>
The last two years have seen a tremendous increase in our understanding of
chiral fermions on the lattice (see <throwit> for reviews of
recent developments). It has
been understood that the anti-commutator characterizing the chiral symmetry
in the continuum has to be replaced by the Ginsparg-Wilson equation
</throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for the lattice Dirac operator <throwit>. Based on this relation, chiral symmetry
can be defined on the lattice and at least for abelian fields chiral gauge
theories can be formulated on the lattice </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 37
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p28">
    <p><text font="bold">Summary</text>
In this letter we have explored a new approach to Ginsparg-Wilson fermions
and tested the new method in 2-d.
To keep the paper self consistent the construction of the Dirac
operator was also given in 2-d, but the generalization to 4-d is
straightforward and will be presented elsewhere <throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002455.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">MOLECULAR DYNAMICS STUDY OF THE</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">GLASS TRANSITION IN CONFINED WATER</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para align="right" xml:id="p5">
    <p class="ltx_parbox" vattach="top" width="469.5pt"><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract.<text font="medium">
A molecular dynamics simulation of SPC/E water confined in a
Silica pore is presented. The pore has been constructed to
reproduce the average properties of a pore of Vycor glass.
Due to the confinement and to the
presence of a strong hydrophilic surface,
the dynamic behaviour of the liquid appears to be
strongly dependent on the hydration level.
The approach to the glass transition of confined water
is investigated on lowering hydration and
on supercooling in the framework of Mode Coupling Theories.
At higher hydrations two quite distinct subsets
of water molecules are detectable. Those belonging to the first
layer close to the substrate suffer a severe slowing down,
while the remaining ones display a scenario typical of
supercooled liquids approaching the kinetic glass transition.</text></text></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p25">

Para index in docroot: 29
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Table 1:</text><text fontsize="90%">M/IIA/F–theory on Calabi–Yau four–fold </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 53
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">I<throwit>II</throwit></text>:
In going to domain <text font="typewriter">II</text> one crosses the
line <throwit> and since there was no connecting between 1 and 3 to start with
these two roots gets connected by a BPS solution. The number of BPS states
in </throwit><text font="typewriter">II</text> is then 4 and the connectivity is of type D.
<text font="bold">II<throwit>III</throwit></text>:
In going to domain <text font="typewriter">III</text> one crosses the line <throwit> and since
there was no connecting between 2 and 3 to start with
these two roots gets connected by a BPS solution. The number of BPS states
in </throwit><text font="typewriter">III</text> is then 5 and the connectivity is of type E.
<text font="bold">III<throwit>IV</throwit></text>:
In going to domain <text font="typewriter">IV</text> one crosses the line <throwit> and since
there was no connecting between 1 and 2 to start with 1
and 2 to will be connected such that all roots are connected and the number
of BPS states is 6. The connectivity is of type F.
</throwit><text font="bold">IV<throwit>V</throwit></text>:
In going to domain <text font="typewriter">V</text> one crosses the line <throwit> and since
there was a connecting between 3 and 4 to start with, this domain wall
disappears and instead 1 and 2 is connected. The connectivity is then of
type E with 5 possible domain walls.
</throwit><text font="bold">V<throwit>VI</throwit></text>:
In going to domain <text font="typewriter">VI</text> one crosses the line <throwit> and since
there was a connecting between 1 and 4 to start with, this domain wall
disappears. The connectivity is then of type D with 4 possible BPS states.
By </throwit><throwit>-symmetry this analysis determines the possible number of BPS
states in all domains and hence we have a complete determination of the
possible domain walls and junctions for a potential with this particular
symmetry. For this class of superpotentials, the number of BPS states
varies from three to six.</throwit></p>
  </para>

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">High Reproduction Rate versus Sexual Fidelity</text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002145.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>A deSitter brane-world bounding regions of anti-deSitter space
has a macroscopic entropy given by one-quarter the area of the
observer horizon. A proposed variant of the AdS/CFT correspondence
gives a dual description of this cosmology as conformal field theory
coupled to gravity in deSitter space. In the case of two-dimensional
deSitter space
this provides a microscopic
derivation of the entropy, including the one-quarter, as
quantum entanglement of the conformal field theory across the horizon.</p>
  </para>

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Fluctuations and entropy driven space–time</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">intermittency in Navier–Stokes fluids.</text></p>

    <p class="ltx_align_center">P.le Moro 2, 00185 Roma, Italia</p>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract: </text><text font="italic">We analyze the physical meaning of fluctuations
of the phase space contraction rate, that we also call entropy
creation rate, and its observability in space–time intermittency
phenomena. For concreteness we consider a Navier–Stokes fluid.</text></p>
  </para>

  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Chaotic hypothesis: </text><text font="italic">Asymptotic motions of a turbulent flow
develop on an attracting set <throwit> in phase space on which time
evolution </throwit><throwit> can be regarded as a transitive Anosov
system for the purposes of computing time averages in stationary
states.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002186.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Abstract</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">We analyze further the IR singularities that appear in noncommutative
field theories on <throwit>. We argue that all IR singularities in
nonplanar one loop diagrams may be interpreted as arising from the
tree level exchanges of new light degrees of freedom, one coupling to each relevant operator. These exchanges are reminiscent of
closed string exchanges in the double twist diagrams in open string
theory. Some of these degrees of freedom are required to have propagators that are inverse linear or logarithmic. We suggest that these can be interpreted as free propagators in one or two extra dimensions respectively. We also calculate some of the IR singular terms appearing at two loops in noncommutative scalar field theories and find a complicated momentum dependence which is more difficult to interpret.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Fig. 1: </text> Planar and nonplanar contributions to the one loop quadratic

cutoff.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> An arbitrary bipartite entangled pure state <throwit> that Alice and Bob share can be written as </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>and </throwit><throwit> are local unitary transformations
by Alice and Bob respectively, </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) form an orthogonal basis for system </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>). In this letter,

entangled pure state involves local operations of respective system and

    <p><text font="bold">Theorem 2</text>: A set of <throwit>-dimensional entangled pure states </throwit><throwit> can be probabilistic transformed to </throwit><throwit>-dimensional-subspace
equivalent states </throwit><throwit> by same LQCC protocol if and only if
they share same marginal density operators for Alice’s or Bob’s subsystem.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 24
<para xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">Theorem 2</text> shows that the sufficient condition in <text font="bold">Theorem 1</text> is
also necessary in a special case. The result means that Alice (Bob) cannot
probabilistically transform <throwit>-dimensional entangled states that are
different in her (his) local observation to </throwit><throwit>-dimensional-subspace
equivalent states. Generally the ordered Schmidt coefficients of the states
to be transformed must be the same, but these states need not be the same,
there exist unitary transformations on both Alice’s and Bob’s sides. While
arbitrary on Bob’s (Alice’s) side, the unitary operators on Alice’s (Bob’s)
side must preserve the density matrix </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>), which means
that only when there exist some coefficients satisfying </throwit><throwit>, the unitary operators </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) can be non-unit.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Proposition 1</text>: Different <throwit>-dimensional entangled states cannot be
transformed to one </throwit><throwit>-dimensional entangled state by same LQCC protocol on
individual pairs.</throwit></p>
  </para>

to a </throwit><throwit>-dimensional maximally entangled state by LQCC on individual pairs.</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0001105.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Quantum Anti-Cloning</text></p>
    <p>[15mm]</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">David D. Song<throwit> and
Lucien Hardy</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[8mm]
<text font="italic">Centre for Quantum Computation</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">[0pt]
Clarendon Laboratory, University of Oxford</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">[0pt]
Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PU, U.K.</text></p>
    <p><text font="smallcaps">Abstract</text></p>
    <inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="426.8pt">
      <para xml:id="p2.p1">
        <p>We derive the transformation for the optimal universal quantum anti-cloner which
produces two anti-parallel outputs for
a single input state. The fidelity is shown to be 2/3 which is same as the measurement fidelity.
We consider a probabilistic quantum anti-cloner and show quantum states can be anti-cloned
exactly with non-zero probability and its efficiency is higher than the efficiency of distinguishing
between the two states.</p>
        <throwit>
      </throwit></para>
    </inline-para>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para align="center" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Abstract</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">KEY WORDS:</text> Hierarchical Basis, Sparse Grids,
Machine Learning, High Performance Computing, Sparsification of
Covariance Matrices, Random Projection Trees, Fast Multipole Method</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00374.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction:</text> The band insulating state of many fermions has received renewed attention in recent times<throwit>. Clues that the band insulating state may support additional nontrivial physics – attributed to topology – was provided by the discovery of the integer quantum Hall effect</throwit><throwit> and the theoretical work that followed</throwit><throwit>. These ideas saw a resurgence with the discovery of the two dimensional spin Hall insulator</throwit><throwit>, soon followed</throwit><throwit> by the three dimensional topological insulator (see </throwit><throwit>).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Model:</text> We consider a region(box) of <throwit>-dimensional space whose volume is </throwit><throwit>. Our random lattice is constructed by placing </throwit><throwit> sites (labeled by </throwit><throwit>) randomly in the box (see Fig. </throwit><throwit>). The positions of the sites are sampled from an uncorrelated uniform distribution. The collection of points is characterized by a single parameter, viz.,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Two dimensional systems:</text> We begin the discussion of our results with two dimensional systems. As is known there are five symmetry classes (A, AII, D, DIII and C) that allow topological phases to exist in two dimensions. We construct Hamiltonians for each of these classes that respect all the relevant symmetries, as shown in Table. <throwit>. We have performed analysis of systems in all these five classes, and discuss the results of class A in detail as a representative.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 25
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">Three dimensional system:</text> Given the vast interest enjoyed by the three dimensional topological insulator (a system with a <throwit> invariant), we also investigate the possibility of realizing this in a random lattice. To this end, we consider a system with four orbitals (</throwit><throwit>) with a Hamiltonian described by </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit> is the mass parameter, and</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>This system has the required time reversal symmetry. For an appropriate set of parameters (<throwit> and </throwit><throwit>), we find indeed that there are mid-gap states in an open system whose wavefunctions are localized on the boundary (see Fig. </throwit><throwit>). This clearly indicates the new possibilities for creating topological phases in three dimensions.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p14">
    <p><text font="bold">Perspective:</text> The possibility of topological phases in a completely random system opens up several avenues both from experimental and theoretical perspectives. Our results suggest some new routes to the laboratory realization of topological phases. First, two dimensional systems can be made by choosing an insulating surface on which suitable “motifs” (atoms/molecules) with appropriate orbitals are deposited at random (note that this process will require far less control than conventional layered materials). The electronic states of these motifs will then hybridize to produce the required topological phase. Second is the possibility of creating three dimensional systems starting from a suitable large band gap trivial insulator. The idea then is to place “impurity atoms”, again with suitable orbitals and “friendly” chemistry with the host, not unlike the process of <throwit>-doping of phosphorus in silicon</throwit><throwit>. The hybridization of the impurity orbitals would again produce a topological insulating state in the impurity bands under favorable conditions. Here we do not thoroughly explore the specific material system that will realize these ideas. In realistic systems the temperature scales over which one will see the topological physics (determined by the bandwidth and band gap) may be low. Nevertheless, we believe that our results will motivate materials science experts to address these challenges. Finally, our work also suggests that a completely amorphous system can be a topological insulator, clearly providing new opportunities to search for “glassy” insulator with spin-orbit coupled motifs to realize topological phases.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">Acknowledgments:</text> AA thanks CSIR, India, for support and VBS acknowledges a research grant from SERB, DST, India. The authors thank Arijit Haldar and Aabhaas Mallik for comments on the manuscript.</p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="180%">Nuclear Collisions</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>S.M.H. Wong</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic">School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis,</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">Minnesota 55455, U.S.A.<throwit /></text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001294.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Avalanches of popping bubbles</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">in collapsing foams</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">N.Vandewalle<throwit>, J.F.Lentz</throwit><throwit>, S.Dorbolo</throwit><throwit> and
F.Brisbois</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Cellular structures are very common in nature <throwit>.
Each cell of the cellular structure can be a bubble in a beer, a biological cell in a tissue </throwit><throwit>, a grain in a polycrystal </throwit><throwit> or a magnetic domain in a solid </throwit><throwit>. Foams have becomed paradigms of disordered cellular systems. Among the physical properties of interest, one is the long-term behaviour of a froth driven by topological rearrangements. In the present work, we report acoustic experiments on foam systems. We have recorded the sound emitted by crackling cells during the collapsing of foams. The sound pattern is then analyzed using classical methods of statistical physics. Fundamental processes at the surface of the collapsing foam are found. In particular, size is not a relevant parameter for exploding bubbles.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=astro-ph0002179.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Highly polarized structures in the near-nuclear regions
of Cygnus A: intrinsic anisotropy within the cones?</text>
<text font="bold">C.N. Tadhunter<throwit>, W. Sparks</throwit><throwit>, D.J. Axon</throwit><throwit>, L. Bergeron</throwit><throwit>,
N.J. Jackson</throwit><throwit>, C. Packham</throwit><throwit>, J.H. Hough</throwit><throwit>, A. Robinson</throwit><throwit>,
S. Young</throwit><throwit /></text>
<throwit /><text fontsize="90%">Department of Physics, University of Sheffield, Sheffield S3 7RH, UK <throwit /><throwit>Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore,
MD 21218, USA </throwit><throwit /><throwit>Division of Physics and Astronomy, Department of Physical Sciences,
University of Hertfordshire, College Lane, Hatfield, Herts AL10 9AB, UK </throwit><throwit /><throwit>Nuffield Radio Astronomy Laboratory, Jodrell Bank, University
of Manchester, UK </throwit><throwit /><throwit>Isaac Newton Group, Sea Level Office, Apartado de Correos,
321, 38780 Santa Cruz de La Palma, Islas Canarias, Spain</throwit></text>
<text font="bold">Abstract.</text>
We present near-IR imaging polarimetry observations of the nucleus of Cygnus A,
taken with the NICMOS camera of the HST at a wavelength of 2.0<throwit>m.
These maps reveal a highly collimated region of polarized emission
straddling the nucleus and extending to a radius of 1.2 arcseconds. Remarkably,
this feature coincides with one, but only one, limb of the edge-brightened
bicone structure seen in the total intensity image. The
high degree (</throwit><throwit>%) and orientation of the extended polarization feature are
consistent with a scattering origin. Most plausibly,
the detection of polarization along only one limb of the bicone is a consequence
of </throwit><text font="italic">intrinsic anisotropy</text> of the near-IR continuum within the radiation cones, with the direction of maximum intensity of the near-IR radiation field
significantly displaced from the direction of the radio axis.
The unresolved nuclear core source
is also highly polarized (<throwit>%), with a position
angle close to the perpendicular
to the radio axis. Given that this high degree
of nuclear polarization can only be explained
in terms of dichroic extinction if the dichroic mechanism is
unusually efficient in Cygnus A, it is more likely that the nuclear
polarization is due to the scattering of nuclear light in an unresolved
scattering region close to the AGN. In this case, the flux of the core
source in the K-band is dominated by scattered rather than transmitted quasar light, and
previous extinction estimates based on K-band photometry of the core
substantially underestimate the true nuclear extinction.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001218.xml

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">BFV–BRST analysis of equivalence between
noncommutative and ordinary gauge theories</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="80%">Ömer F. DAYI</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">Physics Department, Faculty of Science and
Letters, Istanbul Technical University,
80626 Maslak, Istanbul, Turkey</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">and</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">Feza Gürsey Institute,
P.O.Box 6, 81220
Çengelköy, Istanbul, Turkey. <throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002269.xml
Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">Acknowledgements<throwit /></text>This work has been supported in part by the NRF (South Africa), and by
FONDECYT (Chile) under contracts Nos. 1980577 and 7980011. <throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00157.xml
Para index in docroot: 15
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">We study the spin vortices and skyrmions
coherently imprinted into an exciton-polariton condensate on a planar
semiconductor microcavity. We demonstrate that the presence of
a polarization anisotropy can induce a complex dynamics of these structured topologies,
leading to the twist of their circuitation on the Poincaré
sphere of polarizations. The theoretical description of the results carries the
concept of generalized quantum vortices in two-component superfluids, which
are conformal with polarization loops around an arbitrary
axis in the pseudospin space.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Setting up skyrmions and spin vortices<throwit /></text>
Advanced phase-shaping was recently obtained by means of anisotropic
and inhomogeneous liquid-crystal devices called
<throwit>-plates </throwit><throwit>, which allows an extensive
investigation of optical vorticity
and of full- and half-quantum vortex dynamics in polariton
condensates </throwit><throwit>.
Phase-shaping is applied to an initial Laguerre-Gauss </throwit><throwit>
laser pulse (4 ps duration and 0.5 nm bandwidth) by sending it
across the </throwit><throwit>-plate carrying unitary topological charge.
The </throwit><throwit> is hence partially or completely transformed into a unitary
winding state breaking the chiral symmetry between the two spin
populations. Upon proper setting of the incoming/outgoing polarization
and tuning of the </throwit><throwit>-plate, we can prepare the specific combination
and resultant field pattern (see </throwit><throwit>
for experimental details).
Indeed, each skyrmion and spin
vortex shown here can be thought as a composite state resulting from
the specific superposition of two </throwit><throwit> beams with integer
phase winding (</throwit><throwit>), one in each of the two spin
components.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 29
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">Twist of the vortex polarization field<throwit /></text>
The variation of the <throwit> parameters in real-space for the
hyperspin polarization vortex is presented in the first row of
Fig. 2 (</throwit><text font="italic">A-C</text>). These plots relate to the emission from the
polariton condensate at the initial time (after the laser pulse has
arrived), and the degrees of polarizations are clearly mapped also in
the regions of weak or null intensity, such as in the centre of a
vortex. The twofold symmetry (<throwit> symmetry) of the </throwit><throwit> (Fig. 2</throwit><text font="italic">A</text>)
and <throwit> (Fig. 2</throwit><text font="italic">B</text>) results in a petal shape of the polarization
distribution, while <throwit> is approximately zero over all space as expected. The
presence of a very small component in the </throwit><throwit> can be attributed to
the </throwit><throwit>-plate device, which cannot be simultaneously tuned at all the
wavelengths composing the pulsed beam. However, the circular degree of
polarization is far weaker than the linear components of the </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> parameters.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 35
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">Theory models and discussion<throwit /></text>
In order to understand the physical origins of our observations, we
perform numerical modelling of the system’s dynamics using
two-component open-dissipative Gross-Pitaevskii equations, which
describe the microcavity photon field and the quantum
well exciton field coupled to each other.
The excitonic coupling between differently polarized populations
is usually represented by the inter-spin nonlinearity term <throwit>,
although here we are interested in the linear regime.
Fundamental to the present work are
the terms directly acting on the photonic fields
(see </throwit><throwit> for the model details),
as discussed in the following.
The photonic coupling between different polarizations is given by the
finite-</throwit><throwit> TE-TM splitting term </throwit><throwit> and the </throwit><throwit>-independent
anisotropy splitting </throwit><throwit>. The former appears due to the
difference of transverse-electric and transverse-magnetic masses of
microcavity modes </throwit><throwit>, while the
</throwit><throwit>-independent splitting </throwit><throwit> between linearly polarized modes
can be present in some samples due to strain
effects </throwit><throwit> and
heavy-light hole mixing </throwit><throwit> on the
quantum well interfaces. In such cases two linearly polarized waves
with specific polarization directions (say, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>), are subject
to a slight different energy shift, regardless of the direction and
of their wavevector. Hence, also the </throwit><throwit> state can be subject
to a dephasing between the two linear components, and as a result
there could be a precession of an initial polarization state
(different from the linear </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> ones) at each point in space.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 39
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">Conclusions and Perspectives<throwit /></text>
In summary, the dephasing of <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> linear polarization
components, leads to a transformation of the diagonal-antidiagonal
degree of polarization into a circular spin degree, for both spin vortices and
skyrmions. By comparing with the experiments, we deduce that the
axis of the </throwit><throwit> splitting anisotropy in our experimental
configurations are oriented along the diagonal and antidiagonal
directions. The twist speed induced by the </throwit><throwit> term in the
simulations is the same for all four considered states. The perfectly
linear trend in time (starting from </throwit><throwit>, that is when the
fluid is left free to evolve after the arrival of the exciting pulse)
shown in Fig. 4</throwit><text font="italic">O</text> demonstrates the effect to be independent of the
instantaneous density of polaritons, which decay according to the
<throwit>.
On the other hand the strength of the twist is directly proportional to the anisotropy value,
as demonstrated by looking at the slopes of the </throwit><throwit> curves
in Fig. 4</throwit><text font="italic">O</text> corresponding to different <throwit>.
We can evaluate a theoretical twist speed of </throwit><throwit>.
Noticeably here (for the skyrmions), we also
observe an interesting evolution of the </throwit><throwit> pattern in real space
(Fig. 4</throwit><text font="italic">J</text>). There is a sort of rotation of the sectors with some
features of spiralling. This additional effect, i.e., the rotations of
the <throwit> sectors in real space, is instead associated to the
action of the finite-</throwit><throwit> TE-TM splitting term </throwit><throwit> in our model </throwit><throwit>. We
would like to stress that our simulations clearly confirm that it is
the </throwit><throwit> anisotropy, which is the cause for the polarization twisting of
vortex states. On the contrary, the disorder potential term,
produced by the inhomogeneities inside the cavity mirror,
was not needed to
reproduce the observed dynamics.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 41
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">Methods summary<throwit /></text>
<text fontsize="90%">
The experimental polariton device is a typical photonic microcavity (MC)
embedding quantum wells (QW) kept at cryogenic temperature.
A ps laser pulse tuned on the lower polariton branch energy
works as the excitation and reference beams.
Optical vortices and their composition are obtained by
means of a liquid crystal <throwit>-plate device, waveplates and polarizers.
Space-temporal dynamics are retrieved upon implementing
the off-axis digital holography technique on a custom interferometric setup.
The modelling of the system
is based on coupled two-component
open-dissipative Gross-Pitaevskii equations for the MC photons and QW excitons.
Dynamical simulations of the equations are implemented
on the XMDS2 software framework </throwit><throwit>.
For experimental and theoretical details
see refs. </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit>.</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 48
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p25">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Twist of generalized skyrmions and spin vortices in a polariton superfluid<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 49
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p26">
    <p><text font="bold">SI Text<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 50
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p27">
    <p><text font="bold">Experimental methods.</text>
The experimental polariton device is an AlGaAs 2<throwit> microcavity
with three 8 nm In</throwit><throwit>Ga</throwit><throwit>As quantum wells. All the
experiments shown here are performed at a temperature of 10 K in a
region of the sample clean from defects. The excitation beam is a
4.0 ps Gaussian laser pulse with a repetition rate of 80 MHz
selectively tuned on the lower polariton branch energy. Its intensity
is adjusted so that to keep the resonantly excited fluid in a
linear regime during the whole dynamics. In order to obtain the four
different initial topological patterns (as reported in the table of
Fig. 1</throwit><text font="italic">M</text>) we used a combination of impinging polarization, electrical
tuning of the <throwit>-plate and waveplates as described below. In the
case of the spin vortices the pulse is linearly polarized and the
tuning of the </throwit><throwit>-plate is complete (100%). This allows to directly
obtain a hedgehog pattern at the exit. Upon insertion of a
half-wave plate (HWP) after the </throwit><throwit>-plate, we locally rotate the
linear vectors of such pattern, obtaining the hyperspin topology. In
the case of the skyrmion, we send the pulse with a circular
polarization onto the </throwit><throwit>-plate which is now partially tuned (50%).
This results in an outcoming lemon skyrmion, which can be rotated by means
of an HWP into its conjugated state, the star skyrmion.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 53
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p30">
    <p><text font="bold">Theory models.</text>
In order to understand the physical origins of our observations, we
perform numerical modelling of the system’s dynamics using
two-component open-dissipative Gross-Pitaevskii equations, which
describe the microcavity photon field <throwit> and the quantum
well exciton field </throwit><throwit> coupled to each other:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 57
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p34">
    <p><text font="bold">Computational methods.</text>
The dynamics of equation S1 is simulated using the XMDS2 software
framework (40). We employed adaptive step-size algorithm based on
fourth and fifth order “embedded Runge-Kutta” (ARK45) method with
periodic boundary conditions. This algorithm was also tested against
eighth and ninth order (ARK89) of “embedded Runge-Kutta” method.
The periodic boundary condition is an artefact of using FFT in order to efficiently
switch between the real space to compute the potential energy and the momentum space to evaluate the kinetic energy.
This method ensures very fast computation of each time step.
In order to ensure that all flux leaving the system is not coming back
from the other side due to the periodic boundary conditions, we
implemented additional circular/ring absorbing boundary conditions,
with the depth and the width carefully adjusted to the geometry of
current experiments. We solve the equations on a 2D finite grid of <throwit> points and lattice spacing </throwit><throwit>
in a box of </throwit><throwit>.
The large size of the simulation box ensures that polariton
density drops practically to zero at the boundary. However, in all the maps
we plot the physically relevant central region only, where the
density of polaritons is still significant.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 58
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p35">
    <p><text font="bold">SI Movies</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001045.xml
Para index in docroot: 30
<para xml:id="p26">
    <p><text font="bold">2) Possible Anderson localization effect due to the one
dimensional stripes<throwit /></text>At sufficiently low temperatures One dimensional conductors exhibit Anderson
localization. Since we may wish to perform the experiments at low
temperatures one may wonder if this can effect the striped
plate conductivity and hence the proposed experiment.
To show
that these difficulties do not affect the proposed experiment we invoke
again the discussion above of the relevant <throwit> configuration
contributing to the casimir effect. In terms of the Fourier
transform variables these are </throwit><throwit> with </throwit><throwit>.
Hence we do not
need the stripes to be conducting along the full length L of the
macroscopic sample. Rather it suffices that the stripes will be
good conductors along distances </throwit><throwit> of order several times </throwit><throwit>.
Since the distance between stripes </throwit><throwit> and the width of individual
stripes </throwit><throwit> and thickness </throwit><throwit> are also of order </throwit><throwit>
(or rather smaller by a factor of 10 -100 ) the required
conductivity of the stripes is practically guarenteed.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 31
<para xml:id="p27">
    <p><text font="bold">3)Possible effects from changing overlap of stripes
(or other pattern).</text>
A basic requirement in our proposed set-up
is that the separation between the plates <throwit> be larger than the
separation/width of the stripes. In this case the modes relevant for
the Casimir effect of wavelength </throwit><throwit> cannot resolve individual
stripes. Hence </throwit><throwit> will not depend in this case on the relative
positioning of the stripes in the two plates but only on
the angle between their directions </throwit><throwit>, which is exactly the effect of
interest. The decreasing (in absolute value) of </throwit><throwit>
with </throwit><throwit>
and the resulting tendency of the plates to align their stripes
(or whatever other common pattern of conducting patches exist on them),
is a generic feature existing also when, </throwit><throwit>, the characteristic stripe
(patch) size is larger than </throwit><throwit>. The new angle </throwit><throwit> dependence follows from the
fact that in this limit the total casimir energy is proportional
to the total overlap area </throwit><throwit> with </throwit><throwit> the
complete plate area, f the fraction of conducting stripes/patches on
each conductor and g is the the” overlap factor”. If the patterns
on both plates are identical (so that for </throwit><throwit> ,
say, </throwit><throwit>) the overlap factor decreases with increasing </throwit><throwit>
and so should </throwit><throwit>
for </throwit><throwit>. It is amusing to note that the change of </throwit><throwit>
in this case is qualitatively different from that in the </throwit><throwit> the case of
interest here, where as indicated in fig. </throwit><throwit> varies
smoothly as </throwit><throwit>,the angle between the directions of conductivity
changes from </throwit><throwit> to </throwit><throwit>.</throwit><throwit>As one can readily verify the overlap of identical
elements of size </throwit><throwit> (and also stripes of seperation and width of
order </throwit><throwit>) varies dramatically: decreasing
from </throwit><throwit> to its minimal value once </throwit><throwit> .
In passing we note that this dramatic sensitivity </throwit><throwit> could conceivably
be utilized for yet another measurement of the ordinary Casimir effect.
The resulting torque in this case is </throwit><throwit> and is compareable to the torques manifesting in the torqe ballance meassurements of the ordinary Casimir effect.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">We present data collected with the HERA–B wire target which prove the
existence of coasting beam at the HERA proton storage ring. The
coasting beam is inherently produced by the proton machine operation
and is not dominated by target effects.</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 18
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">The Relation to NS5 branes</text>
<throwit>An important special case is when </throwit><throwit> has a </throwit><throwit> isometry
(acting holomorphicly), and the space </throwit><throwit> of fixed points of this
isometry is a (complex) sub-manifold of co-dimension </throwit><throwit>.
Performing T-duality along the </throwit><throwit> isometry, one obtains </throwit><throwit>
a configuration with an NS5 brane wrapped on </throwit><throwit>.

Therefore, in this case, the </throwit><throwit>-dimensional theory defined above describes
the decoupled dynamics of this NS5 brane.
The simplest such case is a configuration of parallel KK monopoles.
The transverse space (multi Taub-NUT space; </throwit><throwit>) has a </throwit><throwit> isometry,
with fixed points at the location of the monopoles.
T-duality along this isometry replaces each KK monopole by an NS5 brane
at the same location
</throwit><throwit /><throwit /><throwit> (see also </throwit><throwit>).
When the NS5 branes coincide, one indeed expects, in the </throwit><throwit> limit,
a non-trivial dynamics on these branes </throwit><throwit> (see also
</throwit><throwit /><throwit /><throwit>).
This is because they are dual to decoupled D5 branes, where one obtains,
at low energy, a gauge theory with a non-vanishing gauge coupling.</throwit></p>
  </para>
