Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Local Equivalence of Sacksteder and Bourgain Hypersurfaces</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract.<text font="medium">
Finding examples of tangentially degenerate submanifolds
(submanifolds with degenerate Gauss mappings)
in an Euclidean space <throwit> that are noncylindrical
and without singularities is an important problem of differential
geometry. The first example of such a hypersurface was constructed
by Sacksteder in 1960. In 1995
Wu published an example of a noncylindrical tangentially degenerate algebraic
hypersurface in </throwit><throwit> whose Gauss mapping is of rank 2 and
which is also without singularities.
This example was constructed (but not published) by Bourgain.</throwit></text></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text>
It is important to find examples of tangentially degenerate submanifolds
in order to understand the theory of such manifolds.
These examples prove the existence of tangentially degenerate
submanifolds and help to illustrate the theory.
The first known example of a tangentially degenerate hypersurface
of rank 2 without singularities in <throwit> was constructed by Sacksteder [S 60].
This example was examined from the differential geometry point of view
by Akivis in [A 87]. In particular, Akivis proved that the Sacksteder
hypersurface has no singularities since they “went to infinity”.
In the same paper, Akivis presented
a series of examples generalizing Sacksteder’s example in </throwit><throwit>,
constructed a new series of examples of three-dimensional hypersurfaces
</throwit><throwit> of rank 2 whose focal surfaces are imaginary, and
proved existence of hypersurfaces of this kind.
Note that more examples of
tangentially degenerate submanifolds without singularities
can be found in [I 98, 99a, 99b]. The examples are essentially
based on classical Cartan’s hypersurfaces (see [Ca 39]).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text> In Cartesian coordinates <throwit> of
the Euclidean space </throwit><throwit>, the equation of
the Bourgain hypersurface </throwit><throwit> is</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>(see [W 95] or [I 98, 99a, 99b]). Equation (1) can be written
in the form</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Make in (2) the following admissible change of Cartesian coordinates:</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Then equation (2) becomes</p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>

<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">3.</text> Let us find singular points of the hypersurface <throwit>.
Such points are defined by the equations
</throwit><throwit>. It follows from (4) that</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>All these derivatives vanish simultaneously if and only if <throwit>. Thus the 2-plane at infinity </throwit><throwit> is the locus of singular points of the hypersurface </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">4.</text>
No one of properties 1–4 characterizes Bourgain’s
hypersurfaces completely: they are necessary but not
sufficient for these hypersurfaces. The following
theorem gives a necessary and sufficient condition
for a hypersurface to be of Bourgain’s type.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Asymptotically spacelike warped anti-de Sitter spacetimes in generalized minimal massive gravity<text font="medium" /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>In this paper we show that warped AdS<throwit> black hole spacetime is a solution of the generalized minimal massive gravity (GMMG) and introduce suitable boundary conditions for asymptotically warped AdS</throwit><throwit> spacetimes. Then we find the Killing vector fields such that transformations generated by them preserve the considered boundary conditions. We calculate the conserved charges which correspond to the obtained Killing vector fields and show that the algebra of the asymptotic conserved charges is given as the semi direct product of the Virasoro algebra with </throwit><throwit> current algebra. We use a particular Sugawara construction to reconstruct the conformal algebra. Thus, we are allowed to use the Cardy formula to calculate the entropy of the warped black hole. We demonstrate that the gravitational entropy of the warped black hole exactly coincide with what we obtain via Cardy’s formula. As we expect the warped Cardy formula also give us exactly the same result which we obtain from usual Cardy’s formula. We calculate mass and angular momentum of the warped black and then check that obtained mass, angular momentum and entropy satisfy first law of the black hole mechanics. According to the results of this paper we belief that the dual theory of the warped AdS</throwit><throwit> black hole solution of GMMG is a Warped CFT.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001324.xml

    <p>[0.3cm]

        <p>The decay distribution of the kinematic variable <throwit> in
inclusive charmless semileptonic decays of </throwit><throwit> mesons is unique.
The novel method for a model-independent determination of
</throwit><throwit> is described.</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002063.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> The field of solar neutrino physics is currently undergoing
a remarkable change. For 30 years the goal was simply to confirm the
deficit of solar neutrinos. The latest experiments, however, such as
Super-Kamiokande, SNO, Borexino, KamLAND, etc, aim to accomplish more
than that. By collecting high statistics real–time data sets on
different components of the solar neutrino spectrum, they hope to
obtain unequivocal proof of neutrino oscillations and measure the
oscillation parameters. With the physics of solar neutrinos
quickly becoming a precision science, it is more
important then ever to ensure that all relevant physical effects are
taken into account and the right parameter set is used.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text> For simplicity, we will only consider here the
two-generation mixing. If neutrino masses are nonzero then, in
general, the mass eigenstates <throwit> are different from
the flavor eigenstates </throwit><throwit>. The relationship between
the two bases is given in terms of the mixing angle </throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>In our convention <throwit> is always the heavier of the two
eigenstates, </throwit><text font="italic">i.e.</text> <throwit>.
Then, as already mentioned, </throwit><throwit>
encompasses all physically different situations.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para xml:id="p15">
    <p><text font="bold">3.</text>
To illustrate the role of matter effects in vacuum
oscillations, we present fits to the total rates of the Homestake
<throwit>, GALLEX </throwit><throwit> and SAGE </throwit><throwit>, and
Super-Kamiokande </throwit><throwit> experiments. We combine experimental rates
and uncertainties for the two gallium experiments and use the latest
available 825-day Super-Kamiokande data set. The experimental results
are conveniently collected and tabulated in </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 27
<para xml:id="p19">
    <p><text font="bold">4.</text> An important question is how well future experiments will be
able to cover vacuum oscillation solutions with <throwit>. In
Fig. </throwit><throwit> we show the sensitivity of the Borexino
experiment to anomalous seasonal variations for the entire physical
range of the mixing angle </throwit><throwit>. This is an extension
of the analysis performed in </throwit><throwit>, where the details of
the procedure are described. The sensitivity region shows a clear
asymmetry as a result of the solar matter effects.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 32
<para xml:id="p23">
    <p><text font="bold">5.</text>
In summary, the preceding examples clearly illustrate the importance
of including the solar matter effects when studying vacuum oscillation
of solar neutrinos with <throwit> eV</throwit><throwit>. Because
to describe such effects one has to use the full range of the mixing
angle </throwit><throwit>, future fits to the data should be
extended to </throwit><throwit>. This seems especially important in light
of the latest analyses </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>,
which in addition to the total rates also use the information on the
neutrino spectrum and time variations at Super-Kamiokande. In this
case the allowed vacuum oscillation regions are mostly located in the
</throwit><throwit> eV</throwit><throwit> region
</throwit><throwit>, precisely where the matter effects
are relevant. (The best fit to the Super-Kamiokande electron recoil
spectrum is achieved for </throwit><throwit> eV</throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>.) It would be very desirable to
repeat these analyses with the solar matter effects included.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00389.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract </text> This paper develops an approach to the evaluation of quadratic Euler sums that involve harmonic numbers. The approach is based on simple integral computations of polylogarithms.
By using the approach, we establish some relations between quadratic Euler sums and linear sums. Furthermore, we
obtain some closed form representations of quadratic sums in terms of zeta values and linear sums. The given representations are new.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">Keywords</text> Harmonic numbers; polylogarithm function; Euler sum; Riemann zeta function.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">AMS Subject Classifications (2010):</text> 11M06; 11M32; 33B15</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.01266.xml
Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract. –</text> The Poynting theorem is used to obtain an expression for the turbulent power-spectral density as function of frequency and wavenumber in low-frequency magnetic turbulence. No reference is made to Elsasser variables as is usually done in magnetohydrodynamic turbulence mixing mechanical and electromagnetic turbulence. We rather stay with an implicit form of the mechanical part of turbulence as suggested by electromagnetic theory in arbitrary media. All of mechanics and flows is included into a turbulent response function which by appropriate observations can be determined from knowledge of the turbulent fluctuation spectra. This approach is not guided by the wish of developing a complete theory of turbulence. It aims on the identification of the response function from observations as input into a theory which afterwards attempts its interpretation. Combination of both the magnetic and electric power spectral densities leads to a representation of the turbulent response function, i.e. the turbulent conductivity spectrum <throwit> as function of frequency </throwit><throwit> and wavenumber </throwit><throwit>. It is given as the ratio of magnetic to electric power spectral densities in frequency and wavenumber space. This knowledge allows for formally writing down a turbulent dispersion relation. Power law inertial range spectra result in a power law turbulent conductivity spectrum. These can be compared with observations in the solar wind. Approximations, warnings and caveats are found in the Appendix.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0002119.xml

Para index in docroot: 34
<para xml:id="p27">
    <p><text font="bold">10.</text>
In conclusion, we have found an exact
field theoretic formula
for the second topological moment of two polymers.
Only the
final
integrations over the spatial variables in the
Feynman diagrams of Fig. <throwit> were done approximately.
These were defined on a lattice related to the finite monomer size.
Our Chern-Simons-based theory is free of
the shortcomings
of previous mean-field procedures.
Our formula for </throwit><throwit>
has been applied to the realistic case of long flexible polymers
in a solution. When the polymer lengths become large,
the Feynman integrals in </throwit><throwit>
can be
evaluated
analytically.
In this way we have been able to derive
the result (</throwit><throwit>) for the average square number
of intersections formed by a polymer </throwit><throwit> with all the others.
This calculation is
</throwit><text font="italic">exact</text> in the long-polymer limit.
The corrections
to (<throwit>) are
suppressed by
further inverse square roots of the polymer lengths.</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Drell-Yan proton-deuteron asymmetry<text font="medium" /></text></p>
    <throwit>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Gravity and the Newtonian limit in the Randall–Sundrum model</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
We point out that the gravitational
evolution equations in the Randall–Sundrum model
appear in a different form than hitherto assumed. As
a consequence, the model yields a correct Newtonian limit
in a novel manner.</p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001070.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> <throwit>This review addresses recent developments in
nonequilibrium statistical physics. Focusing on phase transitions
from fluctuating phases into absorbing states, the universality
class of directed percolation is investigated in detail. The
survey gives a general introduction to various lattice models of
directed percolation and studies their scaling properties,
field-theoretic aspects, numerical techniques, as well as possible
experimental realizations. In addition, several examples of
absorbing-state transitions which do not belong to the directed
percolation universality class will be discussed. As a closely
related technique, we investigate the concept of damage spreading.
It is shown that this technique is ambiguous to some extent,
making it impossible to define chaotic and regular phases in
stochastic nonequilibrium systems. Finally, we discuss various
classes of depinning transitions in models for interface growth
which are related to phase transitions into absorbing states.
</throwit><throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Keywords:</text> <throwit /><text fontsize="80%">nonequilibrium phase transitions, stochastic lattice models,
directed percolation, contact process, absorbing state transitions,
parity-conserving class, damage spreading, interface growth,
depinning transitions, roughening transitions,
nonequilibrium wetting</text> <throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">PACS:</text>
<text fontsize="80%">05.70.Ln, 64.60.Ht, 64.60.Ak</text> <throwit>
 </throwit><text fontsize="80%">submitted to <text font="italic">Advances in Physics</text></text> <throwit /></p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Linear Odd Poisson Bracket</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">on Grassmann Algebra</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="90%">Vyacheslav A. Soroka<throwit /></text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="90%">Kharkov Institute of Physics and Technology</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="90%">310108 Kharkov, Ukraine</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">1.<text font="medium"> Recently a linear degenerate odd Poisson bracket built only of
Grassmann variables has been introduced <throwit>. It was constructed for
this bracket, in contrast with the non-degenerate odd bracket having the
only Grassmann-odd nilpotent differential </throwit><throwit>-operator of the second
order, at once three Grassmann-odd nilpotent </throwit><throwit>-like
differential operators of the first, the second and the third orders with
respect to Grassmann derivatives. It was also shown that these
</throwit><throwit>-like operators together with a Grassmann-odd nilpotent Casimir
function of this degenerate odd bracket form a finite-dimensional Lie
superalgebra. Following to </throwit><throwit>, in the present report we extend the
above-mentioned results to the case of an arbitrary linear odd Poisson
bracket, which is also realized solely in terms of the Grassmann variables
and corresponds to a semi-simple Lie group.</throwit></text></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">2.<text font="medium"> There is a well-known linear even Poisson bracket given
in terms of the commuting (Grassmann-even) variables <throwit>
</throwit><throwit /></text></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">where <throwit> are Grassmann-even
</throwit><throwit> constants which, because of the main
properties of the even Poisson bracket:</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">are antisymmetric in the two lower indices</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">and obey the conditions</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">A sum with the symbol <throwit> in (5) means a summation over cyclic
permutations of the quantities </throwit><throwit>. In relations (2)-(6) </throwit><throwit>
are functions of the variables </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> is a Grassmann parity
of the quantity </throwit><throwit>. The linear even bracket (1) plays a very important
role in the theory of Lie groups, Lie algebras, their representations and
applications (see, for example, </throwit><throwit>). The bracket (1) can be
realized in a canonical even Poisson bracket</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">where <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are the right and left derivatives and
</throwit><throwit>, on the following
bilinear functions of coordinates </throwit><throwit> and momenta </throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">if <throwit> satisfy the conditions (7), (8)
for the structure constants of a Lie group.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">3.<text font="medium"> Now let us replace in expression (1) the commuting variables
<throwit> by Grassmann variables </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>.
Then we obtain a binary composition</throwit></text></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">which, due to relations (7) and (8), meets all the properties of the odd

    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>

    </throwit><p><text fontsize="90%">It is surprising enough that the odd bracket can be defined solely

<throwit>. On the following bilinear functions of canonical variables
commuting </throwit><throwit> and Grassmann </throwit><throwit /></text></p>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">4.<text font="medium"> By contracting the indices in a product of the Grassmann
variables with the upper indices
and of the successive Grassmann derivatives,
respectively, with the lower indices
in (8), we obtain the relations</text></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 15

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">5.<text font="medium"> Thus, we see that both the even and odd linear Poisson brackets
are internally inherent in the Lie group with the structure constants

Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Magnetic trapping of neutrons<text font="medium">
</text></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">P. R. Huffman<throwit>,
C. R. Brome</throwit><throwit>,
J. S. Butterworth</throwit><throwit>,
K. J. Coakley</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>M. S. Dewey</throwit><throwit>,
S. N. Dzhosyuk</throwit><throwit>,
R. Golub</throwit><throwit>,
G. L. Greene</throwit><throwit>,
K. Habicht</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>S. K. Lamoreaux</throwit><throwit>,
C. E. H. Mattoni</throwit><throwit>,
D. N. McKinsey</throwit><throwit>,
F. E. Wietfeldt</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>&amp; J. M. Doyle</throwit><throwit>
</throwit></text>


<throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><rule height="1px" width="100%" />  <throwit /><text font="bold">Accurate measurement of the lifetime of the neutron
(which is unstable to beta decay) is important for understanding the
weak nuclear force<throwit> and the creation of matter during the
Big Bang</throwit><throwit>. Previous measurements of the neutron lifetime
have mainly been limited by certain systematic errors; however, these
could in principle be avoided by performing measurements on neutrons
stored in a magnetic trap</throwit><throwit>. Neutral and charged particle
traps are widely used tool for studying both composite and elementary
particles, because they allow long interaction times and isolation
from perturbing environments</throwit><throwit>. Here we report the
magnetic trapping of neutrons. The trapping region is filled with
superfluid </throwit><throwit>He, which is used to load neutrons into the trap and as
a scintillator to detect their decay. Neutrons have a lifetime in the
trap of 750</throwit><throwit> seconds, mainly limited by their
beta decay rather than trap losses. Our experiment verifies
theoretical predictions regarding the loading process and
magnetic trapping of neutrons. Further refinement of this method
should lead to improved precision in the neutron lifetime measurement.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Acknowledgments.</text><text fontsize="80%"> We thank J. M. Rowe,
D. M. Gilliam, G. L. Jones, J. S. Nico, N. Clarkson, G. P. Lamaze,
C. Chin, C. Davis, D. Barkin, A. Black, V. Dinu, J. Higbie, H. Park,
R. Ramakrishnan, I. Siddiqi, and G. Brandenburg for their help with
this project. We thank P. McClintock, D. Meredith and P. Hendry for
supplying the isotopically pure helium. We acknowledge the support of
the NIST, US DOC, in providing the neutron facilities used in this
work. This work is supported in part by the US NSF. The NIST
authors acknowledge the support of the US DOE.</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00778.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction</text> The theory of hypergroups and semihypergroups was introduced by C .Dunkl [1], R. Jewett [2] and R. Spector [3] and is well developed now.<throwit>Many examples of finite commutative semihypergroups and hypergroups we can find in [4]. In [4] there is a precise </throwit><text font="slanted">physical</text> definition of a finite semihypergroup:<throwit /><throwit>
</throwit><text font="slanted">A finite commutative hypergroup is a finite collection of particles, say </text>{<throwit>}</throwit><text font="slanted">, which are allowed to interact by colliding. When two particles collide, they coalesce to form a third particle. The results of collisions are however not definite; if we collide <throwit> with </throwit><throwit> the probability of emerging with the single particle </throwit><throwit> is </throwit><throwit> and is fixed.
</throwit></text>

In the present article we study some finite commutative semihypergroups which can be developed from commutative groups. In terms of the above physical interpretation the main result shows that for such semihypergroups each particle in {<throwit>} is not an elementary particle, but is a combination of some different elementary particles {</throwit><throwit>} and evolution of {</throwit><throwit>} (collision of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>) can be described as a group operation for some group. Each such semihypergroup defines underlying group precisely.</throwit><throwit /><throwit>Let </throwit><throwit> be a finite semihypergroup with </throwit><throwit> states </throwit><throwit> and convolution operation defined by</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> for each </throwit><throwit> is associative</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Let us denote <throwit>columns {</throwit><throwit>} by </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>matrix with columns {</throwit><throwit>} by </throwit><throwit /><throwit>matrix with columns {</throwit><throwit>} by </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>and cube with matrices {</throwit><throwit>} by </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit /><throwit /><text font="bold">Definition</text> A commutative semihypergroup <throwit> will be said to be </throwit><emph font="italic">derived from a group</emph> if the following condition is satisfied<throwit>(A) There are only </throwit><throwit> different columns among all {</throwit><throwit>} and columns in each </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are linearly independent.</throwit><throwit /><throwit>In matrix terms the convolution operation (1) transforms to </throwit><throwit> (where </throwit><throwit> is a column-vector with 1 on </throwit><throwit>-th position and 0 otherwise). The matrix </throwit><throwit> represents a measure </throwit><throwit> so </throwit><throwit> represents </throwit><throwit>. Now it is obvious that the convolution operation (1) is associative if and only if</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Now let us establish some feature all derived from a group semihypergroups are hold:<throwit /><text font="bold">Corollary 1.</text> There are no more than <throwit> different elements in </throwit><throwit> and all columns in </throwit><throwit> contain the same elements.</throwit><throwit>The </throwit><throwit>-th column in </throwit><throwit> is </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>So</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Because {<throwit>} (</throwit><throwit> - fixed) and {</throwit><throwit>} (</throwit><throwit> - fixed) are from the same set of </throwit><throwit> linearly independent columns in </throwit><throwit> we have that columns </throwit><throwit> contain the same elements as the column </throwit><throwit>. Para index in docroot: 1
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">GERBES ON COMPLEX REDUCTIVE LIE GROUPS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract </text>Let <throwit> be a compact Lie group with complexification </throwit><throwit>.
We construct by geometric methods a conjugation invariant gerbe on
</throwit><throwit>; this then gives by restriction an invariant gerbe on </throwit><throwit>.
Our construction works for any choice of level. When
</throwit><throwit> is simple and simply-connected, the level is just an integer as
usual. For general </throwit><throwit>, the level is a bilinear form </throwit><throwit> on a Cartan
subalgebra where </throwit><throwit> satisfies a quantization condition.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Proof.</text> 
The proof is similar to that of Proposition A-1 so we will be brief. One first assumes that all
line bundles
<throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are trivial. Then one can interpret the data
</throwit><throwit> as yielding as giving
a Čech </throwit><throwit>-cocycle with values in the simplicial sheaf </throwit><throwit> on the
simplicial manifold </throwit><throwit>. Then one uses the exponential exact sequence
to compare </throwit><throwit> with </throwit><throwit>. </throwit><rule depth="2.0pt" height="4.0pt" width="3.0pt" /></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0002022.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Superluminal tunneling through two successive barriers</text></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract —</text> We study the phenomenon of one-dimensional
non-resonant tunneling through two successive (opaque) potential barriers,
separated by an intermediate free region <throwit>, by analyzing the relevant
solutions to the Schroedinger equation.  We find that the total traversal
time does </throwit><text font="italic">not</text> depend not only on the barrier widths (the so-called
“Hartman effect”), but also on the <throwit> width: so that the effective
velocity in the region </throwit><throwit>, between the two barriers, can be regarded
as practically infinite.  This agrees with the results known from the
corresponding waveguide experiments, which simulated the tunneling experiment
herein considered due to the known formal identity between the Schroedinger
and the Helmholtz equation.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">1. – Introduction —</text>  It is known within quantum mechanics, with
regard to the tunneling processes, that the tunneling time —either evaluated
as a simple “phase time”[1] or calculated through the analysis of the
wavepacket behaviour[2]— does not depend on the barrier width in the case of
opaque barriers. Such a phenomenon, sometimes called “Hartman effect”[3],
implies Superluminal and arbitrarily large (group) velocities <throwit> inside
long enough barriers[2]. Experiments that may verify this prediction by,
say, electrons are difficult. Luckily enough, however, the Schroedinger
equation in the presence of a potential barrier is mathematically
identical[4] to the Helmholtz equation for an electromagnetic wave
propagating, e.g., down a metallic
waveguide along the </throwit><throwit>-axis: and a barrier height </throwit><throwit> bigger than the
electron energy </throwit><throwit> corresponds (for a given wave frequency) to a waveguide
transverse size smaller than a cut-off value. A segment of </throwit><text font="italic">undersized</text>
guide does therefore behave as a barrier for the wave (photonic barrier): So
that the wave assumes therein —like an electron inside a quantum
barrier— an imaginary momentum or wave-number and gets exponentially damped
along <throwit>, as a consequence. In other words, it becomes an </throwit><text font="italic">evanescent</text>
wave (going back to normal propagation, even if with reduced amplitude,
when the narrowing ends and the guide returns to its initial transverse
size).  Thus, a tunneling experiment can be simulated by having
recourse to evanescent waves (for which the concept of group velocity can be
properly extended[5]).</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">2. – Phase time evaluation —</text>  Let us consider the (quantum-mechanical)
stationary solution for the one-dimensional (1D) tunneling of a
non-relativistic particle, with mass <throwit>
and kinetic energy  </throwit><throwit>,  through two equal
rectangular barriers with height </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) and width </throwit><throwit>,  quantity
</throwit><throwit> being the distance between them.  The Schrödinger equation is</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 33
<para xml:id="p30">
    <p><text font="bold">3. – Discussion —</text>  The tunneling-time independence from the width
(<throwit>) of each one of the two
opaque barriers is itself a generalization of the Hartman effect, and might be
a priori understood —following refs.[4,6]— on the basis of the reshaping
phenomenon which takes place inside a barrier.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 39
<para xml:id="p36">
    <p><text font="bold">Acknowledgements</text></p>
  </para>

St. Peterburg University, project No. 97–6.2–34.</p>

<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">On a Problem of Mahler</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Concerning the
Approximation of Exponentials and Logarithms</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">In 1953 K. Mahler [7] proved that for any sufficiently
large positive integers <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, the estimates</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">hold; here, <throwit> denotes the distance to the
nearest integer: for </throwit><throwit>,</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">In the same paper [7], he remarks:
</text><text font="slanted">“The exponent <throwit> tends to infinity
very slowly; the theorem is thus not excessively weak, the more
so since one can easily show that</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="slanted">for an infinite increasing sequence of positive integers <throwit> and
suitable integers </throwit><throwit>.”</throwit></text><text font="bold" /></p>
  </para>

    <throwit>

Para index in docroot: 11
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Here we propose two generalizations of Mahler’s problem.
One common feature to our two conjectures is that we
replace rational integers by algebraic numbers. However if, for
simplicity, we restrict them to the special case of rational
integers, then they deal with simultaneous approximation of
logarithms of positive integers by rational integers. In higher
dimension, there are two points of view: one takes either a
hyperplane, or else a line. Our first conjecture is concerned
with lower bounds for <throwit>,
which amounts to ask for lower bounds for </throwit><throwit>. We are back to the situation
considered by Mahler in the special case </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>.
Our second conjecture asks for lower bounds for </throwit><throwit>, or equivalently for </throwit><throwit>. Mahler’s problem again corresponds to the
case </throwit><throwit>. In both cases </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
are positive rational integers.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Dealing more generally with algebraic numbers, we need to
introduce a notion of height. Here we use Weil’s absolute
logarithmic height <throwit> (see [5] Chap. IV,
§ 1, as well as [18]), which is related to Mahler’s
measure </throwit><throwit> by</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">and</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">where <throwit> is the minimal polynomial of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
its degree. Another equivalent definition for
</throwit><throwit> is given below (§ 3.3).</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

1 and 2 below: it is an extension of Mahler’s problem where the
rational integers <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are replaced by algebraic numbers
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 22
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Remark 1.</text><text fontsize="90%"> Thanks to A.O. Gel’fond, A. Baker and others,
a number of results have already been given in the direction of
Conjecture 1. The best known estimates to date are those in
[12], [16], [1] and [9].
Further, in the special case </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">, </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">, sharper
numerical values for the constants are known [6].
However Conjecture 1 is much stronger than all known lower
bounds:
- in terms of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">: best known
estimates involve </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%"> in place of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">;
- in terms of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">: so far, we have essentially </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">
in place of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">;
- in terms of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">: the sharpest (conditional) estimates,
due to E.M. Matveev [9], display </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%"> (with an
absolute constant
</text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">) in place of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">.
On the other hand for concrete applications like those
considered by K. Győry, a key point is often not to know
sharp estimates in terms of the dependence in the different
parameters, but to have non trivial lower bounds with small
numerical values for the constants. From this point of view a
result like [6], which deals only with the special
case </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">, </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%">, plays an important role in many
situations, in spite of the fact that the dependence in the
height of the coefficients </text><throwit /><text fontsize="90%"> is not as sharp
as other more general estimates from Gel’fond-Baker’s method.</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Karl-Heinz FIESELER</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract. 
The real intersection
cohomology <throwit> of a
toric variety </throwit><throwit> is
described in a purely combinatorial way
using methods of
elementary commutative algebra only. We define, for arbitrary fans,
the notion of a “minimal extension sheaf”
</throwit><throwit> on the fan </throwit><throwit> as an
axiomatic characterization of the
equivariant intersection cohomology
sheaf. This provides a
purely algebraic interpretation of the
</throwit><throwit>- and </throwit><throwit>-vector of an arbitrary
polytope or fan under a natural
vanishing condition. — The results
presented in this note originate from
joint work with G.Barthel, J.-P.Brasselet
and L.Kaup (see [3]). </throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent">

  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9

<throwit>: Linear polynomials are of degree </throwit><throwit>, etc.</throwit></p>
  </para>

is called a minimal extension
sheaf (of </throwit><throwit>) if it satisfies the
following conditions:</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

<throwit> on a fan space </throwit><throwit> is a
flabby sheaf of graded
</throwit><throwit>-modules such that, for each cone
</throwit><throwit>, the
</throwit><throwit>-module
</throwit><throwit> is finitely generated and free.</throwit></text></p>

semi-simple sheaf <throwit> on </throwit><throwit> is
isomorphic to a finite direct sum </throwit><throwit>
of shifted simple sheaves with uniquely
determined cones </throwit><throwit>, natural numbers </throwit><throwit>
and integers </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

<throwit> be a refinement map of fans with

Then the direct image sheaf </throwit><throwit> is a semisimple sheaf,
in particular there is a decomposition </throwit><throwit>
with cones
</throwit><throwit>
and positive integers </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001216.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">0. Introduction </text>
Many superbranes were constructed using a
generalisation of the <throwit>-symmetry [1] first found in the point
particle and later in the string. These included the construction of
the action for the twobrane of M theory [2] and the D-branes in ten
dimension [3]. However, the construction of the dynamics of the most
sophisticated brane, the M theory fivebrane, was achieved
[4],[5],[6] using the superembedding formalism [7]. In fact, some
the first brane actions to be constructed were for superbranes in
six and two dimensions [8] using the method of
non-linear realizations [9],[10]. This method has some advantages,
namely the construction is entirely group
theoretical and the fields have a very natural interpretation in terms
of Goldstone particles for broken symmetries. There now exists a
substantial literature [11][12][13][20] on the construction of
superbrane actions using this method. However, these works are
largely confined to branes in
dimensions lower than ten dimensions and the branes in eleven and
ten dimensions have not been constructed using this method.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">1. The Theory of Non-linear Realizations </text>
We first briefly review the theory of non-linear
realizations set out by Coleman, Wess and Zumino [9] and extended
by Volkov [10]. Rather than consider a general group we restrict
ourselves to the (super) group
<throwit> whose generators can be divided into the two sets
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. The sets </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> are both supgroups of </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> is the automorphism group, of </throwit><throwit>.
The generators in each of the above two classes are further divided as
</throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>. The generators </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> both form
subalgebras of the Lie
(super) algebra </throwit><throwit> whose associated groups
we denote by </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> respectively.
The generators of </throwit><throwit> are an automorphisms of </throwit><throwit>.
The division of the generators
of
</throwit><throwit> into these four classes corresponds to:
 </throwit><throwit>, unbroken generators associated with positions in
(super) space-time,
 </throwit><throwit>, spontaneously broken generators associated with
positions in (super) space-time,
 </throwit><throwit>, unbroken automorphism generators,
 </throwit><throwit>, spontaneously broken auotmorphism generators.
The automorphism generators include those of the Lorentz group or its
covering group the corresponding Spin group,
in some cases internal group
generators, but also other generators which are not usually
considered.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">1.  </text> An interesting phenomenon has been
observed in <throwit> supersymmetric </throwit><throwit> gauge theories with various
flavors and with adjoint mass perturbation </throwit><throwit>: confinement
is caused by condensation of magnetic monopoles carrying nontrivial
flavor quantum numbers (see also </throwit><throwit> for further details):
spontaneous flavor symmetry breaking is caused by the same
dyamical mechanism responsible for confinement in these models.
We wish to know what happens in more general classes of models, and
through a systematic analysis, to gain a more microscopic
understanding of these phenomena and related ones in Quantum Chromodynamics. As we see below, the
generalization from </throwit><throwit> to higher-rank gauge groups
turns out to be quite subtle.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">2. </text> First we perform a preparatory
analysis, by minimizing the
scalar potential following from the Lagrangian valid
in the semi-classical regime (when both <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are large).
</throwit><throwit> supersymmetry and holomorphy guarantee the absence of phase
transitions between large </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> to small </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. Therefore
these vacua are related to quantum vacua in other regimes one by one.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">3. </text> We next determine the possible patterns of
dynamical flavor symmetry breaking in these theories. This is done
most easily by studying these theories at large fixed <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>.</throwit><throwit> Such an
analysis is possible since at large adjoint mass the low-energy
effective superpotential can be read off from the bare Lagrangian by
integrating out the heavy adjoint field and by adding to it the
known exact instanton–induced superpotentials of the corresponding
</throwit><throwit> theories. By minimizing the superpotential, we found in all
cases the correct number of vacua
Eqs.(</throwit><throwit>)-(</throwit><throwit>). </throwit><throwit> supersymmetry kept
intact throughout guarantees that there are no phase transitions as
</throwit><throwit> is varied; we can thus determine the symmetry breaking pattern
in each </throwit><throwit> vacuum from the first principles. The analysis is
straightforward, but is not entirely trivial for large </throwit><throwit> because
the non-perturbative effects among the low-energy degrees of freedom
(dual quarks and mesons) have to be correctly taken into account
despite the fact that they are in a “free magnetic phase”</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">4.</text> We now seek for a microscopic understanding of
the mechanism of dynamical flavor symmetry breaking. We do so by
studying the <throwit> vacua on the Coulomb branch which survive </throwit><throwit> perturbation.
We start from the auxiliary genus </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) curves for
</throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) theories</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with <throwit> subject to the constraint </throwit><throwit>, and</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The VEVS of <throwit> are
constructed as
integrals over the non-trivial cycles of the meromorphic differentials
on the curves.
We require that
the curve is maximally singular, i.e. </throwit><throwit> (or </throwit><throwit> for
</throwit><throwit>) pairs of branch points
to coincide: this determines the possible values of </throwit><throwit>’s.
These correspond to the </throwit><throwit> vacua, with the particular </throwit><throwit>
perturbation, Eq.(</throwit><throwit>). Note that as we work with
generic and nonvanishing quark masses, this is an unambiguous
procedure to identify all the </throwit><throwit> vacua of our interest.
</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">5.</text> In the <throwit> case,
the </throwit><throwit> vacua can all be
generated from the various classes of superconformal theories with
</throwit><throwit>, by perturbation by masses </throwit><throwit>. The first type of
vacua (with multiplicity </throwit><throwit>) correspond to the curves</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>that is</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with <throwit>’s chosen such that the nonzero </throwit><throwit> branch points are
paired. These correspond to the so-called class 1 (</throwit><throwit>) and 3 (</throwit><throwit>, with </throwit><throwit> odd)
superconformal theories </throwit><throwit>, while the case, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> even, may
be interpreted as belonging to class 4. Since these adjoint VEVS break the discrete symmetry
spontaneously, they appear in
</throwit><throwit> copies.</throwit><throwit>
When (generic) quark masses are turned on, these vacua split into
</throwit><throwit>-plet of single vacua.
The second class of vacua stem from the (trivial) superconformal theory</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>corresponding to the singularity</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with <throwit>.
Actually there is no vacuum of the
first type with </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 31
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p29">
    <p><text font="bold">6. </text> In the <throwit>
gauge theories, the first type of vacua can be
identified more easily by first considering the equal but novanishing
quark masses. The adjoint vevs in the curve Eq.(</throwit><throwit>) can
be chosen so as to factor out the behavior</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>which describes an <throwit> gauge theory with </throwit><throwit> quarks. These
(trivial) superconformal theories belong in fact to the same universality
classes as in the </throwit><throwit> gauge theory as pointed out by
</throwit><throwit>. They are therefore described by exactly the same
Lagrangian Eq.(</throwit><throwit>). At each vacuum with </throwit><throwit>, the
symmetry (of equal mass theory, </throwit><throwit>) is broken spontaneously as</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>as in Eq.(<throwit>). When a small mass splitting is added
among </throwit><throwit>’s, each of the </throwit><throwit> vacuum split into </throwit><throwit>
vacua, leading to the total of</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>vacua of this type, consistently with Eq. (<throwit>).</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 35
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p33">
    <p><text font="bold">7.</text> To summarize,
we have studied the dynamics of <throwit> </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> gauge
theories obtained by perturbing </throwit><throwit> theories with </throwit><throwit>
hypermultiplets in the fundamental representation with a finite adjoint
mass </throwit><throwit>, determining the possible flavor
symmetry breaking patterns. There are
vacua in confinement phase with symmetry breaking </throwit><throwit>
(</throwit><throwit>) and </throwit><throwit>,
respectively. There also are non-confining vacua with no flavor
symmetry breaking for </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
theories, respectively.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0001080.xml
Para index in docroot: 16
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">Theorem 1:</text> In order to show that it is <text font="italic">possible</text> to produce a
specific outgoing state, any optical circuit with feed-forward detection can
be replaced by a <text font="italic">fixed</text> optical circuit where detection only takes place
at the end.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">Proof:</text> Suppose a feed-forward optical circuit (like the one depicted in
Fig. 1a) giving <throwit> exists. That means that the circuit creates
</throwit><throwit> conditioned on one of potentially many patterns of detector
responses. It is sufficient to consider a single successful pattern. We can
then take every interferometer to be fixed and postpone all detections of the
auxiliary modes to the very end (Fig. 1b). Note that this procedure selects
generally only </throwit><text font="italic">one</text> setup in which entanglement is produced, whereas a
feed-forward optical circuit potentially allows more setups. It therefore
might reduce the efficiency of the process. However, since we are only
interested in the <text font="italic">possibility</text> of creating <throwit>, the
efficiency is irrelevant. </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">Theorem 2:</text> Suppose an optical circuit produces a specific outgoing state
conditioned on <throwit> detected photons in mode 1, </throwit><throwit> detected photons in
mode 2, etc. (with </throwit><throwit>). The same output can be obtained by
a circuit where in every detected mode </throwit><text font="italic">at most</text> one photon is found.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para xml:id="p14">
    <p><text font="bold">Proof:</text> If there are more photons in a mode, we can replace the
corresponding detector by a so-called detector <text font="italic">cascade</text> <throwit>. This
device splits the mode into many modes which are all detected. For a
sufficiently large cascade there is always a non-vanishing probability to have
at most one photon in each outgoing mode. In that case, the same state is
created while at most one photon enters each detector. Note that this again
yields a lower efficiency.  </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nucl-th0001010.xml
Para index in docroot: 11
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Hydrodynamical or thermal description with (standard) freeze
out emission - </text>
First we remind what is the status of the standard
hydrodynamical or thermal description of relativistic nuclear collisions.
In this kind of description,
hadrons are kept in chemical or thermal
equilibrium until some decoupling criterion has become satisfied.
An exemple of
freeze out criterion often used is that a certain
temperature and baryonic potential have been reached.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">Hydrodynamical description with continuous emission - </text>
In the standard hydrodynamical models,
one assumes that the freeze out occurs on a sharp three-dimensional
surface (defined for example by <throwit>).
Before crossing it, particles have a hydrodynamical behavior,
and after, they free-stream toward the detectors, keeping memory
of the conditions (flow, temperature) of where and when they crossed the
three dimensional surface.
The Cooper-Frye formula
</throwit><throwit> gives the invariant momentum distribution
in this case</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><throwit> is a normal vector to the freeze out surface </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> the distribution function of the type of particles considered.
This is the formula implicitly used in all standard thermal and
hydrodynamical model
calculations of the previous section.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">Relation between pion number and entropy - </text>
In a hydrodynamical model without shocks and dissipation, entropy is
conserved. In the usual freeze out scenario, this is an important
point because the initial entropy can be determined from the final
multiplicity.
To illustrate this connection, let us consider a massless pion
gas. Statistical mechanics yields the following relationship for the
entropy density and the pion density <throwit>.
In the longitudinal boost invariant model, the entropy conservation
equation gives: </throwit><throwit>. Using </throwit><throwit> at </throwit><throwit>,
this can be written: </throwit><throwit>.
So we can rewrite</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Therefore, experimental knowledge of <throwit>,
permits to extract </throwit><throwit>, which are both independent of time.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 29
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p23">
    <p><text font="bold">Conclusion - </text>
In this paper, we discussed data on strange and non-strange particles
by NA35, from an hydrodynamical point of view.
The standard model with sudden freeze out can reproduce the strange
particle data but underpredicts the pion abundance, if no extra
assumption is made.
We showed that a hydrodynamical model with a more precise emission
process, continuous emission, can reproduce both the strange and
non-strange particle data without extra assumption.</p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Jon Thaler (University of Illinois):</text> 
Is there any observable effect in electron capture rates?</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Robertson:</text> 
Yes, electron capture decay has been studied as a means for measuring the
neutrino mass (as distinct from the antineutrino mass). Capture from
higher-lying atomic subshells can be cut off or attenuated if the neutrino has
mass. In practice the interpretation of the resulting X-ray spectra is made
difficult by rearrangement processes analogous to shakeup and shakeoff.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 22
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Appendix.</text></p>
    <p>As an evidence aimed to
transmitting the intuition that,
for infinitely large driving,
the current is not relevant at criticality, let us briefly discuss
in this appendix a rather compelling Monte Carlo observation.
It corresponds to a
variation of the DLG, named ALGA (anisotropic
lattice gas automaton); see <throwit>
for a detailed definition. This model is placed by definition
at the limit of infinite driving:
jumps in the anisotropy direction are performed
randomly without attending to energetic considerations. Simulations
are performed both in the presence of an overall current
(case </throwit><throwit> in </throwit><throwit>)
and in the absence of it (</throwit><throwit>);
the curves for the order parameter versus
the distance to the critical point are indistinguishable
in the cases with and without a current
(figure 3 in </throwit><throwit> is particularly illuminating).
It could be argued that the details of this modified model </throwit><throwit>
render it not completely equivalent to the original DLG.
However, we do not think these microscopic differences have any relevance
at a coarse grained level.
In fact,
we expect this model to be represented
by Eq. (</throwit><throwit>): in one direction
particles tend to stay together, and it is natural to
assume that their coarse grained behavior is controlled
by a model B in this
direction. In the other direction, jumps occur regardless of energetics
and, therefore, the dynamics becomes purely diffusive. With these two
ingredients we recover the ADS, Eq. (</throwit><throwit>),
as the Langevin equation for the ALGA.
As a further evidence supporting this hypothesis let us mention
that the measured </throwit><throwit> exponent in the ALGA is </throwit><throwit>
(again very close to the value </throwit><throwit>)
in both cases: with and without current.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0001009.xml
Para index in docroot: 1
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">New strategy for suppressing decoherence in
quantum computation</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> Controlable strong interaction of the
qubit’s bath with an external system (i.e. with the
bath’s environment) allows for choosing the conditions
under which the decoherence of the qubit’s states can
be substantially decreased (in a certain limit:
completely avoided). By ”substantially decreased” we
mean that the correlations which involve the bath’s
states prove negligible, while the correlations
between the qubit’s and the environment’s states
can be made ineffective during a comparatively long
time interval. So, effectively, one may choose the
conditions under which, for sufficiently long time
interval, the initial state of ”qubit + bath” remains
unchanged, thus removing any kind of the errors.
The method has been successfully employed in the
(simplified) model of the
solid-state-nuclear quantum computer (proposed by Kane).</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction</text></p>
  </para>

<para>
    <p><text font="bold">2. General background</text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">3. The strategy</text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">3.1 The perturbation theory employed</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 75

    <p><text font="bold">3.2 Physical interpretation</text></p>
  </para>

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">NEW MODULI SPACES OF POINTED CURVES</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">AND PENCILS OF FLAT CONNECTIONS</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">A. Losev<throwit>, Yu. Manin</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> It is well known that formal solutions
to the Associativity Equations are the same as
cyclic algebras over the homology operad
<throwit> of the moduli
spaces of </throwit><throwit>–pointed stable curves of genus zero.
In this paper we establish a similar relationship between
the pencils of formal flat connections (or solutions to the
Commutativity Equations) and homology
of a new series </throwit><throwit> of pointed stable curves
of genus zero. Whereas </throwit><throwit> parametrizes
trees of </throwit><throwit>’s with pairwise distinct nonsingular marked points,
</throwit><throwit> parametrizes strings of </throwit><throwit>’s stabilized
by marked points of two types.
The union of all </throwit><throwit>’s forms a semigroup
rather than operad, and the role of operadic algebras is taken
over by the representations of the appropriately
twisted homology algebra of this union.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">0. Introduction and plan of the paper</text></p>
  </para>

<para xml:id="p24">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">§1. <throwit>–pointed curves</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 29
<para xml:id="p26">
    <p><text font="bold">1.2. Remarks.</text> a) If we put in this definition <throwit>,
we will get the usual notion of an </throwit><throwit>–pointed (pre)stable curve
whose structure sections are not allowed to intersect
pairwise. Now we divide the sections
into two groups: “white” sections </throwit><throwit> are not allowed
to intersect any other section, whereas “black” sections
</throwit><throwit> cannot intersect white ones, but otherwise
are free and can even pairwise coincide. (However,
both types of sections are not allowed to intersect singularities
of fibres).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 33
<para xml:id="p30">
    <p><text font="bold">1.3. A construction.</text> In this subsection, we start with
an <throwit>–pointed curve (1.1) and produce from it another
</throwit><throwit>–pointed curve:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The base of the new curve will be <throwit>
There will be one extra black mark, say, </throwit><throwit>, so that
</throwit><throwit>. The new curve and sections
will be produced in two steps. At the first step
we make the base change </throwit><throwit> as in 1.2 c),
obtaining an </throwit><throwit>–pointed curve </throwit><throwit>,
with sections </throwit><throwit>
We then add the extra section </throwit><throwit>
which is the relative diagonal, and mark it by </throwit><throwit>.
We did not yet produce an </throwit><throwit>–pointed curve over
</throwit><throwit>, because the extra black section can (and generally will)
intersect both singular points of the fibres and
white sections as well.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 36

    <p><text font="bold">1.3.1. Remark.</text> We can try to modify this construction
in order to be able to add an extra white point,
instead of a black one. However, for <throwit>
we will not be able then
to avoid the local analysis of the situation
by referring to [Kn1]. In fact, points where </throwit><throwit>
intersects at least two </throwit><throwit>–sections simultaneously,
will have to be treated anew.</throwit></p>

    <p><text font="bold">Proof.</text> Properness and smoothness follow by induction
and Knudsen’s local analysis which we already invoked.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 50
<para xml:id="p45">
    <p><text font="bold">2.2.1. Remark.</text> Dual graphs of the degenerate fibers of <throwit> over
</throwit><throwit> come with a natural orientation from </throwit><throwit> to
</throwit><throwit>. We could have allowed ourselves not to distinguish
between the two white points, interchanging them by isomorphisms, but this would produce several
upleasant consequences. First, our manifolds would become
actual stacks, starting already with </throwit><throwit>.
Second, we would have lost the toric interpretation of these
spaces. Third, and most important, we would meet an ambiguity
in the definition of the multiplication between the homology spaces:
see (3.5) below. With our choice, we can simply introduce
the involution permuting </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> as a part of the structure
and look how it interacts with other parts.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 52
<para xml:id="p46">
    <p><text font="bold">Proof. Since <throwit> are defined over
</throwit><throwit>, we can apply the classical Weil’s technique of

but as a power of prime). After the counting is done, we will see that
</throwit><throwit> is a polynomial in </throwit><throwit>

    <throwit>

Para index in docroot: 54
<para xml:id="p48">
    <p><text font="bold">2.4. <throwit> and toric actions. Let </throwit><throwit>
be the trivial partition of </throwit><throwit> of length one. The “big cell”
</throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit> (see 2.2 c))
has a canonical structure of
the torsor (principal homogeneous space) over the torus </throwit><throwit>
(where the subgroup </throwit><throwit> is embedded diagonally).
In fact, </throwit><throwit> is a
</throwit><throwit>–torsor, and the respective action of
</throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>, moving </throwit><throwit>
via the </throwit><throwit>–th factor, produces an isomorphic marked curve
exactly via the action of the diagonal.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 55
<para xml:id="p49">
    <p><text font="bold">Similarly, every stratum <throwit> is a torsor
over </throwit><throwit> (see (2.4)), and there is a canonical
surjective morphism </throwit><throwit> so that </throwit><throwit>
is a union of </throwit><throwit>–orbits. In order to show that
</throwit><throwit> is a toric variety, it remains to show that these
actions are compatible. This again can be done using the
explicit construction of </throwit><throwit> and induction.
For a change, we will provide a direct toric construction.
We start with a more systematic treatment of
the combinatorics involved.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 56
<para xml:id="p50">
    <p><text font="bold">2.4.1. Partitions of finite sets. For any finite
set <throwit>, we call a partition </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit> </throwit></text><text font="italic">a totally
ordered set of non–empty subsets of <throwit> whose union is
</throwit><throwit> and whose pairwise intersectons are empty.</throwit></text><text font="bold">
If a partition consists of <throwit> subsets, it is called
</throwit><throwit>–partition. If its components are denoted </throwit><throwit>,
or otherwise listed,
this means that they are listed
in their structure order. Another partition can be denoted
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> etc. Notice that no particular ordering of </throwit><throwit>
is a part of the structure.
This is why we replaced </throwit><throwit>
here by an unstructured set </throwit><throwit /></text></p>

Para index in docroot: 128
<para xml:id="p112">
    <p><text font="bold">3.2.2. Pencils of flat connections related to
Frobenius manifolds. Any solution to the Associativity Equations produces
a pencil of flat connections.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 129
<para xml:id="p113">
    <p><text font="bold">To explain this we will use the
geometric language due to B. Dubrovin (and the notation of [Ma], I.1.5).
Consider a Frobenius manifold <throwit> where</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">is a (super)commutative associative multiplication on the tangent
sheaf satisfying the potentiality condition, and
<throwit> is an invariant flat metric (no positivity condition is assumed,
only symmetry and non–degeneracy).
Denote by </throwit><throwit> the Levi–Civita connection of </throwit><throwit>.
Finally, denote by </throwit><throwit> the operator obtained from
the Frobenius multiplication in </throwit><throwit> ([Ma], I.1.4). In other words,
consider the pencil of connections on </throwit><throwit> whose covariant derivatives are</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">This pencil is flat (see [Ma], Theorem I.1.5, p. 20). In fact, <throwit> written in a basis
of </throwit><throwit>–flat coordinates and the respective flat vector fields
is simply the matrix of the second derivatives of a local potential </throwit><throwit>
(with one subscript raised). This is the first structure connection
of </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 130
<para xml:id="p114">
    <p><text font="bold">This pencil admits an infinite dimensional deformation:
one should take the canonical extension of the potential
to the large phase space and consider the coordinates
with gravitational descendants as parameters of the
deformation.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 131
<para xml:id="p115">
    <p><text font="bold">Another family of flat connections, this time on the </text><text font="italic">cotangent</text><text font="bold">
sheaf of a Frobenius manifold <throwit> admitting an Euler vector field </throwit><throwit>
(see [Ma], pp. 23–24), is defined as follows. Denote
the scalar product on vector fields </throwit><throwit> The inverse form induces a pencil
of flat metrics on the cotangent sheaf, whose Levi–Civita
connections however do not form a pencil of flat connections
in our sense (see [Du1], Appendix D,
and [Du3] for a general discussion of such setup). This is the second structure
connection of </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 132
<para xml:id="p116">
    <p><text font="bold">3.2.3. Flat coordinates and gravitational descendants.
One can show that 1–forms on <throwit> flat with respect to the dualized first
structure connection are closed and therefore locally exact.
Their integrals are called deformed flat coordinates.
In [Du2], Example 2.3 and Theorem 2.2, B. Dubrovin gives explicit
formal series in </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit> in his notation) for suitably normalized
deformed flat coordinates. Coefficients of these series involve
some correlators with gravitational descendants, namely
those for which the non–trivial operators </throwit><throwit>
are applied only at one point. In [KM2] and [Ma], VI.7.2, p.278,
it was shown
that two–point correlators of this kind determine a linear
operator in the large phase space which transforms
the modified correlators with descendants into non–modified ones (in any genus).
This is important because apriori only modified correlators are defined
for an arbitrary Cohomological Field Theory in the sense of [KM1],
which is not necessarily quantum cohomology of a manifold.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 133
<para xml:id="p117">
    <p><text font="bold">3.2.4. Pencils of flat connections in a global setting.
Pencils of flat connections appear also in the context
of Simpson’s non–abelian Hodge theory. Briefly, consider
a smooth projective manifold <throwit> over </throwit><throwit>. One can define
two moduli spaces, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. The first one classifies
flat connections (on variable vector bundles </throwit><throwit>
with vanishing rational Chern classes) with semisimple
Zariski closure of the monodromy group. The second one
classifies semistable Higgs pairs </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit>
is an operator as in 3.1, satisfying only the condition
</throwit><throwit> (In fact, one should only consider
smooth points of the respective moduli spaces). N. Hitchin,
C. Simpson, Fujiki et al. established that </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
are canonically isomorphic as </throwit><throwit>–manifolds,
but their complex structures </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> are different,
and together with </throwit><throwit> produce a hypercomplex manifold.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 134
<para xml:id="p118">
    <p><text font="bold">P. Deligne has shown that the respective twistor space is
precisely the moduli space of the pencils of flat
connections on <throwit> (where the Higgs complex structure
corresponds to the point </throwit><throwit> in our notation).</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 135
<para xml:id="p119">
    <p><text font="bold">For details, see [Si].</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 136
<para xml:id="p120">
    <p><text font="bold">3.3. Formal solutions to the Commutativity Equations
and the homology of <throwit> In [KM1] and [KMK]
it was shown that formal solutions to the Associativity Equations
are cyclic algebras over the cyclic genus zero homology modular
operad </throwit><throwit> (see also [Ma], III.4).
The main goal of this section is to show the similar
role of the homology of the spaces </throwit><throwit>
in the theory of the Commutativity Equations.
This was discovered and discussed on a physical level in [Lo1], [Lo2].
Here we supply precise mathematical statements with proofs.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 137
<para xml:id="p121">
    <p><text font="bold">Unlike the case
of the Associativity Equations, we will have to deal here
with modules over an algebra (depending explicitly
on the base space) rather than with algebras over an operad.
The main ingredient of the construction is
the direct sum of the homology spaces
of all <throwit> endowed with the multiplication
coming from the boundary morphisms. We work
with the combinatorial models of these spaces
defined in 2.9.1.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
