Para index in docroot: 163
<para xml:id="p142">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">§4. Stacks </text><throwit /><text font="bold">
and the extended modular operad</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 164
<para xml:id="p143">
    <p><text font="bold">4.1. Introduction. The basic topological operad <throwit> of Quantum Cohomology lacks the </throwit><throwit> term which
is usually formally defined as a point. We argued elsewhere
(cf. [MaZ], sec. 7 and [Ma], VI.7.6) that
it would be very desirable to find a non–trivial DM–stack
which could play the role of </throwit><throwit>.
There are several tests that such an object should pass:</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 165
<para xml:id="p144">
    <p><text font="bold">a) It must be a semigroup (because for any operad <throwit>,
the operadic multiplication makes a semigroup of </throwit><throwit>).</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 166
<para xml:id="p145">
    <p><text font="bold">b) It must be a part of an extended genus zero operad,
say, <throwit> geometrically related to </throwit><throwit> in such a way that the theory of Gromov–Witten
invariants with gravitational descendants could be
formulated in this new context. In particular, it must
geometrically explain two–point correlators
with gravitational descendants.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 167
<para xml:id="p146">
    <p><text font="bold">c) In turn, the extended genus zero operad must be a part
of an extended modular operad containing moduli spaces of
arbitrary genus, in such a way that algebras over
classical modular operads produce extended algebras.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 168
<para xml:id="p147">
    <p><text font="bold">In this section we will try to show that the space</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">passes at least a part of these tests. (Another candidate
which might be interesting is <throwit>
with respect to the forgetful morphisms).</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 169
<para xml:id="p148">
    <p><text font="bold">4.2. Semigroup structure. It is defined
as the union of boundary (clutching) morphisms</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">where</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">glues <throwit> of the first curve to </throwit><throwit> of the second curve
and renumbers the black points of the second curve keeping
their order (cf. [MaZ], section 7). This is the structure that
induced our multiplication on </throwit><throwit> in 3.3 above.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 170
<para xml:id="p149">
    <p><text font="bold">4.3. Extended operads. In (4.2), only
white points <throwit> are used to define
the operadic composition whereas the black ones
serve only to stabilize the strings of </throwit><throwit>’s
which otherwise would be unstable. This is a key observation
for our attempt to define an extended operad.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 171
<para xml:id="p150">
    <p><text font="bold">A natural idea would be to proceed as follows. Denote
by <throwit> the stack of stable </throwit><throwit>–pointed
curves of genus </throwit><throwit> (see Definition 1.1). Check that it is
a DM–stack. Put </throwit><throwit>
and define the operadic
compositions via boundary maps, using only white points as above.
(We sometimes write here and below </throwit><throwit> instead of
</throwit><throwit>).</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 172
<para xml:id="p151">
    <p><text font="bold">It seems however that this object is too big for our purposes
and that it must be replaced by a smaller stack which we will
define inductively, by using the Construction 1.3
which we will call here simply the adjoining of a generic black point. The components
of this stack will be defined inductively.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 173
<para xml:id="p152">
    <p><text font="bold">If <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, we start
with </throwit><throwit> and
add </throwit><throwit> generic black points, one in turn. Denote the resulting
stack by </throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 174
<para xml:id="p153">
    <p><text font="bold">For <throwit>, one should
add one more sequence of stacks, corresponding to </throwit><throwit>.
Since we want to restrict ourselves to Deligne–Mumford stacks, we start at </throwit><throwit> identified with </throwit><throwit>
(see 1.2 a)), and add black points to get the sequence
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> These spaces are needed
to serve as targets for the clutching morphisms gluing
</throwit><throwit> to </throwit><throwit> on the same curve of genus zero: cf. below.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 175
<para xml:id="p154">
    <p><text font="bold">Finally, for <throwit> we obtain our series of spaces </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> and moreover </throwit><throwit>, for all </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 176
<para xml:id="p155">
    <p><text font="bold">4.3.1. Combinatorial types of fibers. Let us remind
that combinatorial types of classical (semi)stable curves
with (only white) points labeled by a finite set <throwit>
are isomorphism classes of graphs, whose vertices are
labeled by “genera” </throwit><throwit> and tails are bijectively labeled by elements
of </throwit><throwit>. Stability means that vertices of genus 0 bound </throwit><throwit>
flags, and vertices of genus 1 bound </throwit><throwit> flags.
Graphs can have edges with only one vertex, that is, simple loops.
See [Ma], III.2 for more details.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 177
<para xml:id="p156">
    <p><text font="bold">Starting with such a graph <throwit>, or rather with its geometric
realization, we can obtain an infinite series
of graphs, which will turn out to be exactly combinatorial
types of (semi)stable </throwit><throwit>–pointed curves
that are fibers of the families described above. Namely,
subdivide edges and tails of </throwit><throwit> by a finite set of new vertices
of genus zero (on each edge or tail, this set may be empty). If
a tail was subdivided, move the respective label (from </throwit><throwit>)
to the newly emerged tail. Distribute the black
tails labeled by elements of </throwit><throwit> arbitrarily among the old and the new
vertices. Call the resulting graph </throwit></text><text font="italic">a stringy stable
combinatorial type</text><text font="bold"> if it becomes stable after repainting
black tails into white ones. Clearly, new vertices depict strings of
<throwit>’s stabilized by black points and eventually
two special points on the end components.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 179
<para xml:id="p157">
    <p><text font="bold">The statement a) can be proved in the same way as the
respective statement 2.2 a).</text></p>
  </para>

of the Gromov–Witten invariants, preferably with descendants, to this
context. The Remark 3.2.3 seems promising in this respect.</text></p>

key properties (</throwit><throwit>) without serious calculations:</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001130.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">1.  </text>
Twist-three parton distributions in the nucleon are attracting
increasing interest as unique probes of novel quark-gluon correlations
in hadrons with clear experimental signature, giving rise to certain
asymmetries in experiments with polarized beams and targets.
Quantitative studies of such asymmetries are becoming possible
with the increasing precision of experimental data at SLAC and RHIC,
and can provide for an
important part of the future spin physics program on high-luminosity
accelerators like ELFE, upgraded CEBAF etc.
With this perspective, a detailed theoretical study of twist-three
parton distributions in QCD becomes mandatory.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">2.  </text>
From the OPE analysis <throwit> one finds that
the scale dependence of the moments of the
twist-3 distributions </throwit><throwit>
is governed by renormalization of the set of local composite quark-antiquark-gluon operators (</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>)</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>for chiral-even (<throwit>) and chiral-odd distributions
(</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>,
respectively), see e.g. </throwit><throwit>.
Here, </throwit><throwit> is a light-like vector and
</throwit><throwit> stands for a dual gluon field strength.
To leading order, renormalization of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
is the same and we, therefore, drop the subscript in what follows.
Similarly, it is enough to consider the operator </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">3.  </text>
The large-<throwit> Hamiltonians </throwit><throwit> in (</throwit><throwit>) possess an
additional ‘hidden’ symmetry, related to the existence of a nontrivial
conserved charge </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> stands for the anticommutator. As the result,
eigenstates of </throwit><throwit> can be labeled by quantized eigenvalues
</throwit><throwit>,   </throwit><throwit>,
of the operator </throwit><throwit>:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Since the number of degrees of freedom (=3) equals in this case to
the number of conserved charges (<throwit>), the quantum mechanical system
described by the Hamiltonian </throwit><throwit> is completely integrable.
This allows to use advanced mathematical methods for the analysis of
the spectrum and, in particular, develop the WKB expansion of
the eigenvalues at large </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">4.  </text>
The <throwit> correction </throwit><throwit> to the energy
of the lowest eigenstates is given by Eq. (</throwit><throwit>) for </throwit><throwit>. The calculation
is most easily done by going over to the so-called conformal basis
</throwit><throwit>. The idea is to define a
basis of (orthogonal with respect to (</throwit><throwit>)) polynomials
that satisfy the conformal constraints in (</throwit><throwit>) and, in addition,
diagonalize the two-particle Casimir operator (</throwit><throwit>) in one of the channels, e.g.</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>and, similarly, <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.
Here, the superscripts indicate the order in which the conformal spins
of the three partons
sum up to the total conformal spin </throwit><throwit>. The three
different sets of </throwit><throwit>-functions are related to each other through the
Racah </throwit><throwit>-symbols of the </throwit><throwit> group. Permutation symmetry
between the quarks implies that
</throwit><throwit>.
The explicit expressions
for the </throwit><throwit>functions are given in terms of the Jacobi polynomials
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para xml:id="p23">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">5.  </text>
According to (<throwit>), the moments of twist-3 distributions
receive contributions from the whole tower of operators
with non-minimal anomalous dimensions at the level of </throwit><throwit>
corrections. Aside from the “energy denominators”,
the coefficients in front of these operators in (</throwit><throwit>)
are given by (normalized)
matrix elements </throwit><throwit> of the
perturbation </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> numerate the anomalous
dimensions from below. Our main observation is that
the matrix elements (</throwit><throwit>) are
concentrated close to the diagonal </throwit><throwit>, see Figs. 1, 2 and
Table 2.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Conclusions<throwit /></text>Spin density matrix element <throwit> for
leading vector mesons </throwit><throwit> has been measured to be </throwit><throwit>. This value deviates from the
value of </throwit><throwit> indicating the spin alignment of </throwit><throwit>
produced inclusively in neutron-carbon interactions at
</throwit><throwit> GeV. It has been obtained also that leading vector meson
</throwit><throwit> has spin alignment, increasing with </throwit><throwit>. Some
indications on spin alignment of non-leading </throwit><throwit> have been
obtained, but with low statistical significance: </throwit><throwit>. Thus the qualitative theoretical
expectations </throwit><throwit> of leading particle effect in
spin alignment are confirmed. The present precise measurement is in
agreement with the result obtained in </throwit><throwit> beam </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 1
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">ON M THEORY, QUANTUM PARADOXES AND THE NEW RELATIVITY</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">1. Introduction : Historical background</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">2. The Program of the New Relativity Principle : The Demolition of Today’s Absolutes</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">1</text>. The old Bootstrap Idea of Chew : Each <throwit>-brane is made of </throwit><text font="bold">all </text> the others. To view a single <throwit>-brane as a fundamental identity is a meaningless concept.
</throwit><throwit>-branes are defined only in </throwit><text font="bold">relation</text> to others. This is Mach’s principle once again. For this reason, one must include all dimensions and signatures
on the same footing.
Pezzaglia [2] has called this the principle of Polydimensional Covariance or Dimensional Democracy. The New Relativity theory reshuffles, for example, a string history for a
<throwit>-brane history; a </throwit><throwit>-brane history for a membrane history; an </throwit><throwit>-brane history for a history encompassing all other </throwit><throwit>-branes…and so forth.
Point and extended instantons and tensionless </throwit><throwit>-branes are also inlcluded. The tensionless </throwit><throwit>-brane history excitations of the
infinite dimensional Quantum Spacetime are the ” photons ” in this New Relativity Theory.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">2</text>. Laurent Nottale’s Scale-Relativity theory [3].</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para>
    <p><throwit>-adic numbers and </throwit><throwit>-adic Physics is a nice attempt to
eliminate the problem of having to specify a real number up to infinite digits [11].
The Planck scale is therefore taken as that universal standard of measure invariant under Scale Relativistic transformations of </throwit><text font="bold">resolutions</text> .
In the same vein that the speed of light was taken by Einstein as the
maximum speed in Nature, the Planck scale is taken to be the minimum length.
The speed of light allowed Einstein to embrace space with time, since space and time have different units.
By the same token, to embrace all dimensions one needs a Universal length scale in <text font="bold">all</text> dimensions : the Planck Scale.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 29
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">3</text>. Noncommutative <text font="bold">C</text>-spaces. One of the authors was forced to enlarge the naive notion of commuting spacetime coordinates
to fully covariantize the Quantum Mechanical Loop
Equations for <throwit>-branes. One achieved that goal if one extended the notion of ordinary spacetime vectors and tensors, to a Noncommutative </throwit><text font="bold">C</text>-space,
or Clifford manifold, where all <throwit>-branes were unified in one single footing by using Clifford-algebra valued </throwit><text font="bold">multivectors</text> quantities ( matrices)
instead of ordinary vectors and tensors. In order to combine objects of
different dimensionality one needs a length scale : the Planck scale.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 32
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">4</text>. Quantum Spacetime must be treated from a Multivector-Multiscale point of view. The use of Clifford-valued multivectors was explained above.
The multi-scale or resolution aspects are based on Nottale’s fractals and El Naschie’ s Cantorian-Fractal Quantum Spacetime views that
dimensions are <text font="bold">resolution</text> dependent concepts and not <text font="bold">fixed</text> notions [3,4] .</p>
  </para>

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">3. There is No Such Thing as an Einstein-Rosen-Podolski Paradox in the New Relativity</text></p>
  </para>

disordered mean field models such as, <text font="italic">e.g.</text>, neural networks.</p>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>Neutrino oscillations are studied in the general framework of open quantum
systems by means of extended dynamics that take into account possible
dissipative effects. These new phenomena induce modifications in the
neutrino oscillation pattern that in general can be parametrized by means
of six phenomenological constants. Although very small, stringent bounds
on these parameters are likely to be given by future planned
neutrino experiments.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7

    <p><text font="bold">1. INTRODUCTION</text></p>

using the atmospheric neutrino data of the Super-Kamiokande experiment
a bound on one of the dissipative parameters was obtained.</p>

<para xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract. </text>
It is shown how the the introduction of a suitably defined dilatonic
auxiliary field, <throwit> say, makes it possible for the non-linear Lagrangian
for a generic elastic string model, of the kind appropriate for representing
superconducting cosmic strings, to be converted into a standardised form as
the sum of a kinetic term that is just homogeneously quadratic in the relevant
scalar phase gradient (as in a simple linear model) together with a potential
energy term, </throwit><throwit> say, that is specified as a generically non-linear function
of </throwit><throwit>. The explicit form of this function is derived for various
noteworthy examples, of which the most memorable is that of the transonic
string model, as characterised by a given mass scale, </throwit><throwit> say, for which
this potential energy density will be expressible in terms of the zero
current limit value </throwit><throwit> of </throwit><throwit> by </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" framed="underline">Introduction:</text>   The phase behaviour of isotropic magnets
and related systems in two dimensions is a particular challenge since famous
theorems exclude long-range order<throwit>, but nevertheless phase transitions
occur in models such as the two- dimensional XY ferromagnet</throwit><throwit> or the
planar rotor model (</throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>
is a two component spin at the site </throwit><throwit> with unit magnitude and orientation
</throwit><throwit> ),</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>the sum extends once over all nearest neighbor pairs of the (square) lattice,
and <throwit> is the reduced temperature (the Boltzmann constant </throwit><throwit>
is taken to be </throwit><throwit> throughout). Originally</throwit><throwit> it was proposed that
a critical temperature </throwit><throwit> occurs where the correlation length </throwit><throwit>
describing the decay of the correlation function </throwit><throwit> with distance </throwit><throwit>, and the susceptiblity </throwit><throwit> diverge according to power laws,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><throwit> being the usual critical exponents. However, Kosterlitz and
Thouless (KT)</throwit><throwit> developed a completely different scenario, based on
the unbinding of vortex- antivortex pairs, yielding an essential singularity,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> are nonuniversal constants, while an approximate
renormalization group treatment</throwit><throwit> predicted that the exponents
</throwit><throwit> take the universal values,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold" framed="underline">Monte Carlo estimation of input parameters to the KT theory</text> 
The KT theory<throwit> can be cast in the framework of a
two parameter
renormalization flow for the spinwave stiffness </throwit><throwit> and the fugacity of
vortices </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> is related to the considered length scale as </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> is the lattice spacing. These flow equations in terms
of the scaled variables </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> and upto
next to leading order</throwit><throwit> are,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Using a linearised version of these equations (i.e. keeping only the first
terms on the right hand side of these equations) and using the approximate
initial conditions <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> –
a result from harmonic spin wave theory strictly valid at </throwit><throwit>,
Kosterlitz</throwit><throwit> found that a non- trivial fixed point </throwit><throwit> exists (cf. Eq. (3) above) but the resulting estimate
for </throwit><throwit> is rather different from the current best estimates
</throwit><throwit /><throwit>. Does this discrepancy mean that the
KT scenario does not work?</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold" framed="underline">Discussion and conclusions</text> Our analysis demonstrates that
the planar rotor model is fully consistent with the KT theory, but for a
quantitatively accurate description of the transition (especially for
nonuniversal quantities) it is indispensible that the higher order terms in
the recursion relations Eq.(5) are taken into account. This finding implies
that far away from <throwit> significant corrections to Eq.(3) are expected —
this offers an explanation why the direct simulations </throwit><throwit>
have difficulties in extracting the correct critical behaviour unambiguously.
In contrast, our method yields critical properties with comparatively modest
computational effort. We expect that analogous methods can be applied to
other models that are expected to show KT transitions; in fact, we are
currently undertaking an extension of our approach to the controversial issue
of two- dimensional melting.</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">1.1.</text> <text font="italic">Lattice vertex algebras.</text> Let <throwit> be a free abelian
group on </throwit><throwit> generators </throwit><throwit>. Give </throwit><throwit> an integral
lattice structure by defining a bilinear symmetric </throwit><throwit>-valued form</throwit></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">1.2.</text> <text font="italic">Explicit description of the vertex algebra structure on
<throwit>.</throwit></text> To simplify the notation, we identify <throwit> with the subspace
</throwit><throwit>. As an </throwit><throwit>-module,
</throwit><throwit> is a direct sum of irreducibles and there is one irreducible
module, </throwit><throwit>, for each </throwit><throwit>. </throwit><throwit> is
freely generated by the supercommutative associative algebra
</throwit><throwit> from the highest weight vector </throwit><throwit>.
The words “highest weight vector” mean that the following relations
hold:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 48
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">1.3.</text> <text font="italic">Degeneration of <throwit>.</throwit></text> Denote by <throwit> the subgroup of
</throwit><throwit>
generated by </throwit><throwit>.
Any smooth toric variety </throwit><throwit> can be defined via a fan, </throwit><throwit>,
that is, a collection of “cones” lying in </throwit><throwit>. Borisov uses such
</throwit><throwit> to define a certain degeneration, </throwit><throwit>, of the vertex
algebra structure on </throwit><throwit>. He further shows that the cohomology of
</throwit><throwit> with respect to a certain differential
</throwit><throwit>
equals </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> is the chiral
de Rham complex of [MSV]. Let us describe the outcome of this construction
in the case when </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

potential,
which does not depend on <throwit>. We will construct the Fock’s space

of creation and anihilation of pairs particle-antiparticle. Finally,
we will see that in dimension </throwit><throwit>, when </throwit><throwit>,
these phenomena
disappear. However, in dimension </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>, when </throwit><throwit>, the
creation probability of particle-antiparticle pairs is not zero.</throwit></text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002424.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction.</text>
It is by now well established that the center-of-mass (COM) motion of
two interacting particles (TIP) in a
single tight-binding band of a one-dimensional
Hamiltonian possessing diagonal disorder
is spatially more extended than both their relative motion
and the motion of the particles without interaction <throwit>.
Although this model is a fundamental paradigm for the more general
question of the interplay of disorder and interactions in many-body
systems, it suffers from not being susceptible to experimental
verification. Furthermore, it is not clear whether this finding,
relevant for two particles, can be
generalized to real transport situations in dense Fermi systems.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">Model.</text>
A two-band Hamiltonian <throwit> is considered</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with nearest neighbour coupling <throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) for electrons (holes)
and diagonal disorder given by a box-shaped distribution function
of the single-site energies </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) of total width
</throwit><throwit>. The </throwit><throwit> sites form a linear chain with spacing </throwit><throwit> and periodic
boundary conditions.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">Equation of Motion.</text>
The equation of motion for the pair amplitude <throwit> is derived
using the total Hamiltonian </throwit><throwit>. In the low intensity limit
linear response theory is valid and the equation of motion reads
(with </throwit><throwit>)</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>This equation of motion is solved numerically for <throwit> realizations
(typically </throwit><throwit>) of the
disorder drawn from the distribution of site energies. The observables
are then configurationally averaged over these realizations.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold">Choice of Parameters.</text>
As the present model describes a situation that is in principle
accessible to experiments, the interaction strength is
chosen to yield exciton binding energies in the range of values
typical for low-dimensional semiconductor heterostructures. The
intraband couplings <throwit> and the strength of disorder </throwit><throwit>
are free parameters. However, the tight-binding model
is thought to model the conduction and valence band extremities of
a disordered semiconductor heterostructure.
In this communication we show data for </throwit><throwit>
exclusively, i.e. equal electron and hole masses are assumed.
The lattice constant, equal to a disorder length scale,
is taken to be </throwit><throwit>.
The external
optical pulse resembles typical laser pulses used in ultra-fast
optical experiments on coherent phenomena.
Its central frequency </throwit><throwit>
is chosen to be situated below the center of the
absorption band calculated
without interaction, in order to model the dynamics of
electron-hole pairs in the continuum in a range of energies that
excludes LO-phonon emission.
Specifically, the gap of the noninteracting case is the
origin of the energy axis,
the band center is at </throwit><throwit> meV,
and </throwit><throwit> meV.
For this excitation condition the sign
of the interaction is not irrelevant </throwit><throwit>. Here we use attractive
interaction throughout. A temporal pulse width
</throwit><throwit>100 fs is used corresponding to a spectral width
of 22 meV.
The number of sites </throwit><throwit> is taken
large enough (typically </throwit><throwit>) such that for not too small
disorder the locally excited wave packet does not reach the
boundary of the sample in typically some ten picoseconds. After this
time acoustic phonon scattering will lead to effective dephasing and the
coherent phenomena studied here will be destroyed. For principal
studies, however, the calculation is sometimes performed for much longer times,
although the results are no longer relevant to experiments.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">Observables.</text>
The extension of the electron and hole wave packets as a function of time
can be characterized by the above mentioned participation number
<throwit> which are single-particle quantities.
Using the pair amplitude </throwit><throwit>, the two-particle quantities
COM-coordinate
</throwit><throwit> and relative coordinate
</throwit><throwit> can be defined. Their
ratio </throwit><throwit> is a measure of the interaction induced enhancement.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">Correlated and Anticorrelated Disorder.</text>
While previous results <throwit> have been obtained using uncorrelated
disorder, here the influence of correlation is studied. Disorder
for electrons and holes is called
correlated if the site energies of electrons
equal that of the mirror image of the hole energies
with respect to the gap center. This kind of
disorder is expected in heterostructures due to
interface roughness leading to a spatially
fluctuating
confinement of single-particle wave functions.
On the other hand, if the
energy separation within an isolated site remains constant, i.e.
equal to </throwit><throwit>, the disorder
is called anticorrelated.
A spatially fluctuating electrostatic field would induce this kind of
disorder.
The present model resembles that of the
conventional single-band-TIP if electrons and holes have equal masses
and
if correlated disorder (with </throwit><throwit>)
is applied. Electron and hole
wavefunctions are then pairwise equal, both particles live in the same
environment. For </throwit><throwit> all optical matrix elements connecting these
pairs of states are equal, all others are zero. Therefore,
the optical spectrum for </throwit><throwit>
resembles the density of single-particle states, however, with
bandwidth being the sum of that of the two bands.
As in the last years the conventional TIP-model has been widely studied
we here concentrate mainly on the anticorrelated situation.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">Finite-Time Scaling.</text>
In order to quantify the enhancement finite-time scaling
is applied in the following sense. Although with a dynamical
calculation for finite times
it is impossible to decide whether the two-particle packet is
localized or not a long-time
saturation value of the COM-coordinate <throwit>
is assumed
for practical purposes. While the temporal rise of the
interaction-free traces is exponential with time scale given by that
of the pulse duration, the short time behavior in the interacting
case looks like a diffusive process. So the following interpolation
relation is used:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Figure <throwit> shows the very good quality of typical fits for
times larger than the pulse width. It is found that while the
diffusivity </throwit><throwit> is weakly dependent on disorder and interaction,
</throwit><throwit> shows a much stronger dependence. In the following </throwit><throwit>
is taken to characterize the enhancement.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">Contour Plots.</text>
Figure <throwit> shows contour plots of the
two-particle wave function,
</throwit><throwit>, for anticorrelated and correlated
disorder at time </throwit><throwit> ps. All other parameters are equal to that
used in Fig. </throwit><throwit>.
Again, the anticorrelated situation shows much larger
enhancement.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para xml:id="p18">
    <p><text font="bold">Dependence of Enhancement on Interaction Strength.</text>
Recently the dependence of the enhancement on interaction <throwit>
has been discussed and a duality relation
describing the behavior for large and small </throwit><throwit>
has been proposed </throwit><throwit>. The
present calculations yield similar results, see Fig. </throwit><throwit>
for anticorrelated disorder. The
ratio </throwit><throwit>
is close to unity for small </throwit><throwit>, while it has
a maximum around </throwit><throwit> that increases with increasing disorder. Of
course, both </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> decrease with increasing disorder, however,
</throwit><throwit> faster than </throwit><throwit>.
Remarkably, the position of the maximum does not depend on
disorder.
This behavior of
</throwit><throwit> is apparently related to the fact that for the
chosen excitation energy </throwit><throwit> the center of the
optical spectrum, indicated by the above mentioned peak,
shifts (c.f. Fig. 2) through the spectral position of the
laser pulse with changing </throwit><throwit>. Around
</throwit><throwit> the peak coincides with the excitation
energy </throwit><throwit>, while at larger </throwit><throwit> the excitation takes place again
in a region where states outside the center of the single-particle
bands are optically coupled. It is known that the enhancement is more
pronounced for less localized single-particle states </throwit><throwit>.
These states are situated in the center of the single-particle
bands. The Coulomb enhancement
is therefore largest if the
electron-hole packet is generated
in the center of the optical spectrum since the interaction
couples these weakly localized states most effectively.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para xml:id="p19">
    <p><text font="bold">Conclusions.</text>
For a situation that is in principle accessible to ultra-fast
coherent optical experiments, the delocalizing action of
the Coulomb interaction on optically generated electron-hole pairs has been
studied. The temporal traces of the center-of-mass coordinate
<throwit> and the relative coordinate </throwit><throwit> have been
fitted by an interpolation scheme describing diffusive
and localized
behavior at small and large times, respectively.
It should be noted, however,
that the calculation presented here is unable to yield definite answers about
localization or otherwise.
Correlated and anticorrelated disorder is studied and
it is found that the enhancement of </throwit><throwit>
is much more pronounced for anticorrelated
disorder.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para xml:id="p1">

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">hep-ph/0002199  SNS–PH/00–04</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Neutrino oscillations and large extra dimensions</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Abstract</text></p>
    <quote>
      <p><text fontsize="120%">Assuming that right-handed neutrinos exist and propagate in some large extra dimensions, we attempt to give
a comprehensive description of the phenomenology of neutrino oscillations. A few alternative explanations of
the atmospheric neutrino anomaly emerge, different from the standard <throwit> or </throwit><throwit> interpretations. Constraints from nucleosynthesis and supernova 1987a
are discussed.
The constraints from SN1987a indicates a maximum radius of any extra dimension of about 1 </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
    </quote>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Masses of the Goldstone modes in the CFL phase</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]</p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">of QCD at finite density</text></p>
    <p>[6ex]</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>Cristina Manuel
<throwit> and Michel H.G. Tytgat

    <p>[4ex]

    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]</p>
    <inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="top" width="398.3pt">
      <para xml:id="p2.p1">
        <p>We construct the <throwit> effective lagrangian which encodes
the dynamics of the low energy pseudoscalar excitations
in the Color-Flavor-Locking superconducting phase of QCD at finite quark density.
We include the effects of instanton-induced interactions and study the
mass pattern of the pseudoscalar mesons. A tentative comparison with the
analytical estimate for the gap suggests that some of these low energy momentum modes
are not stable for moderate values of the quark chemical potential </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract:</text><text fontsize="80%">
We consider a stochastic model of incompressible non-Newtonian fluids of second grade on a bounded domain of </text><throwit /><text fontsize="80%"> driven by Lévy noise. Applying the variational approach, global existence and uniqueness of strong probabilistic solution is established.</text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001181.xml
Para index in docroot: 15
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">The Ising model at low temperature.</text>
To proceed in understanding the structure of the bound state spectrum in the
<throwit> theory, let us address the same problem in the case of the
low temperature phase of the 3d Ising model.
The Ising model and the </throwit><throwit> theory belong to the same
universality class.
Therefore they should have the same spectrum in the critical limit.
Indeed,
in </throwit><throwit> it was shown in a Monte Carlo study
that
the two models share the same spectrum of non-perturbative
states.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para xml:id="p22">
    <p><text font="bold">Duality.</text>
Duality is usually expressed as an exact equality between partition functions
in infinite volume,
hence in
principle it does not automatically implies that the two theories must have the
same spectrum. However it can be shown that duality holds not only in the
thermodynamic limit <text font="slanted">but also for finite lattices</text>. This
correspondence is
not trivial and requires a careful analysis of the boundary
conditions of the two models <throwit>.
Since the approach to the thermodynamic limit of the finite
volume partition function is driven by the full spectrum of excited states of
the theory, the finite volume duality implies that the spectra of the two
models must coincide. In particular the bound state of quantum numbers </throwit><throwit> of
the Ising spin model coincides (hence has exactly the same mass) with the
</throwit><throwit> glueball of the gauge Ising model. This identification has two
interesting consequences.
The first one is that the Bethe-Salpeter approach to the calculation of
bound states in </throwit><throwit> theory, described above, becomes an analytical
tool to evaluate the masses of
the first states of the glueball spectrum
of the gauge Ising model. In principle
(apart from technical difficulties) this could be extended to the whole
glueball spectrum, and represents a powerful alternative to the Isgur-Paton
model, which in the case of the Ising gauge model gives rather poor
result </throwit><throwit>.
A second, more important consequence of this identification is that it gives a
possible explanation for a peculiar degeneracy observed in the Monte Carlo
estimates of the glueball masses in the 3d gauge Ising model </throwit><throwit> for
which no alternative explanation exists.
This intriguing feature of the spectrum
can be immediately appreciated by
looking at Tab. 1, (data taken from </throwit><throwit>).
In Tab. 1 the asterisks denote
the radial excitations, thus </throwit><throwit> is the lowest state in the family with
quantum numbers </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> the next one and </throwit><throwit> the third one.
</throwit><throwit> is related by duality to the single-particle state of the 3d Ising model,
</throwit><throwit> to the first bound state and so on.
The degeneracy involves the
pairs </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> (the
last one is only roughly established, it holds within the errors).
Let us stress that
this degeneracy has no obvious physical reason. The only one which we would
expect on physical grounds is the one
between </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> states (for </throwit><throwit>) (see </throwit><throwit> for a discussion of this point)
which is indeed present and has been already taken into account in Tab. 1.
Moreover it </throwit><text font="italic">is not</text> explained by the Isgur-Paton model (last column
of Tab. 1). This degeneracy seems to be a rather
deep phenomenon since it is also present in the glueball spectrum of the SU(2)
model in (2+1) dimensions.
In the third column of Tab. 1 we report the data on SU(2)
obtained by Teper <throwit> (the underlined values are our extrapolations of
the finite-</throwit><throwit> values reported in </throwit><throwit>). One can easily see that
the same pattern of
degeneracy is present both in the SU(2) and in the Ising gauge spectra.
On the contrary, all these degeneracies seem to be
lost in the </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> case (see the data reported in </throwit><throwit>).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 31
<para xml:id="p26">
    <p><text font="bold">Acknowledgements.</text>
We would like to thank M. Campostrini, A. Pelissetto, P. Rossi and E. Vicari
for fruitful discussions, and the organizers of the INTAS meeting 1999
for providing the stimulating environment in which this work was started.
This work was partially supported by the
European Commission TMR programme ERBFMRX-CT96-0045.
The work of K.Z. was supported by the PIMS Postdoctoral Fellowship and
by NSERC of Canada.</p>

    <p><text fontsize="120%">R. J. Rivers</text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00617.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
In this paper we are concerned with the contact process on the squared lattice. The contact process intuitively describes the spread of the infectious disease on a graph, where an infectious vertex becomes healthy at a constant rate while a healthy vertex is infected at rate proportional to the number of infectious neighbors. As the dimension of the lattice grows to infinity, we give a mean field limit for the survival probability of the process conditioned on the event that only the origin of the lattice is infected at <throwit>. The binary contact path process is a main auxiliary tool for our proof.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> contact process, survival probability, mean field limit.</p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=gr-qc0002082.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Effect of latent mass in inhomogeneous cosmological model with
perfect fluid and self-acting scalar field.</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>V.M. Zhuravlev<throwit>, D.A. Kornilov</throwit><throwit /></p>
    <p>Ulyanovsk State University</p>
    <p>Institute for Theoretical Physics</p>
    <p><throwit> zhuravl@sv.uven.ru</throwit></p>
    <p><throwit> kda@sv.uven.ru</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> The inhomogeneous cosmological model with matter in the form
self-acting scalar field and perfect fluid is considered. On the basis
of exact solutions is considered the evolution of density
distribution of a matter in space on a background cosmological
expansion by the Universe. Is shown, the first, in such model the
equation of a matter state is variable in time and is closely
connected to character cosmological expansions. Secondly, it is
shown with point of view of the observer the Universe looks as
space flat, but with effect of latent mass. This effect consists
in that the mass of a perfect fluid by dynamic measurements
surpasses the own mass perfect fluid that is explained by presence
scalar field.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Localized Superluminal Solutions to Maxwell Equations
propagating along a normal-sized waveguide<throwit /></text>
<throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract  –</text>  We show that localized (non-evanescent) solutions
to Maxwell equations exist, which propagate without distortion along
normal waveguides with Superluminal speed.<throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold">1. – Introduction: Localized solutions to the wave equations<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">2. – About evanescent waves<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold">3. – About some localized solutions to Maxwell equations.<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 52

    <p><text font="bold">4. – Localized waves propagating Superluminally down
(normal-sized) waveguides.<throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">MULTIPARTICLE SUSY QUANTUM MECHANICS AND THE REPRESENTATIONS OF
PERMUTATION GROUP.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Abstract.  <text font="medium">
The method of multidimensional SUSY Quantum Mechanics is applied
to the investigation of supersymmetrical
<throwit>particle systems on a line for the case of separable center-of-mass
motion. New decomposition of the superhamiltonian into block-diagonal
form with elementary matrix components is constructed. Matrices of
coefficients
of these minimal blocks are shown to coincide with matrices of irreducible
representations of permutation group </throwit><throwit> which correspond to
the Young tableaux </throwit><throwit>
The connections with known
generalizations of </throwit><throwit>particle Calogero and Sutherland models
are established.
</throwit></text></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001353.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">“Thermometers” of Speculative Frenzy</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text>   Establishing unambiguously the existence of speculative bubbles
is an on-going controversy complicated by the need of defining a model of fundamental prices.
Here, we present a novel empirical method which bypasses all the difficulties
of the previous approaches by monitoring external indicators of
an anomalously growing interest in the public at times of bubbles.
From the definition of a bubble
as a self-fulfilling reinforcing price change, we identify
indicators of a possible self-reinforcing imitation
between agents in the market. We show that during the
build-up phase of a bubble, there is a growing interest in the public for the
commodity in question, whether it consists in stocks, diamonds or coins.
That interest can be estimated through different indicators: increase in
the number of books published on the topic, increase in the subscriptions
to specialized journals. Moreover, the well-known empirical rule according to
which the volume of sales is growing during a bull market finds a natural
interpretation in this framework: sales increases in fact reveal and
pinpoint the progress of the bubble’s diffusion throughout society.
We also present a simple model
of rational expectation which maps exactly onto the Ising model on a random graph.
The indicators are then interpreted as “thermometers”, measuring the balance
between idiosyncratic information (noise temperature) and imitation (coupling) strength.
In this context, bubbles are interpreted as low or critical temperature phases,
where the imitation strength carries market prices up essentially independently of
fundamentals. Contrary to the naive conception of a bubble and a crash as times of
disorder, on the contrary, we show that bubbles and crashes are times where the concensus
is too strong!</p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nucl-th0002042.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Evidence for a New State of Matter:</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold">An Assessment of the Results from the CERN Lead Beam Programme</text></p>
    <p>Ulrich Heinz and Maurice Jacob</p>
    <p>Theoretical Physics Division, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">A common assessment of the collected data leads us to conclude that
we now have compelling evidence that a new state of matter has indeed
been created, at energy densities which had never been reached over
appreciable volumes in laboratory experiments before and which
exceed by more than a factor 20 that of normal nuclear matter.
The new state of matter found in heavy ion collisions at the SPS
features many of the characteristics of the theoretically predicted
quark-gluon plasma.</text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002153.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Charge cross-over at the <throwit>-Higgs phase transition</throwit></text></p>
    <p>[9.5ex]</p>
    <p>Filipe Freire <throwit /><throwit>
and
Daniel F. Litim </throwit><throwit /><throwit /></p>
    <p>[2ex]</p>
    <p><throwit /><text font="italic">Department of Mathematical Physics, N.U.I. Maynooth, Ireland.</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">[2ex]</text></p>
    <p><throwit /><text font="italic">School of Theoretical Physics,
Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">10 Burlington Road, Dublin 4, Ireland.</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]</p>
    <p><throwit /><text font="italic">Institut für Theoretische Physik, Philosophenweg 16</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany.</text></p>
    <p>[6ex]</p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]
<inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="398.3pt">
        <para xml:id="p2.p1">
          <p><text fontsize="90%">The type-I region of phase transitions at finite temperature of the
<throwit>-Higgs theory in 3+1 dimensions is investigated in detail using
a Wilsonian renormalisation group. We consider in particular the
quantitative effects induced through the cross-over of the
scale-dependent Abelian charge from the Gaussian to a non-trivial
Abelian fixed point. As a result, the strength of the first-order phase
transition is weakened. Analytical solutions to approximate flow
equations are
obtained, and all characteristics of the phase transition are
discussed and compared to the results obtained from perturbation
theory. In addition, we present a detailed quantitative study
regarding the dependence of the physical observables on the
coarse-graining scheme. This results in error-bars for the
regularisation scheme (RS) dependence. We find quantitative evidence
for an intimate link between the RS dependence and truncations of flow
equations.</throwit></text></p>
          <p><text fontsize="90%">PACS numbers: 11.10.Wx 11.10.Hi 11.15.Tk 05.70.Fh</text></p>
        </para>
      </inline-para></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math-ph0002047.xml

<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">SUPERSINGULAR SCATTERING</text></p>
  </para>

<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">II. Physical and reference problem</text></p>
    <p>The physical problem to be solved first is two-body scattering by a central singular potential say, <throwit> at the energy </throwit><throwit> in the channel of index </throwit><throwit>, with </throwit><throwit> representing a nonlinear parameter. The potential should fulfill the following requirements:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>In order to construct a suitable reference system for treating the
problem, we introduce a triad <throwit> of auxiliary centrifugal strengths, subject to the restrictions</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The constants <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are for the present freely chosen. The concept ’matching distance’ is defined as the positive root of the ’master equation’</throwit></p>

    </throwit><p>The radial distance <throwit> will be in general substituted for by the dimensionless radial coordinate </throwit><throwit>. We put</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Different regions of the space are distinguished as follows:</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The scattering process is governed by the radial Schroedinger equation</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>A regular-irregular pair <throwit> of its solutions behaves near the origin as</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">III. A pair of convergent expansions</text></p>
    <p>A comparison of the Schroedinger equations (2.6), set up for the exact wave function <throwit>, and Eq.(2.20), solved by the semiclassical wave function </throwit><throwit>, suggests construction of a pair of integral equations,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>The solutions <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, if exist, are solutions of the exact Schroedinger equation within the respective regions. In particular, </throwit><throwit> is uniquely defined by Eq.(3.1) and furnishes a regular solution of the differential equation (2.6) in the exponential region. The solution </throwit><throwit> of Eq.(3.2), in turn, while solving the Schroedinger equation in the trigonometric region, still involves two free constants, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, as noticed following Eq.(2.15). Smoothness requirement for the overall regular solution </throwit><throwit> at </throwit><throwit> is just sufficient to unequivocally specify these coefficients. As to the notation in (3.1)-(3.2), the residual potentials </throwit><throwit> have been defined by (2.22)-(2.24). The resolvents involved in the integral equations are formally given as</throwit></p>
    <throwit>

    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>

  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">IV. The supersingularity limit</text></p>
    <p>The term ’supersingularity’ implies in our terminology a singular
potential which is subject to the requirements (2.1). This involves, among others, that it contains a nonlinear parameter <throwit> which may increase beyond all limits. The relevant asymptotical form of the master equation (2.3) reads</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Bounded values such as <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are by the properties (2.1) obviously excluded from the large-</throwit><throwit> solutions of the Eq.(4.1). One is thus left with the only possibility that </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit>. The master equation itself reduces therefore in the supersingularity limit to</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>It is perhaps worth recalling that <throwit> while </throwit><throwit>, as implied in the set of postulates (2.1). In Eq. (4.2), in turn, the singularity parameter </throwit><throwit> and the matching radius </throwit><throwit>
vary simultaneously and both increase to infinity so as to keep the left hand side of the equation constant.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 32
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">V. Asymptotical exactness</text></p>
    <p>In the last section we studied the question whether a semiclassical expansion that is convergent at a fixed set of dynamical parameters preserves this property invariably in the supersingular limit. A further point we are left with to clear is how the structure of the series changes upon going with the nonlinear parameter to infinity. A characteristic quantity of the argument for finding the answer is the ratio of two neighboring general terms. Recall first the definition (3.11) of <throwit> along with the relevant
recursion relationships (3.14) and (3.18). For simplicity, in the present section we are going to suppress in the formulas the matching distance </throwit><throwit>. Remember it is a functional of the scattering potential </throwit><throwit> and is, in fact,
invisibly present in each quantity and expression below.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 38
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">VI. Discussion</text></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">1. Introduction</text>
In everyday life we face several complex problems, classified as
combinatorial optimization problems, the solutions of which are of great practical importance.
Research in this area tries to find different efficient techniques for finding
the extremum (maximum or minimum) values of a function of many different
independent variables [1-3].</p>
  </para>

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">AND COMPLETE POSITIVITY</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>We consider two non-interacting systems embedded in a heat bath.
If they remain dynamically independent,
physical inconsistencies are avoided only if the single-system
reduced dynamics is completely positive also beyond
the weak-coupling limit.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Complete Positivity.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark 2.1</text> In the approach to <throwit>-mesons as open quantum systems [23-26], the transpositio
n
map </throwit><throwit> is replaced by a phenomenological dynamical map </throwit><throwit> and,
in [24,26], </throwit><throwit> by </throwit><throwit>.
It can be shown [26,27,29] that </throwit><throwit> must be completely positive.
Otherwise, physically realizable initial correlated states of two K-mesons as
in (2.2) would develop negative eigenvalues.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3. Reduced Dynamics</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remarks 3.1</text>
i)
The environment must eventually be considered infinite dimensional
in order to allow for continuous spectra of <throwit> and
avoid recurrences.
The states </throwit><throwit> are thus not confined to density matrices, nor are the
expectation values</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>always expressible via a trace operation.
However, we will stick to
the density matrix notation,
the genuine case of infinitely many degrees of
freedom being easily retrieved [5-8].
ii)
The dissipative effects perturb the time-evolution of
<throwit> given by its own Hamiltonian </throwit><throwit> and are at least of second order
in the coupling </throwit><throwit>.
The weak-coupling limit consists in going from the fast-time variable
</throwit><throwit> to the slow-time variable </throwit><throwit>, with </throwit><throwit>.
The technical procedure is physically justified when
the ratio </throwit><throwit> between the characteristic time </throwit><throwit> of the
environment and the characteristic time of the
dissipative effects on </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, is small [3].
However, there might be heat bath temperatures for which
one has to retain higher powers in </throwit><throwit>,
being forced to go beyond the weak-coupling limit [15].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark 3.2</text> Despite the fact that they are the most used [1-3],
the choice of <throwit> made above and the assumption on the initial global state
cannot be generically upheld.
In particular, one cannot always benefit from a factorized initial state.
However, this is in many instances plausible, as
in the case of neutral </throwit><throwit>-mesons in a gravitational background.
Indeed, </throwit><throwit>-mesons produced in strong </throwit><throwit>-meson decays
are arguably not influenced by geometrical fluctuations of gravitational origin
.
In general, one may be forced
to adopt different projectors suited to initial states
where system </throwit><throwit> and environment </throwit><throwit> result correlated by
interactions prior </throwit><throwit> [13-17, 21].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 30
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark 3.3</text> After standard rearrangement of the integrals in (3.10b), the
whole <throwit>-th order contribution in (3.9) assumes
a typical cumulant expression [19,20].
Thermal correlation functions are expected to factorize for large
times; in such a case the cumulants vanish and allow one to
operate a Markov approximation also at </throwit><throwit>-th order in </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

the Higgs searches?</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Ruhlmann-Kleider:</text> 
The limits on tan<throwit> have been derived with two-loop leading
order calculations
of the radiative corrections and for specific values of the underlying
parameters so they cannot be regarded as absolute, even if the maximal
mixing scenario represents a difficult case. Going to next-to-leading
order two-loop
calculations, varying the underlying parameters or increasing the top
quark mass will make the excluded range in tan</throwit><throwit> decrease if not
vanish.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para align="center" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002245.xml
Para index in docroot: 1
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Renormalization group in Statistical Mechanics and</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Mechanics: gauge symmetries and vanishing beta
functions.</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic">Giovanni Gallavotti</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center">Fisica, Università di Roma 1</p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center">P.le Moro 2, 00185 Roma, Italia</p>
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text><text font="italic">Two very different problems that can be studied by renormalization group
methods are discussed with the aim of showing the conceptual unity that
renormalization group has introduced in some areas of theoretical
Physics. The two problems are: the ground state theory of a one
dimensional quantum Fermi liquid and the existence of quasi periodic
motions in classical mechanical systems close to integrable ones. I
summarize here the main ideas and show that the two treatments, although
completely independent of each other, are strikingly similar.</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> Codes over Galois rings have been studied extensively during the last three decades.
Negacyclic codes over <throwit> of length </throwit><throwit> have been characterized: the ring </throwit><throwit> is a chain ring. Furthermore, these results have been generalized to </throwit><throwit>-constacyclic codes for any unit </throwit><throwit> of the form </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. In this paper, we study more general cases and investigate all cases where
</throwit><throwit> is a chain ring. In particular, necessary and sufficient conditions for the ring </throwit><throwit> to be a chain ring are obtained. In addition, by using this structure we investigate all </throwit><throwit>-constacyclic codes over </throwit><throwit> when </throwit><throwit> is a chain ring. Necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of self-orthogonal and self-dual </throwit><throwit>-constacyclic codes are also provided. Among others, for any prime </throwit><throwit>, the structure of </throwit><throwit> is used to establish the Hamming and homogeneous distances of </throwit><throwit>-constacyclic codes.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords.</text> Constacyclic codes; Hamming distances; Repeated-root codes; Codes over rings; Galois rings; Chain rings.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">THE IRON PROJECT</text></p>
    <p>[5mm]
<text fontsize="120%">Anil K. Pradhan</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">Department of Astronomy, The Ohio State
University,</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">Columbus, Ohio, USA 43210</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00453.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>We introduce a new geometric object, the correlahedron, which we conjecture to be equivalent to stress-energy correlators in planar <throwit> super Yang-Mills. Re-expressing the Grassmann dependence of correlation functions of </throwit><throwit> chiral stress-energy multiplets with Grassmann degree </throwit><throwit> in terms of </throwit><throwit>-linear bosonic variables, the resulting expressions have an interpretation as volume forms on a </throwit><throwit> Grassmannian, analogous to the expressions for planar amplitudes via the amplituhedron. The resulting volume forms are to be naturally associated with the correlahedron geometry. We construct such expressions in this bosonised space both directly, in general, from Feynman diagrams in twistor space, and then more invariantly from specific known correlator expressions in analytic superspace. We give a geometric interpretation of the action of the consecutive lightlike limit and show that under this the correlahedron reduces to the squared amplituhedron both as a geometric object as well as directly on the corresponding volume forms. We give an explicit easily implementable algorithm via cylindrical decompositions for extracting the squared amplituhedron volume form from the squared amplituhedron geometry with explicit examples and discuss the analogous procedure for the correlators.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001174.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Chao-Shang Huang,   Liao Wei</text></p>

Para index in docroot: 6
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Recent observation of Re(<throwit>/</throwit><throwit>) by KTev collaboration
</throwit><throwit> definitely confirms the earlier NA31 experiment</throwit><throwit>. This
direct CP violation measurement in the Kaon system can be accommodated by
the CKM phase in standard model (SM) within the theoretical uncertainties.
However, the CKM phase is not enough to explain the matter-antimatter asymmetry
in the universe and gives the contribution to EDMs much smaller than the limits
of EDMs of electron and neutron. One needs to
have new sources of CP violation and examine their phenomenological effects.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">There exist new sources of CP violation in SUSY theories which come from the
phases of soft SUSY breaking parameters. It is well-known for a long time
that in order to satisfy the current experimental limits on EDMs of electron
and neutron SUSY CP-violating phases have to be much smaller(<throwit>) unless sfermion masses of the first and second generations
are very large (</throwit><throwit> 1 Tev) </throwit><throwit>. Recently it has been shown that various
contributions to EDMs cancel with each other in significant regions of the
parameter space so that the current experimental limits on the EDM of
electron (EDME) </throwit><throwit> and the EDM of neutron (EDMN) </throwit><throwit>,</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">and</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">can be satisfied for SUSY models with SUSY phases of order one and relatively
light sparticle spectrum (<throwit> 1 Tev) </throwit><throwit>. In mSUGRA even in the
parameter space where cancellation among various SUSY contributions to
neutron EDM(EDMN) happens </throwit><throwit> must be less than </throwit><throwit> for small
</throwit><throwit /><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> for large </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit>
while the allowed range of </throwit><throwit> is almost unconstrained. Brhlik et al.
pointed out that more sufficient cancellations happen in MSSM if gaugino
masses are complex </throwit><throwit>. In the letter we consider cancellation
phenomena in SUGRA with nonuniversal gaugino masses.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">CP violation has so far only been observed in K system. It is one of the goals
of the B factories presently under construction to discover and examine CP
violation in the B system. Direct CP violation in <throwit> in SM has been examined
and the result is that it is unobservablly small </throwit><throwit>. In mSUGRA the
CP assymmetry of branching ratio on </throwit><throwit>has been given in </throwit><throwit>.
A detailed analysis of SUSY contributions to CP Violation in semileptonic
B decays has been performed using the mass insertion approximation in </throwit><throwit>.
Direct CP asymmetries and the T-odd normal polarization of lepton
in </throwit><throwit> in mSUGRA with CP-violating phases are investigated in our
previous paper </throwit><throwit>. In the letter we extend the investigation to
SUGRA models with nonuniversal gaugino masses after studying the allowed
regions of the parameter space in the models by EDM data.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">In order to concentrate on the effects of the phases arising from complex
gaugino masses we limit ourself to a class of SUGRA models with nonuniversal
gaugino masses in which gaugino masses at high energy scale (GUT scale) are
nonuniversal but scalar masses and trilinear couplings at GUT scale are still
universal. Such a class of effective SUGRA models can naturally arise from
string models <throwit>. In this class of models, compared to the mSUGRA,
there are two more new independent phases </throwit><throwit> which we choose to be
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, the phases of gaugino masses </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, in
addition to the phases </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. From the one loop
renormalization group equations (RGEs) for </throwit><throwit> (i=1,2,3) </throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">where <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, we know that
the phases of </throwit><throwit> do not run, like the phase of </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Let us recall the cancellation mechanism for EDME. There are only two
contributions, the chargino (-sfermion loop) and neutrilino (-sfermion loop)
contributions, to the EDME. The chargino contribution involves gaugino
-Higgsino(g-h) mixing. The neutrilino contribution involves not only
gaugino-Higgsino mixing but also gaugino-gaugino(g-g) mixing. The chargino
contribution and the part of the neutrilino contribution which comes from
g-h mixing have automatically opposite sign because of the opposite sign of
<throwit> in chargino and neutrilino mass matrices. In general, the chargino
contribution in magnitude is significantly larger than the part of neutrilino
contribution. Therefore, as pointed out in ref. </throwit><throwit>, a cancellation
can happen only if the another part of the neutrilino contribution which
comes from the g-g mixing can balance some of the difference between the two
contributions. For EDME the neutrilino contribution which comes from the g-g
mixing is proportional to </throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="bold">Therefore, given <throwit>, the sign of the contribution can be controlled by
choosing </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> and the magnitude of the contribution
can increase by increasing </throwit><throwit> and/or </throwit><throwit>. Because the chargino
contribution is dependent on </throwit><throwit> and independent on </throwit><throwit>, it is
sufficient to have a cancellation that the magnitude of the </throwit><throwit> term
(first term) in eq.(4) is comparable to that of the </throwit><throwit> term
(second term) in eq.(4). This is easy to be down in MSSM in which </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> are free parameters. Thus, an almost exact cancellation can occur
for the whole range of </throwit><throwit>. That is exactly what happens in MSSM
 </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">However, in SUGRA models low energy properties are determined by running
RGEs from the high energy scale to the electroweak(EW) scale and the
radiative breaking mechanism of the EW symmetry puts constraints on CP-
violating phases. As long as we limit our discussion to mass spectra less than
than 1 Tev, <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>(hence </throwit><throwit>) can not be too large. For small tan
</throwit><throwit>(say </throwit><throwit>), the sufficient condition (i.e., the two
terms in eq.(4) have size of the same order) can easily be realized in the
almost whole range of </throwit><throwit> by choosing </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.
For moderate and large tan</throwit><throwit>, it is difficult for the condition to be
realized due to the limited values of </throwit><throwit> (hence </throwit><throwit>) so that only
for some limited ranges of </throwit><throwit> the EDM constraint can be satisfied.
The similar (but more complicated) situation occurs for EDMN with
appropriate </throwit><throwit> as well as </throwit><throwit> chosen.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
