Para index in docroot: 20
<para xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">In summary, we have analyzed the constraints of electric dipole moments of
electron and neutron on the parameter space in supergravity models with
nonuniversal gaugino masses. It is shown that with a light sparticle spectrum,
the sufficient cancellations in the calculation of EDMs can happen due to
the presence of the two new phases arising from complex gaugino masses,
in addition to the phases <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. With appropriate
correlation between </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> (for EDME) or </throwit><throwit> (for
EDMN) as well as an appropriate choice of </throwit><throwit>, cancellations can
occur and all phases can be order of one in the small tan</throwit><throwit> case and all
phases but </throwit><throwit> (</throwit><throwit>) order of
one in the large tan</throwit><throwit> case. This is in contrast to the case of mSUGRA
where in the parameter space where cancellations among various SUSY
contributions to EDMs happen </throwit><throwit> must be less than </throwit><throwit> for small
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> for large </throwit><throwit>. And our analysis
show that the branching ratio of </throwit><throwit> gives an extra constraint on the
phases for large tan</throwit><throwit> case with light mass spectrum. We have
calculated direct CP asymmetries and the T-odd normal polarization of lepton
in </throwit><throwit> in the regions of the parameter space in the models where the
constraints from EDMs as well as </throwit><throwit> are satisfied. It is shown that the
results for </throwit><throwit> are similar to those in mSUGRA if the mass sprectrum is
relatively heavier(</throwit><throwit>) and it is also
true for </throwit><throwit> in the small tan</throwit><throwit> case. The former is due to the
constraint from </throwit><throwit> and the latter is due to smallness of the contributions
from exchanging neutral Higgs bosons in the small tan</throwit><throwit> case. However,
in the large tan</throwit><throwit> case, </throwit><throwit> can reach </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit> and
is a few percent in most of allowed regions and can reach </throwit><throwit> in some
allowed regions for l=</throwit><throwit>. </throwit><throwit> for </throwit><throwit> is approximately equal
to </throwit><throwit> even in the large tan</throwit><throwit> case. </throwit><throwit> can reach </throwit><throwit> for
</throwit><throwit> and is in the range from </throwit><throwit> to </throwit><throwit> in most of the allowed
regions for l=</throwit><throwit> in the large tan</throwit><throwit> case. That is, there is a
significant enhancement compared to the mSUGRA in which </throwit><throwit> only can reach
about </throwit><throwit> for l=</throwit><throwit> and about </throwit><throwit> for l=</throwit><throwit>. In the small
tan</throwit><throwit> case the results are similar to those in mSUGRA.
For l=e, </throwit><throwit> is negligibly small, as it should be. </throwit><throwit /></text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">1. Introduction.<throwit /></text>The studies related to onset of chaos in one- dimensional discrete systems
modeled by nonlinear maps, have been quite intense and exhaustive during the
last two decades. Such a system normally supports a sequence of period
doublings leading to chaos. It is also possible to take it back to
periodicity through a sequence of period halvings by adding perturbations
or modulations to the original system[1,2]. This has, most often, been
reported as a mechanism for control of chaos. In addition, there are
features like tangent bifurcations, intermittency, crises etc., that occur
inside the chaotic regime and are not of immediate relevance to the present
work. However, if the system is sufficiently nonlinear, there are other
interesting phenomena like bubble structures and bistability that have
invited comparatively less attention. The simplest cases where these are
realised are maps with at least two control parameters, one that controls
the nonlinearity and the other which is a constant additive one. i.e., maps of
the type,</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>In these maps, if <throwit> is varied for a given </throwit><throwit>, the usual period doubling
route to chaos is observed. But when </throwit><throwit> is kept at a point beyond the first
period doubling point </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit> is varied, the first period doubling is
followed by a period halving forming a closed loop like structure called
the primary bubble in the bifurcation diagram(Fig(1.a)). If </throwit><throwit> is kept beyond the
second bifurcation point </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit> is tuned, secondary bubbles appear on
the arms of the primary bubble. Thus as we shift the map along the </throwit><throwit>-axis
and drift it along the </throwit><throwit>-axis, the complete bubbling scenario develops in
the different slices of the space </throwit><throwit>. This accumulates into what is
known as bimodal chaos- chaos restricted or confined to the arms of the
primary bubble. This can be viewed as a separate scenario to chaos in such
systems.</throwit><throwit>It has been confirmed that the Feigenbaum indices for this scenario with
</throwit><throwit> as control parameter would be the same as the </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> of
the normal period doubling route to chaos[3]. However, detailed RG analysis
by Oppo and Politi[4], involving the parameter </throwit><throwit> also, indicates that if
</throwit><throwit> is kept at a critical value, </throwit><throwit>, where bimodal chaos just disappears,
then there is a slowing down in the convergence rate leading to an index
which is </throwit><throwit>. This has been experimentally verified in a
</throwit><throwit> laser system with modulated losses[5].
The bubbling scenario is seen in the bifurcation diagrams of many nonlinear
systems like coupled driven oscillators[6, 7], oscillatory chemical
reactions, diode circuits, lasers[8,9], insect populations[10], cardiac
cell simulations[11], coupled or modulated maps[12,13], quasi-periodically
forced systems[14], DPCM transmission system[15] and traffic flow
systems[16] etc. The very fact that this phenomenon appears in such a wide
variety of systems makes it highly relevant to investigate and expose the
common factor(s) in them i.e., the underlying basic features that make them
support bubbles in their bifurcation scenario. The above mentioned
continuous systems require maps with at least two parameters of type (1) to
model them, the second additive parameter being the coupling strength,
secondary forcing amplitude etc. We note that in all the above referred
papers no specific mention is made regarding the mechanism of formation of
bubbles, probably because the authors were addressing other aspects of the
problem. However, there have been a number of isolated attempts to analyse
the criteria for bubble formation in a few typical systems. According to
Bier and Bountis[3], the two criteria are, the map must possess some
symmetry and the first period doubling should occur facing the symmetry
line. Later, Stone[17] makes these a little more explicit by stating that
the map should have an extending tail (with a consequent inflection point)
and the inflection point should occur to the right of the critical point of
the map. It is clear that this applies only to maps with one critical point.
The relation of the extending tail to bubbling is briefly discussed in [18]
also.</throwit><throwit>Bistability is an equally interesting and common feature associated with
many nonlinear systems like a ring laser[19] and a variety of electronic
circuits[20] .A recent renewal of interest in such systems arises from the
fact that they form ideal candidates for studies related to stochastic
resonance phenomena[21]. The bistable behaviour in two parameter maps
is shown in the bifurcation diagram in Fig(1.b). To the best of
our knowledge, attempts to study any type of conditions for the occurrence
of bistability are so far not seen reported in the literature.</throwit><throwit>Our motivation in the present work is to generalise the criteria reported
earlier for bubbling and put them together with more clarity and simplicity.
As a byproduct, we succeed in stating the conditions for bistability also
along similar lines in systems of type (1), even though these are two
mutually exclusive phenomena as far as their occurrence regime is concerned.
We provide a detailed graphical analysis, which leads to a simple and
comprehensible explanation for the same.</throwit><throwit>The paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the criteria for
bistability and bubbling are stated followed by a brief explanation.
The graphical analysis taking two simple cubic maps as examples is included
in section 3 and the concluding comments in section 4.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">2. The dynamics of bubbling and bistability<throwit /></text>For the special class of maps given in (1), the basic criteria for
bubbling / bistability can be stated as follows.<throwit /><text font="italic">The non-linearity in <throwit> must be more than quadratic.</throwit><throwit /></text>This implies that, <throwit> (the prime indicating derivative
with respect to </throwit><throwit>), is non-monotonic in </throwit><throwit> and there exists at least one
inflection point </throwit><throwit>, where</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Then we consider the following two cases.<throwit>Case (i)</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>We define a value of <throwit> as </throwit><throwit>, through the relation,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>the first period doubling point of the system. For a value of <throwit> close to
</throwit><throwit> but greater than </throwit><throwit>, by adjusting the additive parameter </throwit><throwit>, the
system can be taken through a bubble structure in the bifurcation scenario.</throwit><throwit>Case (ii)</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Here <throwit> is defined as the tangent bifurcation point of the system, through
the relation</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Then by fixing <throwit> greater than </throwit><throwit>, but close to </throwit><throwit>, and tuning </throwit><throwit>, a
bistability region can be produced in the system.</throwit><throwit>For case (i), the value of </throwit><throwit> chosen to be greater than </throwit><throwit> makes
</throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>. Moreover,
conditions (2) and (3) imply that </throwit><throwit> is a minimum for </throwit><throwit>, which
is concave upwards on both sides of </throwit><throwit>. Hence for a fixed point </throwit><throwit>
which is to the left of </throwit><throwit>, but in the immediate neighborhood, of </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>, and hence will be stable.Similarly, fixed
point </throwit><throwit> to the right of </throwit><throwit>, but near to </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> and is stable. Now, the second parameter </throwit><throwit>
is simple additive for the class of maps under consideration and hence
</throwit><throwit> is independent of </throwit><throwit>. By adjusting </throwit><throwit>, the fixed point can be
shifted such that </throwit><throwit> becomes equal to -1, the period
doubling point of the map.Then </throwit><throwit> will give rise to a 2-cycle with
elements </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. Since these are in the neighborhood of </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> will be negative so that
the product </throwit><throwit> is positive. With further
increase of </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> period merging takes place for the 2-cycle, with </throwit><throwit>
and </throwit><throwit> collapsing into </throwit><throwit>, which is just stable at the point
where </throwit><throwit>. Thus in the parameter window </throwit><throwit>, a
bubble structure is formed.</throwit><throwit>The situation is exactly reversed for case (ii). Here conditions (2) and (5)
makes </throwit><throwit> a maximum of </throwit><throwit> and the falls off on both sides of
</throwit><throwit>. At a value of </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> is defined by (6),
</throwit><throwit>. Then in the neighborhood of </throwit><throwit>, a fixed point
</throwit><throwit>, to the left of </throwit><throwit>, can be stable since
</throwit><throwit>.
Similarly </throwit><throwit> on the right of </throwit><throwit> also will be stable.By adjusting
the second parameter </throwit><throwit>, these will be shifted to their respective tangent
bifurcation points, i.e., </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit> is born and </throwit><throwit> where
</throwit><throwit> disappears. Then a bistability window is seen in the interval
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit><throwit /><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">3. Graphical analysis.<throwit /></text>The mechanism of occurrence of bubbling and bistability explained above for
maps satisfying the conditions in case (i) and case (ii) respectively can be
made more transparent through a detailed graphical analysis. For this we
plot the curve C1=<throwit>, the 1-cycle fixed point curve C2=</throwit><throwit>
and the 2-cycle curve C3=</throwit><throwit> simultaneously as functions of </throwit><throwit>, for
chosen values of </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. The zeroes of C2 give the 1-cycle fixed point
</throwit><throwit> while those of C3 give the elements of the 2-cycle. Their stability
can be checked from the same graph, since the value of the derivative at the
fixed points can be read off. We fix the value of </throwit><throwit> to be greater than </throwit><throwit>,
which helps to position the curve C1 in the proper way. By plotting the three
curves for different values of </throwit><throwit>, bistability regions or bubbling sequences
can be traced for any given map function of type (1).</throwit><throwit>For further discussion, we consider two specific forms of maps of the cubic
type, which are simple but typical examples for case (i) and (ii). They are,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p>For M1, there are two critical points, <throwit>, which is a maximum and
</throwit><throwit>, which is a minimum. The inflection point in between
occurs at </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. Hence it belongs to case (i)
and </throwit><throwit> as defined by (4) is 1. In Fig(2), the three curves mentioned above
are plotted for this map at </throwit><throwit>. We start from a value of </throwit><throwit>,
Fig(2.a) where the fixed point </throwit><throwit> is just born via tangent
bifurcation since </throwit><throwit> here is +1, and the curves C2 and C3
just touches the zero line on the left of </throwit><throwit> at </throwit><throwit>. Though C2 has
a zero on the right, the slope there is larger than 1 and hence it is
unstable, for this value of </throwit><throwit>. Since </throwit><throwit> is only additive, increase in the
value of </throwit><throwit>, shifts C2 upwards, resulting in a slow drift of </throwit><throwit> from
left to right. Thus as </throwit><throwit> is increased to -0.7(Fig(2.b)),
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> bifurcates into </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>. At </throwit><throwit>(Fig(2.c)), the 2-cycle is stable with
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, both negative and their product
is positive but less than 1. Note that the curve C3 has developed a maximum
and a minimum on both sides of </throwit><throwit>, which is now unstable, cutting the
zero line again at </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. As </throwit><throwit> is further
increased, they move apart. Since the value chosen is within the stability
window of 2-cycle no further period doubling takes place. As </throwit><throwit>
crosses </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit> move towards each other and merge together
at </throwit><throwit>(Fig(2.d)) and coincide with the fixed point </throwit><throwit>. Further,
</throwit><throwit> disappears by a reverse tangent bifurcation at </throwit><throwit>, when
</throwit><throwit> becomes equal to +1. Thus the above events lead to the
formation of a primary bubble in the window (-0.7,0.7).</throwit><throwit>By keeping </throwit><throwit> at a value beyond the second period doubling point </throwit><throwit>, of
the map, the merging tendency starts only after the second period doubling
and hence secondary bubbles are seen on the arms of the primary bubble. These
can be repeated until at </throwit><throwit>, the system is taken to chaos.</throwit><throwit>Now the above analysis is repeated for map M2, which satisfies the conditions
in case (ii) (Fig(3)). Here of the two critical points of the map,
</throwit><throwit> is the minimum and </throwit><throwit> is the maximum
with a positive slope at the point of inflection </throwit><throwit>. </throwit><throwit> in this case
is also 1. Hence in the Fig (3) </throwit><throwit> is chosen to be 1.4. Fig(3.a) shows
the situation for </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> and hence the
1-cycle fixed point </throwit><throwit> period doubles into a 2-cycle. For lower values
of </throwit><throwit>, we expect the full period doubling scenario since </throwit><throwit> is
monotonic beyond this point(Fig(3.b)). However, as </throwit><throwit> is increased to -0.1,
</throwit><throwit>, where the other 1-cycle, </throwit><throwit> to the right of
</throwit><throwit> is born by tangent bifurcation(Fig(3.c)). Note that at this point </throwit><throwit> is still
stable with </throwit><throwit>. This continues until </throwit><throwit>,
where </throwit><throwit> and hence </throwit><throwit> disappears(Fig(3.d)). The birth of
</throwit><throwit> is concurrent with the maximum of C2 touching the zero line </throwit><throwit>
while the disappearance of </throwit><throwit> occurs as the minimum of C2 touches the
zero line </throwit><throwit>. As </throwit><throwit> is increased and C2 is moving up it is clear that
the former will take place for a lower </throwit><throwit> value than the latter as the
maximum of C2 occurs for </throwit><throwit> and minimum at </throwit><throwit> (slope
being positive at </throwit><throwit>). Hence </throwit><throwit>, or there is a window </throwit><throwit>,
where bistability exists, which in our graph is (-0.1,0.1) for </throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit> is stable beyond this point also and it period doubles as </throwit><throwit> is
increased to </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit>. The full Feigenbaum
scenario then develops for higher values of </throwit><throwit>.By keeping </throwit><throwit> at higher
values and tuning </throwit><throwit>, the bistability can be taken to 2-cycle, 4-cycle and
even chaotic regions.</throwit><throwit>The stability regions of the different types of dynamical behaviour possible
for M1 can be marked out in parameter space plot in the </throwit><throwit>
plane(Fig(4.a)). The cone like region on the left is the stability zone of the
1-cycle fixed point (periodicity, p=1) and it is separated from the escape
region by the tangent bifurcation line on both sides. The parabola like
curve inside it marks out the 2-cycle (p=2) region, while the smaller
parabolas indicate curves along which 4-cycles (p=4) and other higher
periodic cycles becomes stable until chaos is reached. The line parallel to
the </throwit><throwit>-axis at a value of </throwit><throwit>, along which primary bubble is formed, is
shown by the dotted line. It is clear that along this line, the system is
taken from escape –¿ 1-cycle –¿2-cycle –¿1-cycle –¿ escape. Similarly
secondary bubbles are formed along a line drawn at </throwit><throwit> etc. The
parameter space plot for M2 is shown in Fig(4.b). The quadrilateral like
region marked as (I) beyond </throwit><throwit> is the bistable region for 1-cycle,
while quadrilateral (II) is that for 2-cycle etc. The area marked with p=1,
is the stability region of 1-cycle while p=2, that for 2-cycle etc. When
the system is taken along the dotted line beyond </throwit><throwit>, bistability is seen
in the central region, followed by period doubling bifurcations to both sides,
until chaos is reached.</throwit><throwit> </throwit><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">4. Conclusion.<throwit /></text>Although the above discussion is confined to two simple cubic maps, the
analysis is repeated for a large number of maps of type (1) chosen from a
wide variety of situations covering different functional forms like
exponential, trigonometric and polynomial maps. We find that the qualitative behaviour in all cases remain the same
and depends only on the criteria (2)-(6). Hence the pattern of scenario
detailed in this paper can be taken to be atypical as far as maps of the
form (1) are concerned.<throwit>The criteria for bistability reported here are certainly novel while those
for bubbling are more rigorous and general in nature compared to earlier
studies. They can be used as a test to identify maps in which bistability or
bubbling is possible and also to isolate the regions in the parameter space
</throwit><throwit> where they occur. Our main result is that whether it is bistability
or bubbling is decided by the sign of the third derivative of the map
function at the inflection point. If </throwit><throwit> is
positive, because of the concave nature of the derivative, tangent
bifurcation will precede period doubling as </throwit><throwit> is increased. Hence bubbling
structure is possible. Similarly when </throwit><throwit> is
negative, curve of </throwit><throwit> is convex and hence period doubling
precedes tangent bifurcation, leading to bistability. In case
</throwit><throwit>, higher derivatives must be considered for
deciding the behaviour.</throwit><throwit>Bubbling can be looked upon as an extreme case of incomplete period
doublings and the latter has been often associated with positive Schwarzian
derivative[22]. But for the system under study, it is easy to check that
this is always negative (independent of the form of the map function),
because of properties (2), (3) and (5). In fact, a few such
maps have been reported earlier[23] though in a totally different context.
The bubbling scenario in maps of the type M1, leads to bimodal chaos that
is restricted to the arms of the primary bubble. Such confined chaos or even
low periodic behavior prior to that, makes them better models in population
dynamics of eco systems than the usual logistic type maps[24]. Attempts to
extend the criteria to continuous and higher dimensional systems are
underway and will be reported elsewhere.</throwit><throwit /><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Acknowledgements<throwit /></text>SNV thanks the UGC, New Delhi for financial assistance through a junior
research fellowship and GA acknowledges the warm hospitality and computer
facility at <throwit>IUCAA, Pune.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Muon <throwit> and precision electroweak physics</throwit></text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">in the MSSM </text></p>
    <p><text font="bold">Gi-Chol Cho<throwit>, Kaoru Hagiwara</throwit><throwit> and
Masashi Hayakawa</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <p><throwit /><text font="italic">Theory Division, KEK, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-0801, Japan</text></p>
    <p><throwit /><text font="italic">Scuola Normale Superiore, Piazza dei Cavalieri 7,

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[7mm]
<inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="341.4pt">
        <para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3.p1">
          <p>The minimal supersymmetric extension of standard model (MSSM)
is examined by analyzing its quantum effects on the precision
electroweak measurements and the muon <throwit>.
We examine carefully the effects of light charginos and neutralinos
that are found to improve the fit to the electroweak data.
We identify two distinct regions on the </throwit><throwit>-plane that
fit well to the electroweak data and give significant contribution
to muon </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
        </para>
      </inline-para></p>
  </para>

    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>F. Buccella <throwit /></p>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p align="center"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Response-theory for nonresonant hole burning: Stochastic dynamics
</text></p>
    <p align="center"><text font="bold">Gregor Diezemann</text></p>
    <p align="center">Institut für Physikalische Chemie, Universität Mainz,
Welderweg 15, 55099 Mainz, FRG</p>
    <p><text font="italic">The time signals relevant for nonresonant spectral hole burning, a
pump-wait-probe method designed to investigate slow relaxation, are calculated.
The step-response function following the application of a high amplitude ac
field (pump) and an intermediate waiting period is shown to be the sum of the
equilibrium integrated response and a modification due to the preparation
via ac irradiation.
Both components are calculated for a class of stochastic dipole reorientation
models.
The results indicate that the method can be used for a clearcut
distinction of homogeneously and heterogeneously
broadened susceptibilities as they occur in the slow primary relaxation of
supercooled liquids and other disordered materials. This is because only in the
heterogeneous case is a frequency selective modification of the response
possible.
</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Fock representations from <throwit> holonomy algebras</throwit></text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text fontsize="120%">Madhavan Varadarajan</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="slanted">Raman Research Institute,
Bangalore 560 080, India.</text></p>
    <p>madhavan@rri.ernet.in</p>
    <p>November 1999</p>
    <p>ABSTRACT</p>
    <p>We revisit the quantization of <throwit> holonomy algebras using the abelian
</throwit><throwit> algebra based techniques which form the mathematical underpinnings
of current efforts to construct loop quantum gravity. In particular,
we clarify
the role of “smeared loops” and of Poincare invariance in the construction
of Fock
representations of these algebras. This enables us to critically re-examine
early pioneering efforts to construct Fock space representations of
linearised gravity and free Maxwell theory from holonomy algebras through
an application
of the (then current) techniques of loop quantum gravity.</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
  </throwit></para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001163.xml
Para index in docroot: 1
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Analytical Estimate of the
Critical Velocity for</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">Vortex Pair Creation in Trapped Bose Condensates</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">ABSTRACT :</text> We use a modified Thomas-Fermi approximation
to estimate analytically the critical velocity for the formation of
vortices in harmonically trapped
BEC. We compare this analytical estimate to numerical calculations and
to recent experiments on trapped alkali condensates.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 32
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">IV: Conclusion :</text>
In this paper we report an analytical calculation of the critical velocity
for creation of a pair of counter-rotating vortices in
harmonically-trapped,
dilute
Bose condensates. Excitation of
vortices may set the lowest limit for a superfluid critical velocity in
BEC. For the analytical calculation presented here, we
developed a modified Thomas-Fermi approximation to the standard mean-field
theory [13]. This approximation is
appropriate to the limit of large interparticle interactions, and thus
is relevant to most current experiments. The approximation consists of two
steps, described above in Section II: (i) solve a continuity equation for
the phase of the condensate wavefunction; and then (ii) insert this
solution for the phase in an equation of hydrostatic equilibrium and solve
for the condensate envelope function, ignoring the second order spatial
derivative of the envelope function. In essence, we include contributions
to the condensate kinetic energy that come from gradients of the phase (a
signature of vortices), but assume that vortex-induced gradients in the
condensate envelope function are negligible. Alternatively, one can think
of the modified Thomas-Fermi approximation as equivalent to treating
BEC like a fluid with an exotic equation of state, with the leading vortex
kinetic energy terms acting as
an effective potential. Once the envelope function is determined, we
compute approximately
the energy and integrated linear momentum (or impulse) of the vortex pair,
and determine the
critical velocity from the Landau criterion, <throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002091.xml

Para index in docroot: 12
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">A mono-velocity atomic beam</text> or uniformly moving sample
corresponds to the simple case of spatial dispersion, so-called
drift dispersion.
In the co-moving frame atoms are at rest,
there is no spatial dispersion and the group
velocity is given by the first term of Eq. (1) alone,
<throwit>.
The Galilean transformation to the laboratory frame,
</throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit> is the atomic velocity,
yields the group velocity
</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">Atoms with a thermal velocity distribution.</text>
Let us consider a stationary cell of hot atoms.
If the intensity of
the drive is strong enough to provide EIT for the resonant group of atoms
(see Fig. 4)
but at the same time weak enough to avoid an interaction with
off-resonant atoms, moving with “wrong” velocities, it is mainly
this drifting beam that
would support <text font="italic">the ultra-slow EIT polariton</text> with zero or even
negative group velocity.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00388.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract </text> In this paper, we obtain some formulae for harmonic sums, alternating harmonic sums and Stirling number sums by using the method of integral representations of series. As applications of these formulae, we give explicit formula of several quadratic and cubic Euler sums through zeta values and linear sums. Furthermore, some relationships between harmonic numbers and Stirling numbers of the first kind are established.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">Keywords</text> Harmonic number; Euler sum; Riemann zeta function; Stirling number.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">AMS Subject Classifications (2010):</text> 11M06; 11M32; 33B15</p>
  </para>

    <p class="ltx_parbox" vattach="top" width="424.0pt"><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">The exterior algebra and ‘Spin’
of an orthogonal </text><throwit /><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">-module</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Introduction</text>
Let <throwit> be a reductive algebraic Lie algebra over an algebraically closed
field </throwit><text class="ltx_markedasmath" font="symbol" fontsize="120%">𝕜</text> of characteristic zero and <throwit> is the corresponding connected
and simply connected group.
</throwit><throwit>
The symmetric algebra of a (finite-dimensional) </throwit><throwit>-module </throwit><throwit>
is the algebra of polynomial functions on the dual space
</throwit><throwit>. Therefore one can study the algebra of symmetric invariants
using geometry of </throwit><throwit>-orbits in </throwit><throwit>.
In case of the exterior algebra, </throwit><throwit>,
lack of such geometric picture results by now in absence of general structure
theorems for the algebra of skew-invariants </throwit><throwit>.
One may find in the literature several interesting results related to
skew-symmetric invariants. We only mention
Kostant’s computation for cohomology of the nilradical of
a parabolic subalgebra in </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit> and
R. Howe’s classification of “skew-multiplicity-free” </throwit><throwit>-modules
</throwit><throwit>.
But the general situation still remains unsatisfactory, and developing of
Invariant Theory in the skew-symmetric setting represents an attractive problem.
</throwit><throwit>
In this paper, we begin with describing all irreducible
orthogonal </throwit><throwit>-modules such that
</throwit><throwit> is again an exterior algebra.
It is shown that in this case either </throwit><throwit> and hence </throwit><throwit> is simple
or </throwit><throwit> has a structure of </throwit><text font="slanted">simple</text> <throwit>-graded
Lie algebra, which quickly leads to a short classification, see
Table </throwit><throwit>.
Obviously, none of the symplectic representations
(with </throwit><throwit>) can have an exterior algebra of skew-invariants.
But the situation for the representations of “general
type” is not yet clear.
</throwit><throwit>
In case </throwit><throwit> is orthogonal, a better understanding of the </throwit><throwit>-module
structure of </throwit><throwit> can be achieved through the notion of
</throwit><text font="italic">‘Spin’</text> of <throwit>. This goes as follows. Let </throwit><throwit>
be the corresponding representation. Restricting the spinor representation
of </throwit><throwit> to </throwit><throwit> gives us a </throwit><throwit>-module, which is denoted by
</throwit><throwit>. The motivation came from Kostant’s result that
</throwit><throwit> is a primary </throwit><throwit>-module;
namely, </throwit><throwit>, the
highest weight
</throwit><throwit> being the half-sum of the positive roots </throwit><throwit>.
The main property of </throwit><throwit> is that, depending on parity of
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> is isomorphic to either </throwit><throwit>
or </throwit><throwit>. It is thus interesting to find the
orthogonal </throwit><throwit>-modules, where </throwit><throwit> has a simple structure.
In general, </throwit><throwit>, as element of the representation ring, has a numerical
factor depending on the zero-weight multiplicity. Omitting this factor
yields a </throwit><throwit>-module, which is called the </throwit><text font="italic">reduced ‘Spin’</text> of
<throwit> and denoted
by </throwit><throwit>; e.g. </throwit><throwit>. In a sense, </throwit><throwit> behaves
better than </throwit><throwit>. For, regardless of parity of </throwit><throwit>,
we have </throwit><throwit>,
where </throwit><throwit> is the zero-weight multiplicity, and
</throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit>
An orthogonal </throwit><throwit>-module </throwit><throwit> is said to be </throwit><text font="italic">co-primary</text>, if
<throwit> is irreducible. In sections </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>,
a classification of the co-primary modules is obtained. To this end, we
give a geometric description of some highest weights of </throwit><throwit>.
These weights are called </throwit><text font="italic">extreme</text>. The assumption that
<throwit> has a unique extreme weight imposes strong constraints on
the weight structure of </throwit><throwit>. Using this, one shows that </throwit><throwit> must be simple
whenever </throwit><throwit> is an irreducible faithful co-primary </throwit><throwit>-module, and
that any reducible co-primary module is being obtained by iterating the
“direct sum” procedure: </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><throwit>.</throwit></p>
    <p>It is thus sufficient to classify the irreducible co-primary modules.
The resulting list appears to be rather short:</p>
  </para>

the </throwit><throwit>-invariant positive-definite scalar product in </throwit><throwit>
determined by a non-degenerate invariant bilinear form </throwit><throwit> on </throwit><throwit>.</throwit><throwit>If </throwit><throwit> is any finite set of weights, then </throwit><throwit>;
</throwit><throwit>. </throwit><throwit>If </throwit><throwit>, then </throwit><throwit> stands for the irreducible
</throwit><throwit>-module with highest weight </throwit><throwit>.
</throwit><throwit>

work was done while I was visiting Université de Poitiers. I am grateful to
this institution for the great hospitality I enjoyed there.

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">THE SUPERCOMPLEXIFICATIONS AND ODD
BIHAMILTONIANS STRUCTURES </text></p>
    <p>Z. Popowicz <throwit /></p>
    <p>Institute of Theoretical Physics, University of Wrocław</p>
    <p>pl.M.Borna 9, 50-204 Wroclaw, Poland</p>
    <p>ziemek@ift.uni.wroc.pl</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text>
The general method of the complex supersymmetrization (supercomplexifications) of the
soliton equations with
the odd (bi) hamiltonian structure is established. New version of the
supercomplexified Kadomtsev-Petvishvili hierarchy is
given. The second odd Hamiltonian operator of the SUSY KdV
equation generates the odd N=2 SUSY Virasoro - like algebra.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002074.xml

Para index in docroot: 70
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Démonstration.</text> Rappelons qu’une paire d’ouverts de Stein
<throwit> est dite de Runge si l’enveloppe holomorphe convexe de
toute partie compacte de </throwit><throwit> relativement à l’algèbre des
fonctions holomorphes sur </throwit><throwit> est compacte dans </throwit><throwit>. On sait alors que
l’image du morphisme de restriction </throwit><throwit> est
dense, et que pour tout compact </throwit><throwit> de </throwit><throwit> il existe une fonction
d’exhaustion strictement plurisousharmonique </throwit><throwit> sur </throwit><throwit> telle
que l’ensemble de niveau </throwit><throwit> vérifie </throwit><throwit>. Le théorème 3.5 se prouve en 3 étapes.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 84
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3.8.</text> Explicitons l’assertion de 3.7 : soit <throwit>
le </throwit><throwit>-nerf du recouvrement </throwit><throwit>, constitué des
intersections non vides de </throwit><throwit> des éléments de </throwit><throwit>, et

définies sur les ouverts </throwit><throwit> et localement </throwit><throwit> au dessus de </throwit><throwit>, avec les applications de cobord</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>usuelles. Alors <throwit>
est la cohomologie du complexe ainsi défini. Les espaces
</throwit><throwit>
sont naturellement munis de la topologie de la convergence en norme
</throwit><throwit> au dessus des compacts </throwit><throwit>-simples contenus dans les </throwit><throwit>

Para index in docroot: 86
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">3.9.</text> Désignons par <throwit> et </throwit><throwit> respectivement l’image de </throwit><throwit> et le noyau de </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit>avec </throwit><throwit>.
On a alors une suite exacte</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>où <throwit> est
l’adhérence dans </throwit><throwit> de </throwit><throwit>
et</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>L’espace <throwit>
est par définition un espace de Fréchet, mais
</throwit><throwit>
est muni de la topologie grossière et, s’il est non nul, la cohomologie

</throwit><throwit> des recouvrements de Stein de </throwit><throwit>. On suppose </throwit><throwit> plus

</throwit><throwit>. Alors, dans le diagramme commutatif associé </throwit><throwit>,</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>les applications verticales <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
sont des isomorphismes topologiques (d’espaces de Fréchet en ce qui
concerne </throwit><throwit>). En effet, si (pour simplifier) on désigne
par </throwit><throwit> et </throwit><throwit> les complexes de Fréchet

l’application de restriction </throwit><throwit> est continue. On a alors
une application surjective </throwit><throwit> entre
espaces de Fréchet. Le théorème de l’application ouverte montre
que cette application est ouverte, et il en est donc de même pour
l’application induite </throwit><throwit>. Ceci
montre déjà que </throwit><throwit> est un isomorphisme
topologique. L’assertion pour </throwit><throwit> et </throwit><throwit> s’en
déduit immédiatement, puisque </throwit><throwit> est la partie
grossière et </throwit><throwit> le quotient séparé de la cohomologie.
Ceci nous mène à la définition suivante.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Brane-Universe in Six Dimensions with Two Times</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Abstract</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002272.xml
Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text>
A highly constrained proposal for the origin of baryonic matter in the
universe is electroweak baryogenesis in the minimal supersymmetric
standard model (MSSM) <throwit>. Unlike many other
baryogenesis mechanisms, this one has strong prospects for being falsified
in upcoming experiments, due to its need for some light exotic particles,
notably a right-handed top squark which is lighter than the top quark
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">2.</text>
To explain the how the classical force mechanism works, we first review
the simple case of a top quark with a spatially varying complex mass
<throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. By solving the Dirac equation
</throwit><throwit> to first
order in derivatives (the WKB approximation), one finds that a particle
of energy </throwit><throwit> experiences a spin (</throwit><throwit>) dependent force</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The spin dependent part of the force has opposite sign for antiparticles,
which causes the distributions of like-helicity fermions and antifermions
to be separated in the vicinity of the wall. For relativistic particles,
we can approximate helicity by chirality, and speak of spatially varying
chemical potentials, <throwit> for the left- and right-handed
components; these are related to the asymmetry between the particle and
antiparticle densities by </throwit><throwit>. Diffusion
equations can be derived by inserting the force (</throwit><throwit>) into the
Boltzmann equation, doing an expansion in moments of the distribution
functions, and truncating the expansion. They have the form</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> is the diffusion coefficient (of order the inverse mean free
path), </throwit><throwit> is the bubble wall velocity, and </throwit><throwit> is a damping rate
representing decays or inelastic collisions of the left-handed fermions.
The source term for each species is related to the classical force through a thermal
average </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Although this looks similar to spontaneous baryogenesis <throwit>, it is
not the same; the latter arises through the collision term in the Boltzmann equation,
while ours comes from the flow term </throwit><throwit>, and we find that it gives
a somewhat larger effect.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">3.</text> When the above picture is adapted to the MSSM some
complications occur, because the quarks do not get complex masses and
hence are not directly sourced. The chargino mass matrix does contain
complex phases however, and the chiral asymmetry which develops in the
chargino sector induces one for the quarks because of the strong
coupling between Higgsinos and the top quark. This system involves not
just one, but many coupled diffusion equations. We will show that they
can, nevertheless, be reduced to a single equation by reasonable
approximations.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p17">
    <p><text font="bold">4.</text>
We have carried out the above procedure to study how the BAU depends on
the velocity of the bubble wall <throwit>, the wall width </throwit><throwit> (appearing in
the Higgs field profile as </throwit><throwit>), </throwit><throwit> (at zero temperature) and the chargino mass parameters
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. We take as our preferred values </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> GeV. We also took
</throwit><throwit> GeV and </throwit><throwit> GeV. We computed the values of </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> from the actual Feynman diagrams
and thermally averaged cross sections, and also using the results of ref. </throwit><throwit>. With our preferred parameters we find </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>
and
</throwit><throwit>.
In the following figures where certain of
these quantities are varied, those which are not specified have the above
values. It is customary to express the BAU as
a scaled ratio of baryons to photons, </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit>, and we take the
number of degrees of freedom in the MSSM to be </throwit><throwit>. Current
limits from big bang nucleosynthesis give </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 27
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">5.</text> In summary, we have presented a quantitatively
accurate analysis of the baryon asymmetry of the universe in the MSSM,
using the classical force mechanism, which allows a consistent
computation of the sources appearing in the diffusion equations. A
CP-violating force acts on Higgsinos while they cross the bubble walls
causing a particle-antiparticle separation in charginos, which then
gets partially transformed to a chiral quark asymmetry that biases
sphalerons to produce baryons. Unlike previous authors, we have not
assumed that the two components of the Higgsino, <throwit> and
</throwit><throwit>, reach complete chemical equilibrium through Yukawa and
helicity-flipping interactions, and we showed that a large enhancement
of the BAU can result, relative to what one would get this
oversimplification. Nevertheless, after carefully computing the relevant
damping rates and diffusion coefficients, and accurately solving the
transport equations, we find that it is difficult to generate the observed
baryon asymmetry unless CP violation in the </throwit><throwit> term is close to
maximal. Further details of our formalism and
calculations can be found in ref. </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 15
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Discussion</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 16
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Sherwood Parker (University of Hawaii):</text> 
Did you make any changes to the apparatus to achieve the better results
in the second run?</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 17
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Blucher:</text>  There were no fundamental changes to the detector, but
small modifications were made to improve data quality and datataking
efficiency. For data quality, the most important changes involved the
drift chamber system.
The drift chamber electronics
were improved to have higher gain and lower
noise to reduce the chamber inefficiency. The two upstream drift chambers
were also restrung because of damage sustained during the 1996-1997 run.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p9">
    <p><text font="bold">B. F. L. Ward (University of Tennessee):</text> 
Is there any understanding of why there may have been a systematic
bias in the earlier
measurement that caused it to miss the higher value of
Re<throwit>?</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold">Blucher:</text> 
As mentioned earler,
we have studied the E731 analysis and have not found any evidence
of a systematic problem. For example,
comparisons of data and Monte Carlo <throwit> distributions for
E731 </throwit><throwit>,
similar to
those shown for KTeV in Fig. </throwit><throwit>, do not show any sign of an
acceptance problem.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 20
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">Mario Calvetti (INFN, Florence):</text> 
In your analysis, you rely on the Monte Carlo
acceptance corrections to the first order. Why is this
preferable to the method of NA48; that is,
reweighting the events in order
to have similar longitudinal vertex distribution?</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p12">
    <p><text font="bold">Blucher:</text> 
The NA48 procedure sacrifices statistics to reduce the required acceptance
correction, while
the KTeV procedure maximizes the statistical power of the data sample, but
requires that the detector acceptance be understood.
We believe that we have a reliable procedure to estimate the systematic
error
associated with our acceptance correction. As a cross check,
we have analyzed our data
with an alternate technique that compares vacuum and
regenerator beam <throwit> distributions
directly, eliminating the need for a
Monte Carlo acceptance correction. This analysis gives a
consistent value of </throwit><throwit> but with a
significantly larger statistical error.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=gr-qc0002029.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Evolution of the Quantum Friedmann Universe
Featuring Radiation</text> <throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">V. V. Kuzmichev</text> <throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> The classical and quantum models of the
Friedmann universe originally filled with a scalar field and
radiation have been studied. The radiation has been used to
specify a reference frame that makes it possible to remove
ambiguities in choosing the time coordinate. Solutions to the
Einstein and Schrödinger equations have been studied under the
assumption that the rate of scalar-field variation is much less
than the rate of universe expansion (contraction). It has been
shown that, under certain conditions, the quantum universe can be
in quasistationary states. The probability that the universe goes
over to states with large quantum numbers owing to the interaction
of the scalar and gravitational fields is nonzero. It has been
shown that, in the lowest state, the scale factor is on order of
the Planck length. The matter- and radiation-energy densities in
the Planck era have been computed. The possible scenarios of
Universe evolution are discussed.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001241.xml

</text></p>
  </para>

to measure the valence

<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Orbifold projection in supersymmetric QCD at <throwit /></text></p>
    <p>S. L. Dubovsky<throwit /></p>
    <p><text fontsize="90%">Institute for Nuclear Research of
the Russian Academy of Sciences,</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="90%">60th October Anniversary
Prospect, 7a, 117312 Moscow, Russia
</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> Recently, a new approach to the dynamics of strongly
coupled gauge theories based on the correspondence between large <throwit> theories
and supergravity in higher dimensions has been
suggested </throwit><throwit>. One of impressive results obtained
within this approach is a relation between Green’s functions of two
different gauge theories in the large </throwit><throwit> limit. The relation holds
provided the gauge and matter contents are related by
the so called “orbifold projection”. Then all Green’s functions of the
projected (daughter) theory are equal to certain Green’s functions of
the original (parent) theory.
Suggested in the framework of string theory
</throwit><throwit>, this relation has been later supported
by diagrammatic analysis at the level of field theory
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11

some positive integer. By the large </throwit><throwit> limit we mean the limit
</throwit><throwit>, with </throwit><throwit> kept constant.

projection can be found in Refs. [2–7].
Let us describe its specific version </throwit><throwit>

    <p><text font="bold">6.</text> To conclude, we have considered orbifold projection of SQCD
with relatively small number of quark flavors. It was found that in
the case of stabilized run-away vacuum, the orbifold projection serves
as a non-trivial check of the commutativity of the large <throwit> and
infrared limits.</throwit></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nlin0001030.xml
Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
The dynamics of a model, originally proposed for a type of instability in
plastic flow, has been investigated in detail. The bifurcation portrait of
the system in two physically relevant parameters exhibits a rich variety of
dynamical behaviour, including period bubbling and period adding or Farey
sequences. The complex bifurcation sequences, characterized by Mixed Mode
Oscillations, exhibit partial features of Shilnikov and Gavrilov-Shilnikov
scenario. Utilizing the fact that the model has disparate time scales of
dynamics, we explain the origin of the relaxation oscillations using the
geometrical structure of the bent-slow manifold. Based on a local analysis,
we calculate the maximum number of small amplitude oscillations, <throwit>,
in the periodic orbit
of </throwit><throwit> type, for a given value of the control parameter. This further leads
to a scaling relation for the small amplitude oscillations. The incomplete
approach to homoclinicity is shown to be a result of the finite rate of
‘softening’ of the eigen values of the saddle focus fixed point. The latter
is a consequence of the physically relevant constraint of the system which
translates into the occurrence of back-to-back Hopf bifurcation.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">PACS number(s):</text> 05.45.Ac, 83.50.-v, 62.20.-x<throwit /></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords :</text> Portevin - Le Chatelier effect, chaos, stick-slip dynamics, slow
manifold, mixed mode oscillations, homoclinic bifurcation.</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Dirac–Maxwell Solitons</text></p>
    <p>[18pt]</p>
    <p>C. Sean Bohun<throwit> and F. I. Cooperstock</throwit><throwit /></p>
    <p>[3pt]</p>
    <p>1)
<text font="typewriter">Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Victoria,</text></p>
    <p><text font="typewriter">P.O. Box 3045, Victoria, B.C., Canada V8W 3P4</text></p>
    <p>2)
<text font="typewriter">Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Victoria,</text></p>
    <p><text font="typewriter">P.O. Box 3055, Victoria, B.C., Canada V8W 3P6</text></p>
    <p><text font="typewriter">[18pt]
</text>
ABSTRACT</p>
    <p>[6pt]
<inline-block class="ltx_parbox" vattach="middle" width="264.0pt">
        <p>Detailed analysis of the coupled Dirac-Maxwell equations and the
structure of their solutions is presented.
Numerical solutions of the field equations in the case of spherical
symmetry with negligible gravitational self-interaction reveal the
existence of families of solitons with electric field dominance
that are completely determined by the observed charge and mass of the
underlying particles. A soliton is found which has the charge and mass
of the electron as well as a charge radius of <throwit>. This is
well within the present experimentally determined upper limit of
</throwit><throwit>. Properties of these particles as well as
possible extension to the work herein are discussed.</throwit></p>
      </inline-block></p>
    <p>[18pt]</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0002194.xml
Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">The BPT formula:</text>
Consider a scatterer connected to
leads that terminate at electron reservoirs. All the reservoirs are
initially at the same chemical potential and at zero temperature.
The scatterer is described by its (on-shell) <throwit> matrix, which, in
the case of </throwit><throwit> channels is an </throwit><throwit> matrix parameterized
by the energy and other parameters associated with the adiabatic
driving of the system (e.g. gate voltages and magnetic fields).</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Derivation:</text> Every unitary <throwit> matrix can be
expressed in the form:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where
<throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.
In terms of these parameters, Eq. (</throwit><throwit>) reads</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

Para index in docroot: 23
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">Geometrical interpretation:</text> <throwit> is the
1-form (vector potential) associated with Berry’s phase</throwit><throwit>. If we define the
unit spinor </throwit><throwit> then</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The set of all spinors <throwit> is a 3-sphere (since </throwit><throwit>), while
the set of all ratios </throwit><throwit> is the projective space </throwit><throwit>.
The natural map between them, namely </throwit><throwit>,
is called the Hopf fibration, and </throwit><throwit> is called the
“global angular form”
of this fibration.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 28
<para xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold">Statistics of weak pumping:</text> Next we consider how a random
scatterer transports charge when two parameters are varied gently
and cyclically. More precisely, we consider the charge
transported by moving along the circle <throwit>, </throwit><throwit> in parameter space. If
</throwit><throwit> is small, then the charge transport is close to </throwit><throwit>,
evaluated at the origin, where </throwit><throwit> are the tangent
vectors associated with the parameters </throwit><throwit>. The vectors
</throwit><throwit> map to random vectors on </throwit><throwit>, which we assume to
be Gaussian with covariance </throwit><throwit>. The problem is then to
understand the possible values of the curvature </throwit><throwit> applied
to two random vectors.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 38
<para xml:id="p31">
    <p><text font="bold">Hard Pumping:</text> Finally, we consider what happens for hard
pumping. Here one can no longer evaluate the curvature at a point
and multiply by the area. One needs to honestly integrate the
curvature. Hard pumping was addressed by <throwit> who
studied it in the context of random matrix theory and showed,
using rather involved diagrammatic techniques, that pumping scales
like the root of the perimeter. Here we shall describe a
complementary, elementary result that holds provided the </throwit><throwit> matrix
is a periodic function of the parameters. This is the case, for
example, when the pumping is driven by two Aharonov-Bohm fluxes.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00610.xml
Para index in docroot: 8
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> We present an approach for real-time change detection in the transient phases of complex dynamical systems based on tracking the local phase and amplitude synchronization among the components of a univariate time series signal derived via Intrinsic Time scale Decomposition (ITD)–a nonlinear, non-parametric analysis method. We investigate the properties of ITD components and show that the expected level of phase synchronization at a given change point may be enhanced by more than 4 folds when we employ multiple intrinsic components. Next, we introduce a concept of maximal mutual agreement to identify the set of ITD components that are most likely to capture the information about dynamical changes of interest, and define an InSync statistic to capture this local information. Extensive numerical as well as real-world case studies involving benchmark neurophysiological processes and industrial machine sensor data suggest that the present method can detect sharp change points and second/higher order moment shifts with average sensitivity of 91% as compared to approximately 30% for other contemporary methods tested on the case studies presented.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para align="center" class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> Phase synchronization, Change detection, Nonlinear and nonstationary systems</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 18
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Supplemental Material:</text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.00424.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> The maximum principle forms an important qualitative property of second order elliptic equations, therefore its discrete analogues, the so-called discrete maximum principles (DMPs) have drawn much attention. In this paper DMPs are established for nonlinear surface finite element problems on Riemannian manifolds, corresponding to the classical pointwise maximum principles on surfaces in the spirit of Pucci et al. Various real-life examples illustrate the scope of the results.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> nonlinear elliptic problems on surfaces, maximum
principle, discrete maximum principle, finite element method, simplicial
mesh.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Mathematical Subject Classification:</text> 35B50, 35J65, 65N30, 65N50</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001149.xml
/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math-ph0001026.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Graph-Laplacians and Dirac Operators on (Infinite) Graphs</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">and the Calculation of the Connes-Distance-Functional</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Manfred Requardt </text></p>

Para index in docroot: 34
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">Discussion</text></p>
    <p>The arguments presented above indicate that all 2D <throwit> models possess
a massless phase. (This situation contradicts common wisdom. Evidence
in favor of the latter is analyzed separately [10] and found wanting.)
The arguments moreover suggest that although at large </throwit><throwit> extended
topological defects - instantons - may exist in non-Abelian models, they
are supressed entropically with respect to spin waves. This situation,
already conjectured by the author in 1986 [11], suggests that for</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>the 2-point function may behave as</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>I have no basis at the present time to estimate <throwit>
and </throwit><throwit>, nor whether </throwit><throwit> depends on </throwit><throwit> in any given model. However, it could be that </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are such that at intermediate distances the decay is exponential to a very good approximation (a similar effect governs the time evolution of a
metastable state in nonrelativistic quantum mechanics [12]).</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-th0001095.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p align="center"><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Conformal Anomaly and Large</text></p>
    <p align="center"><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">Scale Gravitational Coupling</text></p>
    <p align="center"><throwit /><throwit> ,
 </throwit><throwit /><throwit /></p>
    <p align="center"><text fontsize="90%">Department of Physics, Sh. Beheshti University, Evin,
Tehran 19839, Iran.</text></p>
    <p>In the absence of a full theory of quantum gravity, one of the
theoretical frameworks in which we may improve our understanding of quantum
processes in a gravitational field is a semiclassical approximation. In
this framework the matter is described by quantum field theory while
the gravitational field itself is regarded as a classical
object. The gravitational coupling of a quantum field is then investigated
through the study of the quantum stress-tensor, i.e. the expectation
value of the stress-tensor of the
quantum field taken in some physical state. However, since
the quantum stress-tensor contains singularities, some
renormalization prescriptions <throwit> are used to obtain a meaningful
expression. One
of the most remarkable consequences of these
prescriptions is the so called conformal anomaly. This means that the trace
of the quantum stress-tensor of a conformal invariant field
obtains a nonzero
expression while the trace of the classical stress-tensor vanishes
identically. The appearance of a nonvanishing trace may be regarded as
the breackdown of conformal symmetry. Since the conformal
invariance of a theory reflects its invariance under rescaling
of lengths, one may expect that the anomalous trace of the quantum
stress-tensor may somehow be related to a scale of length.</throwit><throwit>The purpose of this note is to establish this relation by connecting the
trace anomaly with a cosmological constant. We shall deal with this possibility
by making a distinction between the trace anomaly and the traceless part
of the quantum stress-tensor. Such a distinction is suggested by the results
of the renormalization theory, although there is an alternative motivation
which can be found in </throwit><throwit>. In this way a simple dynamical model is
introduced in which the traceless part is characterized by the
stress-tensor of a conformal invariant scalar field. In this model, it is
possible to rescale the trace anomaly and convert it into a cosmological
length. The conformal symmetry
is then broken by this cosmological length and a preferred conformal frame is
determined in which the Einstein field equations with a cosmological
constant are established.</throwit><throwit>Let us begin with the results of renormalization of a quantum stress-tensor
</throwit><throwit> for a quantum scalar field conformally coupled with a
background metric </throwit><throwit /><throwit> </throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 21
<para xml:id="p18">
    <p><text font="bold">Four supersymmetries exact / Four supersymmetries broken.</text>
If we put equal to zero all central charges, appearing
in the algebra, then no partial breaking of supersymmetry
is possible. In this case, all supersymmetries are exact,
if the energy of the ground state is zero; otherwise all of them are
broken. This statement is obviously independent of the number of
dimensions <throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 22

considered earlier <throwit> in the framework of one-dimensional
</throwit><throwit> SUSY QM, but we shall describe it for completeness as well.
Consider the one – dimensional (</throwit><throwit>) </throwit><throwit> SUSY QM and put all
the constants entering into the right – hand sides
of (</throwit><throwit>) – (</throwit><throwit>)
equal to zero, except </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>.
Then, the algebra (</throwit><throwit>) – (</throwit><throwit>) takes the form</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>It means that if the energy of the ground state is equal
to <throwit> and the last-mentioned product is positive,
then </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> supersymmetries are exact, while the other
two are broken. If </throwit><throwit> is negative, then
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> supersymmetries are exact provided the energy of the
ground state is equal to </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0001106.xml
Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="207%">Reflexive polyhedra, weights and</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="207%">[4mm]toric Calabi–Yau fibrations</text></p>
    <p>[5mm]
Maximilian KREUZER<throwit /></p>
    <p>[2mm]
Institut für Theoretische Physik, Technische Universität Wien</p>
    <p>Wiedner Hauptstraße 8–10, A-1040 Wien, AUSTRIA</p>
    <p>[2mm] and</p>
    <p>[2mm] Harald SKARKE<throwit /></p>
    <p>[1mm] Humboldt Universität zu Berlin, Institut für Physik, QFT,</p>
    <p>Invalidenstraße 110, D-10115 Berlin, GERMANY</p>
    <p>[5mm]
<text font="bold">ABSTRACT </text></p>
    <p>[4mm] <inline-block class="ltx_parbox" vattach="middle" width="426.8pt">
        <p>During the last years we have generated a large number of data related to
Calabi–Yau hypersurfaces in toric varieties which can be described by
reflexive polyhedra. We classified all reflexive polyhedra in three dimensions
leading to K3 hypersurfaces and have nearly completed the four dimensional case
relevant to Calabi–Yau threefolds.
In addition, we have analysed for many of the resulting spaces whether they
allow fibration structures of the types that are relevant in the context of
superstring dualities.
In this survey we want to give background information both on how we obtained
these data, which can be found at our web site, and on how they may be used.
We give a complete exposition of our classification algorithm at a
mathematical (rather than algorithmic) level. We also describe how fibration
structures manifest themselves in terms of toric diagrams and how we
managed to find the respective data.
Both for our classification scheme and for simple descriptions of fibration
structures the concept of weight systems plays an important role.</p>
      </inline-block></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nucl-th0002004.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">TEMPERATURE, CHEMICAL POTENTIAL</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">AND THE <throwit>–MESON</throwit></text></p>
    <p>[2mm]
C.D. ROBERTS and S.M. SCHMIDT</p>
    <p>[5mm]
<text font="italic" fontsize="90%">Physics Division, Argonne National Laboratory,</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="90%">Argonne IL 60439-4843, USA</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic" fontsize="90%">[8mm] </text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction.</text>    Models of QCD must
confront nonperturbative phenomena such as confinement, dynamical chiral
symmetry breaking (DCSB) and the formation of bound states. In addition, a
unified approach should describe the deconfinement and chiral symmetry
restoring phase transition exhibited by strongly-interacting matter under
extreme conditions of temperature and density. Nonperturbative
Dyson-Schwinger equation (DSE) models <throwit> provide insight
into a wide range of zero temperature hadronic phenomena; e.g., non-hadronic
electroweak interactions of light- and heavy-mesons </throwit><throwit>, and diverse
meson-meson </throwit><throwit> and meson-nucleon </throwit><throwit> form factors. This
is the foundation for their application at
nonzero-(</throwit><throwit>) </throwit><throwit>,</throwit><throwit>-</throwit><throwit>. Herein we
describe the calculation of the deconfinement and chiral symmetry restoring
phase boundary, and the medium dependence of </throwit><throwit>-meson properties. We
also introduce an extension to describe the time-evolution in the plasma of
the quark’s scalar and vector self energies based on a Vlasov equation.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Dyson-Schwinger Equation at
Nonzero-(<throwit>).</throwit></text>    The dressed-quark DSE at
nonzero-(<throwit>) is</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, and </throwit><throwit> is the quark’s Matsubara frequency.
The complex-valued scalar functions: </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, depend only on
</throwit><throwit>. With a given dressed-gluon propagator the
solutions are determined by</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where herein we only consider models where <throwit>. It is the interplay
between the functions </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> that leads to confinement, realised via the
absence of a Lehmann representation for the dressed-quark </throwit><throwit>-point
function </throwit><throwit>,</throwit><throwit>-</throwit><throwit>. </throwit><throwit> in the
chiral limit signals DCSB.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">3. Nonequilibrium
Application.</text>    The time evolution of the self energies
can be studied using Vlasov’s equation</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Solving this equation is complicated for two reasons. (i) The energy is a
functional of the scalar and vector self energies, which in general are
nonzero and momentum-dependent. While the scalar self energy is small in the
plasma phase due to chiral symmetry restoration, the vector self energy
remains significant <throwit>. (ii) The absence of a Lehmann
representation for the dressed-quark propagator in the confined phase
precludes the existence of a single particle distribution function, </throwit><throwit>, in
this phase. Therefore a conventional kinetic theory is only reasonable in
the deconfined phase. This situation is adequately represented in DSE
models; e.g., Refs. </throwit><throwit> describe a quark’s </throwit><throwit>-evolution
from a confined to a propagating mode, and Ref. </throwit><throwit> makes use of
this evolved quasiparticle behaviour in calculating the plasma’s
thermodynamic properties. Therefore, approaching the phase boundary from the
plasma domain we anticipate a discontinuous disappearance of the quark
distribution function, </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center.
S.M.S. acknowledges financial support from the A. v. Humboldt foundation.</p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract.<text font="medium"> A pre-Lie algebra is a vector space <throwit>
endowed with a bilinear product </throwit><throwit>
satisfying the relation </throwit><throwit>. We give an
explicit combinatorial description in terms of rooted trees of the operad associated to this type
of algebras and prove that it is a Koszul operad.
</throwit></text>Mathematics Subject Classifications (2000): <text font="medium">18D50, 17B60, 17D65, 05C05.

    <p><text fontsize="144%">S.B. Gerasimov</text></p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.01204.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="398.3pt" xml:id="p1">
    <p align="center"><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract</text><text fontsize="80%" /></p>
    <p><text fontsize="80%">We study the ergodicity of stochastic reaction-diffusion equation driven by subordinate Brownian motions.
After establishing the strong Feller property and irreducibility of the system, we prove the tightness of the solution’s law. These properties imply that this stochastic system admits a unique invariant measure according to Doob’s and Krylov-Bogolyubov’s theories.
Furthermore, we establish a large deviation principle for the occupation measure of this system by a hyper-exponential recurrence criterion. It is well known that S(P)DEs driven by </text><throwit /><text fontsize="80%">-stable type noises do not satisfy Freidlin-Wentzell type large deviation, our result gives an example that
strong dissipation overcomes heavy tailed noises to produce a Donsker-Varadhan type large deviation as time tends to infinity.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Keywords</text><text fontsize="80%">: Stochastic reaction-diffusion equation; Subordinate Brownian motions; Large deviation principle (LDP); Occupation measure.</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Mathematics Subject Classification (2000)</text><text fontsize="80%">:  60F10, 60H15, 60J75.</text></p>
  </para>

<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Gamma-Ray Bursts in the 1990’s –</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">[0.2cm]
a Multi-wavelengths Scientific Adventure<throwit /></text></p>
