Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">On a Planarity Criterion</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">[1ex]
Coming from Knot Theory</text></p>
    <p>[3ex]
<text fontsize="120%">Jörg Sawollek<throwit /></text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="120%">[1ex]
January 25, 2000 (revised: August 29, 2002)</text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0001057.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction.   </text>
It is probably impossible to present an interpretation of quantum
mechanics in unambiguous way without writing equations. Chalmers’s presentation of
Everett-style interpretation also can be understood in different
ways. Instead of equations Chalmers used some technical jargon of
quantum theory, however, some words like “substates” have no clear
meaning even for physicists. Byrne and Hall (BH) interpreted
Chalmers’s jargon in a way which leads to contradictions. In this
note I will argue that by taking a more positive approach, one can see
in Chalmers’s writing a consistent (although not necessarily very
persuasive) argument.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">3. An alternative interpretation of Chalmers.   </text>
It is possible to read Chalmers in another way such
that the contradictions of the type described in the previous section do not arise. Let us make the following
modification of the OPUS principle:</p>
    <quote>
      <p>OPUS<throwit>“If a computation is implemented by a system in a
maximal physical state </throwit><throwit> </throwit><text font="italic">which is not a superposition</text>, it
is also implemented by a system in a superposition of <throwit> with
orthogonal physical states”(Chalmers, 350)</throwit></p>
    </quote>
    <p>This modified principle can be applied to <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, but it cannot
be applied to </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> and, therefore, one cannot reach the
contradiction described above as well as the contradictions
described by BH.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 21
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">4. Byrne and Hall against </text><text font="italic">any</text><text font="bold"> Everett-style interpretation.   </text>
BH start their argument by pointing out that
the orthodox quantum theory and the Everett interpretation formally
defined on the same “family of state spaces” and that the difference
is only
in dynamics.
Then they say that because of the difference in dynamics it
does not follow that the quantum state corresponding to a particular
experience in the orthodox theory will correspond to the same belief
(if at any) in the framework of the Everett theory.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001189.xml

L.McLerran,M.Strikman and I.Zahed for helpful discussions.
The work is partly supported by
the US DOE grant No. DE-FG02-88ER40388.</p>
  </para>

  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 47
<para align="left" xml:id="p43">
    <p><text font="bold">A. The protocols</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 49
<para xml:id="p45">
    <p><text font="bold">Protocol 1</text><text font="italic" /></p>
    <enumerate xml:id="S0.I1">
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i1">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i1.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center measures his GHZ particle in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction and obtains the result
</text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic" /></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i2">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i2.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center tell Alice and Bob his measurement results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i3">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i3.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob make respectively the random measurement on their GHZ particles, either in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i4">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i4.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Check the eavesdropping by using the correlation properties of the GHZ states.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i5">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i5.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob compare their bases. If their measurement bases are same, Alice and Bob keep their results, otherwise they discard their results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I1.i6">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I1.i6.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob obtain the final key by using the data sifting, the error
correction and the privacy amplification technologies.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
    </enumerate>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 55
<para xml:id="p51">
    <p><text font="bold">Protocol 2</text><text font="italic" /></p>
    <enumerate xml:id="S0.I2">
      <item xml:id="S0.I2.i1">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I2.i1.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center measures his GHZ particle either in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction and obtains any of the four states </text><throwit /><text font="italic" /></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I2.i2">

        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I2.i3.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob make respectively a random measurement on their GHZ particles, either in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I2.i4">
        <throwit>

          <p><text font="italic">Checking the eavesdropping like protocol 1.</text></p>
        </para>

        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I2.i5.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob compare their bases. If the center’s result is </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or
</text><throwit /><text font="italic"> and their measurement bases are same, or if the center’s result is </text><throwit /><text font="italic">
or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> and their measurement bases are different, Alice and Bob keep their results,
otherwise they discard the results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I2.i6">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I2.i6.p1">

        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I2.i7">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I2.i7.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob gain the final key by using the data sifting, the error
correction and privacy amplification technologies.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
    </enumerate>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 59
<para xml:id="p55">
    <p><text font="bold">Protocol 3</text><text font="italic" /></p>
    <enumerate xml:id="S0.I3">
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i1">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i1.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob make respectively a random measurement on their GHZ particles,
either in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i2">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i2.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob send their measurement bases (</text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic">) to the center, but not
the qubit values.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i3">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i3.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center randomly measures his particle according to Alice’s and Bob’s
measurement bases.
If both Alice and Bob measure their particle using the same measurement basis,
e.g. </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction, the center measures his particle using the </text><throwit /><text font="italic">
measurement basis, otherwise, the center measures his particle using the </text><throwit /><text font="italic">
measurement basis.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i4">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i4.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center announces his measurement results, which is any of the four states
</text><throwit /><text font="italic">.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i5">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i5.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Check eavesdropping like the protocol 1.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i6">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i6.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob judge the quantum state each other according to table III.
While the center announces his results, both Alice and Bob know the center’s
results. Then the Alice’s (Bob’s)
and the center’s results can jointly determine what is the Bob’s (Alice’) measurement outcome.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I3.i7">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I3.i7.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob obtain a sharing key by using the data sifting, the error
correction and privacy amplification technologies.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
    </enumerate>
  </para>

<para align="left" xml:id="p57">
    <p><text font="bold">B. security analysis</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 63

    <p><text font="bold">3. The entanglement attacks</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 70

    <p><text font="bold">IV. Bell-nQKD protocols</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 72
<para align="left" xml:id="p68">
    <p><text font="bold">A. protocol</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 74
<para xml:id="p70">
    <p><text font="bold">Protocol 4</text><text font="italic" /></p>
    <enumerate xml:id="S0.I4">
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i1">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i1.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center prepares a set of two-particle entanglement pairs and projects each pair onto any of the four Bell bases.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i2">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i2.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center sends respectively Alice and Bob one of the two-particles entanglement
and his measurement results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i3">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i3.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob make respectively the random measurement on their particle, either
in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i4">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i4.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob check the eavesdropping by using the correlation of Bell states.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i5">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i5.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">If their measurement bases are same, Alice and Bob keep their results, otherwise they discard the results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I4.i6">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I4.i6.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob obtain a sharing key by using the data sifting, the error
correction and the privacy amplification technologies.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
    </enumerate>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 77
<para xml:id="p73">
    <p><text font="bold">Protocol 5</text><text font="italic" /></p>
    <enumerate xml:id="S0.I5">
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i1">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i1.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center prepares a set of two-particle entanglement pairs and projects each pair onto any of the four bases </text><throwit /><text font="italic">.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i2">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i2.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">The center sends respectively Alice and Bob one of the two-particles entanglement
and his measurement results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i3">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i3.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob make respectively the random measurement on their particle, either
in the </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> or </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> direction.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i4">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i4.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Check the eavesdropping by using the correlation demonstrated in Table II.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i5">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i5.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob compare their bases. If the center’s result is one of the Bell states </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> and their measurement bases are same, or if the
center’s result is one of the states </text><throwit /><text font="italic"> and
their measurement bases are different, Alice and Bob keep their results,
otherwise they discard the results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i6">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i6.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice makes her results be consistent with Bob’s results.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
      <item xml:id="S0.I5.i7">
        <throwit>
        </throwit><para xml:id="S0.I5.i7.p1">
          <p><text font="italic">Alice and Bob obtain a sharing key by using the data sifting, the error
correction and privacy amplification technologies.</text></p>
        </para>
      </item>
    </enumerate>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Debye screening and Meissner effect in a two-flavor
color superconductor</text></p>
    <p>[1cm]
Dirk H. Rischke</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic">RIKEN-BNL Research Center</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, U.S.A.</text></p>
    <p><text font="italic">email: rischke@bnl.gov</text></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><throwit>
  </throwit></para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=cond-mat0001315.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Introduction.</text>
The electron localization properties of disordered solids are of high
interest both experimentally and theoretically. A simple approach to
this problem is given by the Anderson model of localization. In this
model one considers a single electron on a lattice with <throwit> sites
described by the Hamiltonian</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>where <throwit> denotes the Wannier states at site </throwit><throwit>. Disorder is
usually introduced by varying the onsite potential energies
</throwit><throwit> randomly in the interval </throwit><throwit>. In this work we
report on the effects of additional off-diagonal disorder
</throwit><throwit>, i.e., with random hopping elements
</throwit><throwit> between nearest neighbor sites.
Thus </throwit><throwit> represents the center and </throwit><throwit> the width of the uniform
off-diagonal disorder distribution. The energy scale is set by keeping
</throwit><throwit> fixed. This kind of disorder is similar to the random flux
model </throwit><throwit>, but here the modulus of the </throwit><throwit> is
random while the phase is constant. The Hamiltonian (</throwit><throwit>)
has a chiral symmetry on a bipartite lattice, i.e., under the
operation </throwit><throwit>, the Hamiltonian </throwit><throwit>
changes it sign and as a consequence, if </throwit><throwit> is an eigenvalue
of </throwit><throwit>, then so is </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Localization lengths at the 1D Dyson singularity.</text>
In 1D it has been shown that the density of states (DOS) of the
disordered model diverges at <throwit> </throwit><throwit>, if </throwit><throwit> on a
bipartite lattice </throwit><throwit>. This singularity is
intimately related to a divergence of the localization length
</throwit><throwit>. Assuming that the localization
properties of the wave function can be described as usual by an
exponential decay, one finds analytically </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with <throwit> the Fermi velocity and </throwit><throwit> an energy parameter depending
on the strength of the disorder. In Fig. </throwit><throwit> we show
that this energy dependence is convincingly reproduced in numerical
data of the model: </throwit><throwit> diverges at </throwit><throwit> as in Eq. (</throwit><throwit>) for </throwit><throwit>. Note that the smallest
values for the localization length are obtained for </throwit><throwit>. We
remark that the validity of the exponential form of the wave function
has been questioned in previous studies </throwit><throwit>
presenting evidence for power-law localization usually related to
critical states.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p4">
    <p><text font="bold">Odd/even effects in quasi 1D systems.</text>
In 2D, the DOS also has a sharp peak at the band center
<throwit> and it was shown by the TMM that the
localization length again diverges </throwit><throwit>. A
finite-size-scaling (FSS) analysis of the TMM data together with
studies of the participation numbers and multifractal properties of
the eigenstates revealed </throwit><throwit> that the states at
</throwit><throwit> show critical behavior like in the 3D Anderson model at the MIT
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">Critical exponents in 3D.</text>
For the 3D model we computed the critical parameters at the MIT when
either <throwit> or </throwit><throwit> are varied across the transition, i.e., </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit> </throwit><throwit> at
fixed </throwit><throwit>. The left panel of Fig. </throwit><throwit> shows the reduced
localization length </throwit><throwit> for even </throwit><throwit> up to </throwit><throwit> at
</throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>. The transition from extended states for </throwit><throwit> to localized states for </throwit><throwit> is clearly visible as
</throwit><throwit> decreases (increases) with increasing </throwit><throwit> for the
extended (localized) case. In the right graph the resulting scaling
function </throwit><throwit> is plotted. It was obtained by a non-linear fit
taking non-linear and non-universal corrections to FSS </throwit><throwit>
into account. Comparing the exponents </throwit><throwit> and
</throwit><throwit> of the transitions obtained from the fits at
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, respectively, with recent results for
the Anderson model with pure diagonal disorder we find good agreement.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Conclusion.</text>
In this work we have studied the localization properties of the
Anderson model of localization with off-diagonal disorder. We find
non-localized states in 1D and 2D only at the band center. In quasi
1D we examined odd/even system size effects for the localization
length. We showed that the wave functions at <throwit> in 2D remain
critical up to the system sizes considered regardless of the odd/even
effects. Our numerical results match reasonably well with the
predictions </throwit><throwit>. In the 3D case, we
obtained the critical exponents of the MIT using TMM and FSS. Their
values agree with recent results for the model with only diagonal
disorder </throwit><throwit>. Thus although the off-diagonal case
exhibits some unusual features, its physics is nevertheless accurately
described by the orthogonal universality class within the scaling
theory of localization </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 14
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">Acknowledgements.</text>
We thank C. M. Soukoulis and J. Stolze for pointing out Refs. <throwit> to us.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">1.</text> In the Standard Model (SM) and its supersymmetric extensions, the
masses of electroweak gauge bosons, leptons, and quarks are generated
by interactions with Higgs fields <throwit>. The Yukawa couplings
between Higgs particles and fermions therefore grow with the masses
</throwit><throwit> of the fermions. The couplings obey a universal scaling law
</throwit><throwit> in the SM, with </throwit><throwit> being the
ground-state value of the Higgs field. In supersymmetric models, which
involve at least two Higgs doublets, the size of the Yukawa couplings
is also set by the fermion masses, yet the relationship is more
complex owing to the mixing among the Higgs fields. The Yukawa couplings
</throwit><throwit> of the two CP-even light/heavy Higgs bosons </throwit><throwit>
and of the CP-odd Higgs boson </throwit><throwit> in the minimal supersymmetric
extension of the Standard Model (MSSM) </throwit><throwit>, expressed in
units of the SM couplings, are collected in Table </throwit><throwit /><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 11
<para xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">a.)</text>
The QCD corrections to the top final states <throwit> can be interpreted
easily in two kinematical areas. Whenever the invariant mass of the </throwit><throwit> pair is close to
threshold, the gluonic Sommerfeld rescattering-correction
is positive and becomes large. In the threshold region the </throwit><throwit>
factor approaches the asymptotic form </throwit><throwit /></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>with the maximal quark velocity
<throwit>
in the </throwit><throwit> rest frame.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 15
<para xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold">b.)</text>
The results are exemplified in Fig. <throwit> for </throwit><throwit> and
30 and for the collider energy </throwit><throwit>.
If required by the size of the cross section, which should not fall
below </throwit><throwit> fb in order to be accessible experimentally, we switched
to </throwit><throwit>.
The Born
terms are shown by the dotted curves, while the final results for the cross
sections, including QCD corrections, are given by the full curves.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nlin0001052.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text>.
We generalize to the supersymmetric case the representation of the KP hierarchy as
a set of conservation laws for the generating series of the conserved
densities. We show that the hierarchy so obtained is isomorphic to
the JSKP of Mulase and Rabin.
We identify its “bosonic content” with the so–called
Darboux–KP hierarchy, which geometrically encompasses the theory of
Darboux–Bäcklund transformations, and is an extension both of the KP theory
and of the modified KP theory. Finally, we show how the
hierarchy can be linearized and how the supersymmetric counterpart of a
wide class of rational solution can be quite explicitly worked out.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002210.xml

    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text fontsize="80%">V. V. KORNYAK</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">Laboratory of Computing Technique and Automation,
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research,</text></p>
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="italic" fontsize="80%">Dubna, Moscow region 141980, Russia</text></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
<text fontsize="90%">
Suppose that <throwit> is a map of the Wiener space into itself, of the
following type: </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit> takes its values in the
Cameron-Martin space </throwit><throwit>. Assume also that </throwit><throwit> is a finite sum of
</throwit><throwit>-valued multiple Ito-Wiener integrals. In this work we prove that
if </throwit><throwit> preserves the Wiener measure, then necessarily </throwit><throwit> is in the
first Wiener chaos and the transformation corresponding to it is a
rotation in the sense of </throwit><throwit>.
Afterwards the ergodicity and mixing of rotations which
are second quantizations of the unitary operators on the Cameron-Martin
space, are characterized. Finally, the ergodicity of the
transformation </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>
where </throwit><throwit> is </throwit><throwit>-dimensional Wiener and </throwit><throwit> is non random is
characterized.
</throwit></text></p>

    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> <text fontsize="90%">We generalize the notion of trace to the Kontsevich quantization algebra and show that for all Poisson manifolds representable by quotients of a symplectic manifold by a Hamiltonian action of a nilpotent Lie group, the trace is given by integration with respect to a unimodular volume form.</text></p>

preserves each fiber of </throwit><throwit>. Let </throwit><throwit> be a family of </throwit><throwit>-equivariant elliptic operators
along the fiber </throwit><throwit>. Then the family index of </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit>,

and is a virtual <throwit>-representation (cf. [</throwit><text font="bold">LiuMa1</text>]).
We denote by <throwit> the </throwit><throwit>-invariant part of
</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="173%">A Model for</text></p>
    <p>[3mm]
<text font="bold" fontsize="173%">the Colour Form Factor</text></p>
    <p>[3mm]
<text font="bold" fontsize="173%">of the Proton</text></p>
    <p>[10mm]
<text fontsize="120%">Master of Science Thesis by Johann Dischler</text></p>
    <p>[2mm]
<text fontsize="120%">Thesis advisor: Torbjörn Sjöstrand</text></p>
    <p>[2mm]
<text font="italic">Department of Theoretical Physics,</text></p>
    <p>[1mm]
<text font="italic">Lund University, Lund, Sweden</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p>[2ex]
<inline-para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="middle" width="384.1pt">
        <para xml:id="p3.p1">
          <p>The total cross-section <throwit> and the jet cross-section </throwit><throwit>
differ at a proton-proton collision. The latter is divergent if arbitrarily
small transverse momenta are allowed. Even with some fixed lower </throwit><throwit> cutoff,
</throwit><throwit> increases much faster than </throwit><throwit> at high energies.
We have in this paper studied how the
divergence could be tamed by colour screening effects among the partons.</throwit></p>
          <p>To do this we have built a proton model where we assign momenta, positions and
colour charge to all partons in the proton.</p>
          <p>We find that the relative behaviour of the cross-sections can be better
understood by the inclusion of this effect.</p>
        </para>
      </inline-para></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0001307.xml
Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p7">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> <throwit>We consider the polarization of </throwit><throwit> baryons
produced in polarized Deep Inelastic Scattering at leading order, with
various spin configurations: longitudinally polarized leptons and
unpolarized nucleon; unpolarized leptons and longitudinally or transversely
polarized nucleons; longitudinally polarized leptons and nucleons. We show
how the different results in the different cases are related to different
aspects of the elementary dynamics and to the spin properties of the
distribution and fragmentation functions and show how a combined analysis
might give useful information. We give numerical results according
to several sets of polarized fragmentation functions recently proposed.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 10
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p8">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction</text>
<throwit> baryons produced in high energy interactions and resulting
from quark fragmentation allow a unique test of spin transfer
from partons to hadrons: the </throwit><throwit> polarization is easily
measurable by looking at the angular distribution of the
</throwit><throwit> decay (in the </throwit><throwit> helicity rest frame) and
the fragmenting parton polarization is determined by the elementary
Standard Model interactions, provided one knows the initial parton
spin state. In this respect </throwit><throwit>’s produced in lepton induced
processes are particularly interesting and indeed several
papers on this subject have recently been published or submitted
to e-Print archives </throwit><throwit>-</throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=nlin0002040.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text>
Iterating between a router and a traffic micro-simulation is an
increasibly accepted method for doing traffic assignment. This paper,
after pointing out that the analytical theory of simulation-based
assignment to-date is insufficient for some practical cases, presents
results of simulation studies from a real world study. Specifically,
we look into the issues of uniqueness, variability, and robustness and
validation. Regarding uniqueness, despite some cautionary notes from
a theoretical point of view, we find no indication of “meta-stable”
states for the iterations. Variability however is considerable. By
variability we mean the variation of the simulation of a given
plan set by just changing the random seed. We show then results from
three different micro-simulations under the same iteration scenario in
order to test for the robustness of the results under different
implementations. We find the results encouraging, also when comparing
to reality and with a traditional assignment result.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords:</text> dynamic traffic assignment (DTA); traffic micro-simulation;
TRANSIMS; large-scale simulations; urban planning</p>
  </para>

    <p>As for the correlation function we have the data for <throwit>

Para index in docroot: 5
<para>
    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">1. Introduction</text></p>
    <p>The aim of theoretical physics is to
provide a clear conceptual framework for the wide variety of natural
phenomena, so that not only are we able to make accurate predictions
to be checked against observations, but the underlying mathematical
structures of the world we live in can also become sufficiently
well understood by the scientific community. What are therefore the
key elements of a mathematical description of the physical world?
Can we derive all basic equations of theoretical physics from a few
symmetry principles? What do they tell us about the origin and
evolution of the universe? Why is gravitation so peculiar with
respect to all other fundamental interactions?</p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para align="center" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Solar Proton Burning Process Revisited within
a Covariant</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Model Based on the Bethe-Salpeter Formalism</text></p>
    <p>[1cm]
<text font="smallcaps">L.P. Kaptari<throwit>,
B. Kämpfer</throwit><throwit>
E. Grosse</throwit><throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[1cm]</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><throwit>Forschungszentrum Rossendorf,
PF 510119, 01314 Dresden, Germany</throwit></p>
    <p>[1mm]
<throwit>Bogoliubov Laboratory of Theoretical Physics, JINR Dubna,</throwit></p>
    <p>141980, Moscow reg., Russia</p>
    <p>[1mm]</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 5
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">I. Introduction:</text>
The proton-proton fusion reaction
<throwit> plays an important role in understanding processes
occurring in the Sun and in investigating the solar structure.
This reaction is the first step in the chain of nuclear reactions
producing the solar energy and neutrino
fluxes. Unfortunately the corresponding
cross section is far too low for a direct laboratory study.
In this context reliable theoretical calculations
and estimates of the reaction rates are of a great importance. Nowadays, the
most precise estimates have been obtained within the framework
of low-energy potential models </throwit><throwit>.
The accuracy of the obtained results is believed to be
of the order of few per cents or even better </throwit><throwit>.
For instance,
the low-energy cross section factor </throwit><throwit> that determines the
rates for the proton-proton fusion
is estimated as
</throwit><throwit> MeV b </throwit><throwit>.
While this number is considered as a canonical value, recent
estimates </throwit><throwit>, based on an
effective relativistic field theory,
claimed a considerably larger value being inconsistent with helioseismic
data </throwit><throwit>.
This has triggered a series of recalculations of </throwit><throwit>
within various approaches (cf. </throwit><throwit> and
further references therein), which recover values of </throwit><throwit>
centered around the canonical one.
However, there are some other indications </throwit><throwit>
that </throwit><throwit> may be </throwit><throwit> MeV b or even larger.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">II. Deuteron disintegration near thresholds:</text>
In this section we consider processes of the type
<throwit>, i.e. the
deuteron disintegration by leptons in electromagnetic
(</throwit><throwit>) and weak (</throwit><throwit>) reactions near threshold.
There the amplitudes
fall down rapidly and the cross sections are governed by the phase space of
final products. The threshold energies
are </throwit><throwit> MeV (</throwit><throwit> reactions)
and </throwit><throwit> MeV (weak interaction),
where </throwit><throwit> is the total energy
of the incident lepton in the deuteron rest frame.
We consider the electromagnetic disintegration process within the
one-photon exchange approximation (cf. fig. 1a) and the weak
positron-nucleon interaction (cf. fig. 1b)
within the effective Fermi model.
The deuteron vertex </throwit><throwit> is treated
in a covariant way within the BS formalism.
The BS equation has been solved numerically </throwit><throwit>,
with realistic one-boson-exchange interactions, and suitably
parameterized </throwit><throwit>.
The solution describes fairly accurate the main low-energy and
static characteristics of the deuteron, such as the deuteron binding energy,
and its quadrupole and magnetic moments </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 13
<para xml:id="p10">
    <p><text font="bold">III. Solar proton burning process:</text>
Let us now consider the process of the two-proton fusion
<throwit>
at low relative energies.
While this reaction looks rather similar to the processes in the previous section,
here appears a peculiarity. Due to the relation
</throwit><throwit>
(with </throwit><throwit> MeV, </throwit><throwit> MeV,
deuteron binding energy </throwit><throwit> MeV,
and </throwit><throwit> MeV)
there is no energy threshold for the
</throwit><throwit> fusion and, in principle, the fusion process may
occur at arbitrarily small
relative energies of the two protons. In this case, in the
cross section (</throwit><throwit>) two factors will play the major role:
(i) the two-proton flux (</throwit><throwit>) approaches
rather rapidly zero and the computation of the cross section becomes
problematic,
(ii) a strong Coloumb repulsion between protons makes the amplitude
</throwit><throwit> sharply decreasing and compensates singularities appearing from
the vanishing flux. In order to avoid uncertainties connected to these
circumstances
one usually separates the contribution of Coulomb repulsion by factorizing
the Coulomb part of the two-proton final state, which at low
relative energies may be taken as
</throwit><throwit>
where </throwit><throwit> is the Sommerfeld penetration parameter,
</throwit><throwit> denotes the relative
velocity of the protons, and </throwit><throwit> is the corresponding
relative kinetic energy;
the exponent is known as the
Gamov penetration factor </throwit><throwit>.
Then one introduces the notion of the
</throwit><throwit> factor, which is determined only by the nuclear part
of the interaction and is connected with the cross section by
</throwit><throwit>
Then the rate of </throwit><throwit> fusion reactions can be written in
the form</throwit><throwit>
</throwit><throwit>
here </throwit><throwit> is the temperature in units of </throwit><throwit> K,
</throwit><throwit> dominates
the temperature dependence of the reaction rate,
</throwit><throwit> is a screening factor calculated first by Salpeter </throwit><throwit>,
and </throwit><throwit> is in MeV b. The </throwit><throwit> factor is needed
at the most probable interaction energy </throwit><throwit>,
which is in a range of 5 keV </throwit><throwit> 30 keV.
However, in most analyzes in the literature, the value of
</throwit><throwit> is quoted at vanishing energy, obtained , e.g. within
the low-energy effective theory </throwit><throwit>.
Hence, for the sake of extrapolation to the finite value
of </throwit><throwit>, a good estimate
of the associated derivatives is also required.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 19
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">IV. Summary:</text>
We present a covariant model, based on the Bethe-Salpeter formalism,
to investigate the energy dependence of the
matrix elements relevant to the solar proton-proton burning process.
Explicit covariant expressions for the cross section and the low-energy cross
section factor <throwit>
are presented. Our numerical estimates of </throwit><throwit> and its
derivatives confirm previous results.</throwit></p>
  </para>

the Heisenberg-Landau JINR-FRG collaboration project, and by

  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para class="ltx_minipage" vattach="top" width="469.5pt" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="80%">Abstract<text font="medium">. We present the results of a Molecular Dynamics computer
simulation of a binary Lennard-Jones liquid confined in a narrow pore.
The surface of the pore has an amorphous structure similar to that of
the confined liquid. We find that the static properties of the liquid are
not affected by the confinement, while the dynamics changes dramatically.
By investigating the time and temperature dependence of the intermediate
scattering function we show that the dynamics of the particles close
to the center of the tube is similar to the one in the bulk, whereas
the characteristic relaxation time <throwit> of the intermediate
scattering function at wavevector </throwit><throwit> and distance </throwit><throwit> from the axis
of the pore increases continuously when approaching the wall, leading
to an apparent divergence in the vicinity of the wall. This effect is
seen for intermediate temperatures down to temperatures close to the
glass transition. The </throwit><throwit>-dependence of </throwit><throwit> can be
described by an empirical law of the form </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> are constants,
and </throwit><throwit> is the only parameter which shows a significant temperature
dependence. </throwit></text></text></p>
  </para>

<para xml:id="p14">
    <p><text font="bold">Theorem 1</text> <text font="italic">Given two prime numbers <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> we define r as the lowest positive integer x such that </throwit><throwit> for an arbitrary integer </throwit><throwit>.     <p><text font="bold" fontsize="90%">Abstract.<text font="medium"> Let <throwit> be a finite group and </throwit><throwit> a class function. /home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=quant-ph0002032.xml
Para index in docroot: 2
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Teleportation and Secret Sharing with
Pure Entangled States  <throwit /></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">I. Introduction: <throwit /><throwit /></text>In recent years quantum entanglement [1] has found many exciting applications
which have considerable bearing on the emerging fields of quantum
information [2] and quantum computing [3]. Two such key applications
are quantum teleportation [4] and quantum secret sharing [9]. Quantum
teleportation involves secure transfer of an unknown qubit from one
place to another and in quantum secret sharing, quantum information
encoded in a qubit is split among several parties such that only one
of them is able to recover the qubit exactly provided all the other
parties agree to cooperate.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 12
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p11">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">II. Quantum Teleportation: BBCJPW Protocol</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 27
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p26">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">III. Conclusive Teleportation: Proposal of Mor
and Horodecki</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 33
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p32">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">IV. Qubit assisted Conclusive Teleportation <throwit /><throwit /></text>We now discuss two methods for conclusive teleportation which are
optimal. We will see that both these methods can appropriately be
referred to as qubit assisted processes, since in both schemes either
Alice or Bob are required to prepare a qubit in some specified state
to implement the respective protocol. Since the process of teleportation
involves two parties, so, modifications as far as measurement and
other operations are concerned, may be suggested for any one of the
parties without introducing any new operations for the other side.
By this we mean that we can either modify the measurement part of
Alice keeping the Bob part the same i.e he only has to do the standard
rotations (proposal 1) or we can also suggest some further operations
to be carried out by Bob once the original protocol of teleportation
gets completed (proposal 2), which implies measurement part of Alice
remains unchanged.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 34
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p33">
    <p><text font="bold">IV. a. Proposal I</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 66

    <p><text font="bold">IV. b. Proposal II:</text></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 3
<para xml:id="p2">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Protein Folding Simulations in a Deformed Energy
Landscape</text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 7
<para xml:id="p6">
    <p class="ltx_align_center"><text font="bold">ABSTRACT</text></p>
    <p>A modified version of stochastic tunneling, a recently
introduced global optimization technique, is introduced as a
new generalized-ensemble technique and tested for a benchmark
peptide, Met-enkephalin. It is demonstrated that the new technique allows
to evaluate folding properties and especially the glass temperature <throwit>
of this peptide.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 24
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p22">

Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan. I like to thank the Institute
and specially C.K. Hu, head of the Laboratory for Statistical and
Computational Physics, for the kind hospitality extended to me.
Financial support from a Research Excellence
Fund of the State of Michigan is gratefully acknowledged.</throwit><throwit /></p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="144%">Moduli constraints on primordial black holes</text></p>
    <p>Martin Lemoine<throwit /></p>
    <p><text font="italic">DARC, UMR–8629 CNRS, Observatoire de Paris-Meudon, F–92195

Para index in docroot: 4
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text>
The amount of late decaying massive particles (e.g., gravitinos,
moduli) produced in the evaporation of primordial black holes (PBHs)
of mass <throwit>g is calculated. Limits imposed by big-bang
nucleosynthesis on the abundance of these particles are used to
constrain the initial PBH mass fraction </throwit><throwit> (ratio of PBH energy
density to critical energy density at formation), as: </throwit><throwit>; </throwit><throwit> is the fraction of PBH luminosity
going into gravitinos or moduli, </throwit><throwit> is the upper bound
imposed by nucleosynthesis on the number density to entropy density
ratio of gravitinos or moduli. This notably implies that such PBHs
should never come to dominate the cosmic energy density.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math-ph0001029.xml
Para index in docroot: 8
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">1. Introduction.</text>
In the study of nonequilibrium statistical mechanics, if
nonhamiltonian forces are used to achieve nonequilibrium, a thermostat
is needed to cool the system. The <text font="italic">Gaussian thermostats</text> introduced
by W. Hoover and D. Evans have the great interest of respecting the
deterministic character of the equations of motion (see for instance
Evans and Morriss [3]). Starting with an evolution equation <throwit> in phase space, a Gaussian thermostat constrains the evolution
to a prescribed hypersurface </throwit><throwit> by projecting </throwit><throwit>, for
</throwit><throwit>, to the tangent plane to </throwit><throwit> at </throwit><throwit>. In the present
note we follow Cohen-Rondoni, and Gallavotti comparing an isokinetic and an isoenergetic thermostat, and showing that they give the same result in the limit of a large system (thermodynamic limit).
In equilibrium statistical mechanics one can show rigorously
that fixing the kinetic energy is equivalent to fixing the total energy,
asymptotically for large systems (see [6]). It is therefore natural to
hope that something similar is true for nonequilibrium, as advocated by
Gallavotti (many references, see [4], [5]) and by Cohen and Rondoni [2].
However, the entropy considerations which are available in equilibrium
statistical mechanics fail utterly outside of equilibrium, </throwit><text font="italic">i.e.</text>,
fluctuations of energy at fixed kinetic energy are uncontrolled, and the
situation appears rather hopeless. We shall show however that the
argument of Cohen and Rondoni can be modified to apply, at least formally, to the dynamics of actually infinite systems. (In a different context – at equilibrium – Sinai [7] has also shown the interest of considering the dynamics of infinite systems). Our approach will remain formal at the level of infinite system evolution equations: technical problems arise there, which do not seem directly related to the problem at hand, and are better discussed separately.
We shall consider a system of particles in <throwit> dimensions which is infinitely extended in </throwit><throwit> dimensions, with </throwit><throwit>, and we shall discuss states of infinitely many particles which are invariant under translations in </throwit><throwit>. The assumption that the infinite systems dynamics is well defined, and </throwit><throwit>-ergodicity, will be sufficient to establish the equivalence of isokinetic and isoenergetic nonequilibrium steady states
</throwit><text font="bold">2. IK an IE dynamics.</text>
We recall now the definition of the <text font="italic">Gaussian isokinetic</text>
(IK) thermostat. We take for our configuration space <throwit> a compact
subset of </throwit><throwit> where </throwit><throwit> is the </throwit><throwit>-torus,
and momentum space is identified with </throwit><throwit>. We assume that a
force field on </throwit><throwit> is given, written as </throwit><throwit>, where
</throwit><throwit> is a potential, and </throwit><throwit> is a nongradient vector
field</throwit><throwit>. Consider now the equations of motion</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>completed by elastic reflection at the boundary of <throwit>. Without the
term </throwit><throwit> this time evolution would be Hamiltonian. The term
</throwit><throwit> maintains the system outside of equilibrium. The term </throwit><throwit>
is the thermostat. We obtain the Gausssian isokinetic thermostat by
choosing </throwit><throwit> such that the kinetic energy is constant:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic">i.e.</text>,</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>Note that if <throwit> is locally a gradient (corresponding to a multivalued potential function on </throwit><throwit>), the Dettmann-Morriss pairing theorem asserts that (except for one value </throwit><throwit>) the spectrum of Lyapunov exponents of an ergodic measure is symmetric with respect to some constant </throwit><throwit> which is in general nonzero. (We shall however not make use of this result).
We consider now the </throwit><text font="italic">Gaussian isoenergetic</text> (IE) thermostat
associated again with the force <throwit>, but where we want to
maintain fixed the energy function</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>The equations of motion are again of the form (1) and using (3) the isoenergetic condition is</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="italic">i.e.</text>,</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>With the Gaussian isoenergetic (IE) thermostat the time evolution is thus defined by (1), (4).
We consider now the IK and the IE time evolution in the infinite
system limit. We want to study the time evolution of a state <throwit>
ergodic under </throwit><throwit>-space translations. We shall ignore
existence and uniqueness problems for these evolution equations, and our
discussion will thus remain formal in this respect. (In fact, the
one-dimensional situation may be relatively accessible to rigorous
study, but the </throwit><throwit>-dimensional case with </throwit><throwit> appears much more difficult).
Physically we may think of a system of particles in a region </throwit><throwit>
invariant under </throwit><throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> but
possibly </throwit><throwit>. For example we may consider a shear flow
between two moving plates, but we do not take the limit where these two
plates are infinitely far apart, as this would introduce unwanted
hydrodynamic instabilities. Another example would be a system of
particles in </throwit><throwit>. In the </throwit><throwit>-direction we put an
electric field and we assume a suitable boundary condition (see [1]).
The expressions </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> diverge for an infinite system, but behave additively with respect to volume, and we can (under mild conditions on </throwit><throwit>) define the average per unit volume with respect to </throwit><throwit>, noted </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>. Since </throwit><throwit> is ergodic, it is carried by points (in infinite phase space) for which the large volume average of </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit> is well defined and constant, equal to </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>. The expressions </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> behave almost additively with respect to volume and, again under mild conditions, we can define the large volume averages </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. Again, </throwit><throwit> is carried by points (in infinite phase space) for which the large volume average of </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit> is well defined and constant, equal to </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>.
In our formal treatment of the infinite system IK or IE evolution we consider the time evolution of an infinite phase space point, generic with respect to the space ergodic measure </throwit><throwit>, replacing the expressions (2), (4) for </throwit><throwit> by their large volume limits</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>or</p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>In general <throwit> depends on time, and so does </throwit><throwit> given by </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>. Suppose now that </throwit><throwit> is invariant under the IK or IE time evolution; then </throwit><throwit> and also </throwit><throwit> are time independent, so that</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>But then <throwit> and </throwit><throwit> coincide: the infinite system IK and IE
evolutions have the same time invariant space ergodic states </throwit><throwit>.
(Apart from the use of space ergodicity for an actually infinite system,
this is the remark of Cohen and Rondoni [2]).
Note that, if we replace in (3) </throwit><throwit> by </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit> by
</throwit><throwit>, imposing </throwit><throwit> yields</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>and in the infinite system limit we have again equivalence with the
isokinetic ensemble. On the other hand, if <throwit> is not of the form
</throwit><throwit>, the Gaussian thermostat doesn’t give a term
of the form </throwit><throwit> in (1) and we do not have equivalence with the
isokinetic ensemble in the infinite system limit.
For the purposes of nonequilibrium statistical mechanics one should presumably restrict </throwit><throwit> to be an infinite system SRB state (defined so that the time entropy per unit volume is equal to the sum of the positive Lyapunov exponents per unit volume). Hopefully, the space ergodic SRB states form a 2-parameter family parametrized by the average number of particles and the energy (or the kinetic energy) per unit volume. But the delicate question of identifying the natural nonequilibrium steady states is here bypassed by the remark that they are the same for the infinite system IK and IE evolutions.
In equilibrium statistical mechanics the proof of equivalence of ensembles is somewhat subtle, and uses in particular the concavity properties of the entropy (see [6]). One might think that the corresponding problem in nonequilibrium statistical mechanics would be even more difficult, and the above findings about the equivalence of IK and IE appear thus surprisingly cheap. What we have shown is however only that the IK and IE evolutions coincide (formally) in the infinite system limit; the detailed study of the natural nonequilibrium states remains to be made.
</throwit><text font="bold">3. The constant <throwit> case.</throwit></text>
It is of interest to consider the equations (1) with <throwit> = constant. For this situation one obtains the following result.
</throwit><text font="bold">Proposition.</text>

    <throwit>
    </throwit><p><text font="slanted">in <throwit>, where </throwit><throwit> and we impose elastic reflection on the boundary of </throwit><throwit>. Para index in docroot: 5
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract </text> The generalized hyperharmonic numbers <throwit> are defined by means of
the multiple harmonic numbers. We show that the hyperharmonic numbers </throwit><throwit> satisfy certain recurrence relation which allow us to write them in terms of classical harmonic numbers. Moreover, we prove that the Euler-type
sums with hyperharmonic numbers:</throwit></p>
    <throwit>
    </throwit><p>can be expressed as a rational linear combination of products of Riemann zeta values and harmonic numbers. This is an extension of the results of Dil (2015) <throwit> and Mez</throwit><throwit> (2010) </throwit><throwit>. Some interesting new consequences and illustrative examples are considered.
</throwit><throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">Keywords</text> Euler sums; generalized hyperharmonic numbers; harmonic numbers; Riemann zeta function; Stirling numbers.
<throwit>
</throwit><text font="bold">AMS Subject Classifications (2010):</text> 11B73; 11B83; 11M06; 11M32; 11M99</p>
  </para>

    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text></p>
    <p><text fontsize="90%">We carefully analyze the relative branching ratios of <throwit> final states
</throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit> and </throwit><throwit>,
from various resonances of </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>, </throwit><throwit>. We find
that the Bose symmetry interference effects would make their ratios to
obviously differ from the naive counting values without considering these
effects. The results should be applied to estimate correctly various
</throwit><throwit> decay branching ratios of relevant resonances.</throwit></text></p>

to the space group C</throwit><throwit> as PbZrO</throwit><throwit /><throwit>. Below
150 cm</throwit><throwit> (spectral region depicted in the insert of Fig. 1)
six modes at frequencies of 35, 44, 50, 55, 70, and 132 </throwit><throwit>
are observed. This spectral region contains the external modes
related to Pb- lattice modes</throwit><throwit>. In the high frequency
region, </throwit><throwit> cm</throwit><throwit> some internal modes
related to certain polyatomic groups of the material appears in
the Raman spectra. In the 0.0 GPa spectrum, bands at 204, 232
(Zr-O bending), 285, 330, and 344 (</throwit><throwit> torsions), 501, and

    <p class="ltx_align_left"><text font="bold">Example 1.4</text><text font="bold">:</text></p>
    <p>Let <throwit> be a closed hyperbolic 3-manifold whose fundamental group surjects
the free group of rank </throwit><throwit>. Such examples are easily constructed
by doing hyperbolic surgery on a null-homotopic hyperbolic knot
in </throwit><throwit> [Section 3, BW].
Let </throwit><throwit> denote such a map.
Let </throwit><throwit> be any hyperbolic 3-manifold such that </throwit><throwit> has
two generators, then there is an epimorphism </throwit><throwit>.
If we choose </throwit><throwit> such that the volume of </throwit><throwit> is larger than the volume
of </throwit><throwit>, then the map realizing the epimorphism </throwit><throwit>
must be zero degree by the work of Gromov and Thurston, </throwit><throwit>.
We remark that the volumes of hyperbolic 3-manifolds of rank </throwit><throwit>
are unbounded. Briefly, it follows from work of Adams that the
volumes of hyperbolic 2-bridge knot complements are unbounded. Doing large
enough hyperbolic Dehn surgeries on these gives the required family, see [CR].</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 25
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Note if <throwit> and </throwit><throwit>
are homeomorphic and satisfy Thurston’s geometrization conjecture,
then a </throwit><throwit>-surjective map </throwit><throwit> must be degree one. For
since </throwit><throwit> is hopfian, </throwit><throwit> is surjective implies </throwit><throwit> is an
isomorphism. Since </throwit><throwit> is aspherical </throwit><throwit> must be a homotopy
equivalence, and so in particular, </throwit><throwit> is of degree one. Thus the
question above is a kind of generalization of the Hopfian property:
the condition “homeomorphic manifolds” is replaced by “manifolds of
the same rank”, the condition “</throwit><throwit>-surjective” is replaced by
“</throwit><throwit>-surjective” or “</throwit><throwit>-finite-index”, and the conclusion replace
“degree one” by “non-zero degree”. It is easy to construct examples
to show that
“non-zero degree” cannot be sharpened to “degree one”, see the examples
in Section 3.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 26
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">One of the main results of this paper is to prove that for Seifert
fibered 3-manifolds Question 1.5 has a positive answer (see Theorem
2.1 and Remark 2.4).
In §4 we use this result to construct the
first known example of a Haken 3-manifold which is minimal with
respect to degree 1 mappings in Thurston’s picture of 3-manifolds
(Theorem 4.1).
The manifold is a graph
manifold built from the union of two trefoil knot complements.
An orientable 3-manifold <throwit> is minimal if there is a degree one map
</throwit><throwit> implies either </throwit><throwit> or </throwit><throwit>. Usually it is difficult
tell if a 3-manifold is minimal.
We remark that all minimal Seifert manifolds are non-Haken </throwit><throwit>,
and that the known minimal hyperbolic 3-manifolds are also non-Haken
</throwit><throwit>, see [BW], [RW] and [LWZ]
for a further discussion of such matters.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002002.xml
Para index in docroot: 21
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">Definition.</text> Let <throwit> be the set of all hyperbolic
3-manifolds of totally geodesic boundary and with volume bounded
above by </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 25
<para class="ltx_noindent">
    <p><text font="bold">Remark on Theorem 4.</text> Theorem 4 can be restated as follows:
For hyperbolic 3-manifolds with totally geodesic boundary and bounded volume,
the areas of their boundaries have an upper bound, and the lengths
of simple closed geodesics on their boundary have a lower bound.
Neither of those two assertions is true in dimension 2. Surfaces
of given area can have geodesic boundaries of any length.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 30
<para>
    <p><text font="bold">References.</text></p>
  </para>

<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">1. Generic morphisms of surfaces and the Chisini conjecture.</text>
A ramified covering <throwit> is
a finite morphism of a non-singular irreducible projective surface
onto the projective plane.
The </throwit><text font="italic">branch curve</text> of <throwit> is defined as
the set of points over which </throwit><throwit> is not étale.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 20
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p15">
    <p><text font="bold">2. Cusps of branch curves and BMY inequalities.</text>
Consider a generic morphism <throwit> of degree </throwit><throwit>
with branch curve </throwit><throwit>.
Denote by </throwit><throwit> the degree of </throwit><throwit> (it is always even),
by </throwit><throwit> the genus of the desingularization of </throwit><throwit>,
and by </throwit><throwit> the number of cusps of </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=1701.01215.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p1">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract</text>
We study the two-dimensional stationary Navier-Stokes equations
describing the flows around a rotating obstacle.
The unique existence of solutions and their asymptotic behavior at spatial infinity are established
when the rotation speed of the obstacle and the given exterior force are sufficiently small.</p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 8
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold">Keywords</text>  Navier-Stokes equations <throwit> two-dimensional exterior flows </throwit><throwit> scale-criticality </throwit><throwit> flows around a rotating obstacle</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 9
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">Mathematics Subject Classification (2000)</text>  35B35 <throwit> 35Q30 </throwit><throwit> 76D05</throwit></p>
  </para>

<para xml:id="p38">
    <p><text font="bold">(8)</text> The prediction for the mixing of the electron neutrino is quite
interesting because, depending on what one assumes for <throwit>, it
comes out quite naturally to give </throwit><text font="italic">either</text> the small-angle MSW
solution to the solar neutrino problem <text font="italic">or</text> the vacuum “just-so”
solution. If one supposes that the matrix <throwit> does not have large
mixing between the first family and the other families, i.e.
that the 12, 21, 13, and 31 elements of </throwit><throwit> are negligible, then
the mass matrix of the light neutrinos, which has the usual “see-saw”
form </throwit><throwit>, also gives very little mixing between
the first family and the others. (See Eq. (11).) This is also the
case no matter what the form of </throwit><throwit> if the parameter </throwit><throwit>
(meaning that </throwit><throwit>). In these cases, the mixing of the electron
neutrino comes entirely, or almost entirely, from diagonalizing </throwit><throwit>.
In that case one gets a sharp prediction that </throwit><throwit>. For maximal
mixing of </throwit><throwit>, as needed to fit the atmospheric
neutrino data, this gives </throwit><throwit>,
which is in the allowed range for small-angle MSW.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 50
<para xml:id="p46">
    <p><text font="bold">(9)</text> Finally, there is a prediction for the <throwit>
mixing angle. It is easy to show that in </throwit><text font="italic">both</text> cases, the
small-angle MSW case and the bimaximal vacuum oscillation case,
the mixing <throwit> comes out the same: </throwit><throwit>.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math-ph0001032.xml
Para index in docroot: 6
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p5">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract.</text> A quantum integrable model
is considered which
describes a quantization of affine hyper-elliptic
Jacobian. This model is shown to possess the
property of duality: a dual model with inverse
Planck constant exists such that the eigen-functions of its
Hamiltonians coincide with the eigen-functions of
Hamiltonians of the original model.
We explain that this duality can be considered as duality
between homologies and cohomologies
of quantized affine hyper-elliptic Jacobian.</p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=math0002015.xml

    <p class="ltx_align_center">Toshiki NAKASHIMA</p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=astro-ph0001305.xml
Para index in docroot: 9
<para xml:id="p3">
    <p><text font="bold">There are about 2000 gamma ray burst (GRB) events known to us
with data pouring in at the rate of one per day. While the
afterglows of GRBs in radio, optical and X-ray bands are
successfully explained by the fireball model, a significant
difficulty with the proposed mechanisms for GRBs is that a small amount
(<throwit>) of baryons in the ejecta can be involved.
There are very few models that fulfill this criteria together with
other observational features, among which are the differentially
rotating collapsed object model </throwit><throwit> and the
”supernova” model </throwit><throwit>. These models generally invoke rapidly
rotating neutron stars, and may be subject to uncertainties in the
formation mechanisms and the equations of state of neutron stars.
According to Spruit </throwit><throwit>, the problem of making a GRB from
an X-ray binary is reduced to finding a
plausible way to make the star rotate differentially.
We suggest that a model of strange star (SS) can naturally explain
many of these bursts with not only their low baryon content
</throwit><throwit>, but the differential rotation which leads to an
enhanced magnetic field that surfaces up and is responsible for
GRBs.</throwit></text></p>
  </para>
  

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002156.xml
Para index in docroot: 4
<para align="center" xml:id="p2">
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">Coherent Contributions of Nuclear Mesons to</text></p>
    <p><text font="bold" fontsize="120%">[.50em]
Electroproduction
and the HERMES Effect<throwit /></text></p>
    <p>[10 mm]</p>

/home/local/yzan/Desktop/Cleanskin/results/latexml/=hep-ph0002120.xml
Para index in docroot: 7
<para class="ltx_noindent" xml:id="p6">
    <p><text font="bold">Abstract:</text> <throwit>An azimuthal dependence of pions produced in polarized Deep Inelastic
Scattering, </throwit><throwit>, has been recently observed
and might be related to the so-called Collins effect. We discuss
in details, for a general spin configuration of the nucleon,
the kinematics of the process and methods of extracting information on
the fragmentation properties of a polarized quark. Assuming that the
observed azimuthal dependence is indeed due to Collins effect, we
derive a lower bound estimate for the size of the quark analysing power,
which turns out to be large.</throwit></p>
  </para>

Para index in docroot: 42
<para xml:id="p13">
    <p><text font="bold">FIG. 11–</text> Effect of using different PSF stars on the PSF
subtracted F160W non-coronagraphic image. Zoomed-in
<throwit>″</throwit><throwit>″
region of the NICMOS camera 2 non-coronagraphic 1.6 </throwit><throwit>m broad-band
image of the field of LBQS 1210+1731, on using PSF stars P330E,
BRI 0021, Q1718PSF, and GSC4. The PSF star
observation dates and average breathing values are (July 8, 1998; 1.0),
(December 20, 1997; -1.2), (July 21, 1998; 1.8) and
(Nov. 11, 1997; -3.2),
respectively for the (a) top left, (b) top right, (c) bottom left,
and (d) bottom right
panels. The quasar observations were obtained on July 22, 1998 at mean
breathing value of 2.3. The differences between the different panels
may be largely because of breathing differences. (The match with
the quasar breathing value is poor for panels b and d, while
it is best for panel c.) The negative feature near the right edge of
panel (c) is because of a second star near
the main PSF star used for subtraction.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 45
<para xml:id="p16">
    <p><text font="bold">FIG. 14–</text> Effect of different focus positions
on the PSF subtracted F160W non-coronagraphic image. Zoomed-in
<throwit>″</throwit><throwit>″
region of the NICMOS camera 2 non-coronagraphic 1.6 </throwit><throwit>m broad-band
image of the field of LBQS 1210+1731. (a) The top left
panel shows the PSF subtraction obtained on using PSF star
image from the field of galaxy cluster CL0939+47 which has the same
“camera 1-2” focus as our quasar data. (b) The top right panel shows
the difference of two simulated Tiny Tim
PSFs corresponding to the “camera 2 focus” and “camera 1-2” focus.
(c) The bottom left panel shows, on the same intensity stretch as
the top left panel, the difference of the two simulated Tiny Tim PSFs
after normalizing each to match the quasar.
(d) The bottom right panel shows the quasar image after subtracting
a synthetic PSF made by multiplying the July 8, 1998 image of P330E
by the ratio of the Tiny Tim models for the two focii. See the text
for details.</throwit></p>
  </para>

schemes in data reduction and different interpolation schemes in image
display on the PSF subtracted F160W non-coronagraphic
image. Zoomed-in <throwit>″</throwit><throwit>″
region of the F160W image for (a) no magnification in image
analysis, bicubic interpolation in image display (top left),
(b) magnification by a factor of 2 and bicubic interpolation in image
display (top right), (c) no magnification and pixel replication in
image display (bottom left), (d) magnification by a factor of 2 and
pixel replication in image display (bottom right). Note the
similarities between the magnified and unmagnified
images, resulting from camera 2 being almost critically
sampled at 1.6 </throwit><throwit>m.</throwit></p>

Para index in docroot: 49
<para xml:id="p20">
    <p><text font="bold">FIG. 18–</text> Effect of shifting the PSF star by 0.1 pixel
in various directions relative to the quasar on the
PSF subtracted non-coronagraphic F160W image. The central
panel (e) is the optimum minimum-variance solution (same as
Fig. 4b). Top central (b) and bottom central (h) panels correspond
to PSF star shifts of 0.1 pixel in +y and -y directions. Left central
(d) and right central (f) panels correspond to PSF star shifts
of 0.1 pixel in -x and +x directions. Top left (a), top right (c),
bottom left (g), and bottom right (i) panels correspond to PSF star
shifts of 0.1 pixel in the top left, top right, bottom
left, and bottom right directions, respectively. The
large residuals caused by the slight shifts illustrate
how well centered the PSF star is with respect to the quasar in the
optimum PSF subtraction. The regions shown are 2.74
<throwit> regions around the quasar.</throwit></p>
  </para>
  

Para index in docroot: 50
<para xml:id="p21">
    <p><text font="bold">FIG. 19–</text> Mean star formation rate in DLAs in
M<throwit> yr</throwit><throwit> as a function of redshift, for </throwit><throwit>,
</throwit><throwit> km s</throwit><throwit> Mpc</throwit><throwit>. The filled
triangle shows the upper limit from this
work, while the unfilled triangles show the limits from Bunker
et al. (1999). The curve shows the prediction from a closed-box model
applied to proto-disk galaxies, as calculated by Bunker et al.
(1999). Note that our SFR limit is a factor of
3 improvement over the tightest limits of Bunker et al. (1999), and
that most data points are inconsistent with the proto-disk model.</throwit></p>
  </para>
